PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
SENATE
Hansard
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH PARLIAMENT
(SECOND PERIOD)

PARA.TAB: The Senate, on 27 May 1993, adjourned to 17 August 1993, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 27 May 1993, the Senate met on Tuesday, 17 August 1993 at 2 p.m.
His Excellency the Honourable William George Hayden, Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia, entered the chamber and, taking his seat on the dais, said:
Honourable Senators:
I am present to administer to senators elected to serve in the Senate from 1 July 1993 the oath or affirmation of allegiance, as required by section 42 of the constitution.
The Clerk produced and laid on the table the certificates of election for the following senators elected, on 13 March 1993, to serve in the Senate for the respective states from 1 July 1993:
New South Wales—Graham Frederick Richardson; Michael Ehrenfried Baume; John Philip Faulkner; John William Tierney; Kerry Walter Sibraa; John Alexander Lindsay Macdonald.
Queensland—Margaret Reynolds; David John MacGibbon; William George O'Chee; Malcolm Arthur Colston; Warwick Raymond Parer; John Woodley.
South Australia—Amanda Eloise Vanstone; Nick Bolkus; Nicholas Hugh Minchin; Dominic John Foreman; Alan Baird Ferguson; Meg Heather Lees.
Tasmania—Brian Roper Archer; John Coates; Brian Francis Gibson; Brian Harradine; Shayne Michael Murphy; Michael Carter Tate.
Victoria—Gareth John Evans; James Robert Short; Kim John Carr; Julian John James McGauran; Alice Olive Zakharov; Judith Mary Troeth.
Western Australia—Susan Christine Knowles; Peter Francis Salmon Cook; Ian Gordon Campbell; Christopher Vaughan Evans; Christopher Martin Ellison; Diane Elizabeth Margetts.

The Clerk informed the Senate that on 5 July 1993 Mr President received a letter from Senator Michael Carter Tate resigning his place as a senator for the state of Tasmania. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the constitution Mr President notified the Governor of Tasmania of the vacancy in the representation of that state caused by the resignation.
The above named senators, with the exception of Michael Carter Tate, made and subscribed the oath or affirmation of allegiance.

TAB.EMPHASIS: His Excellency the Governor-General having retired—

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Clerk, I remind the Senate that the time has come when it is necessary for the Senate to choose one of its members to become President. I propose Senator Sibraa, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senator Sibraa take the Chair of the Senate as President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, in accordance with the standing orders, Senator Sibraa is elected President and will take the chair.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Senator Sibraa having been conducted to the dais—

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator Sibraa)—I thank all honourable senators for the high honour that they have bestowed upon me today in re-electing me for what is now the fourth time. I well recall that, in February 1987, I went to Senator Ray and asked, `Do you think that I should stand for the position?'. He said, `Why not—you'll probably get into the history books as the shortest serving President of all time!'. I am personally very pleased, of course, that that has not happened. I can assure you all that I am very much aware of the responsibilities attached to the office of President that you have elected me to today, and with your permission I shall now occupy the chair.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of government senators, may I express congratulations to you on your election. You have served in this Senate since 1975, with one small hiccup along the way, and have been President in this place since February 1987.

PARA.TAB: You have served honourably and with distinction throughout that period, as I believe has been recognised by the non-contest for the position on this occasion again today. Might I add that you have served with distinction, not only in this chamber and in Australia but also in many other parts of the world. It could not be said of you, as it was said of one of your distinguished previous figures in Labor Party history, that they are creating countries faster than you can visit them.

It is not an easy job at the best of times, and it is not going to be any easier, of course, in the circumstances which now confront us in this place. I am sure you will handle the job with great skill and good humour, as you have done in the past. I repeat my good wishes and I am sure that in doing so I speak for all honourable senators in this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to congratulate you on behalf of opposition senators. You certainly are a survivor. It was not long ago that we thought you would not hold your seat; then we heard you were going to Hungary. Neither has occurred and you are back here as President again.
—You got it wrong again.

—We might have got the timing wrong; we are not sure of that. There is still a rumour or two about. In August of 1990 I congratulated you on your diplomatic skills. I will not do that again on this occasion in case we want to comment adversely in due course. Today we wish you well. We know that—
—That is a great way to start, Robert. You won't say that in case you have to contradict it later!

—Well, she started off on the right foot. Mr President, you know we hold you in high regard and you know particularly our great respect for the office that you hold. You will also be aware that ministers in the last government constantly abused the forms of this place and made your life difficult. I want to assure you, Mr President, that opposition senators will continue to cooperate and otherwise be helpful to you, as we have in the past. We congratulate you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I offer you congratulations on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We believe that you have unfailingly and often quite frustratingly displayed the impartiality and skills required of your position—skills which we believe will be increasingly important in the interesting times which lie ahead of us in this chamber in the coming months.

PARA.TAB: We wish you well in this important position and we hope you will look kindly upon suggestions to reform our sitting hours to enable some of us to still greet you in the pool in the mornings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I offer congratulations on behalf of the National Party. We wish you the best in your term as President. You have always displayed fairness and have been unbiased in the period that you have occupied the high office of President. We see no reason why you would not honour those commitments in the future. Once again, we extend to you our best wishes for your term in the chair.
—Mr President, I did not think there would be a contest and, of course, there has not been a contest for the position of President—
—In public.

—Senator Kernot says `in public'. The only hint of a possible challenge was when a journalist rang me a couple of weeks ago and announced that you, Mr President, had decided to stand for the presidency of the Senate. It was news to me that you were not going to stand. In any event, that journalist said to me, `What about yourself? Were you thinking of going for the presidency of the Senate in the same circumstance'. My reply to her was, `I would rather vote for Kerry Sibraa than for myself'. I do not know whether that says anything for you, Mr President.
—I think it is going to get me into trouble.
—I have appreciated very much the way in which you have handled situations from the chair. The fact is that you are now entering, what is it, a third term?

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Fourth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your entering a fourth term in that chair gives us a great deal of encouragement that the way in which you have dealt with situations in this chamber will continue, much to the benefit of this chamber as a whole. I have always believed that you have an acute sense of justice and fair play. That was notably exhibited on a particular day in August 1975, which I will never forget. You also apply that sense of justice and fair play to the proceedings of this chamber.

—Mr President, on behalf of the Greens (WA), of which there are now two members in the Senate, I, too, congratulate you on your renewed position in the Senate. As Senator Harradine said, `I would rather vote for Senator Sibraa than for myself', but I feel I should say that the only regret I have is that I would like to see a woman occupying that place. With that aside, I have valued the experience and the dignity with which you have conducted your role in the Senate in the short time I have been here, and I wish to add my congratulations to those of other senators.

—I am grateful to all the honourable senators who have spoken this afternoon—Senators Gareth Evans, Hill, Kernot, Boswell, Harradine and Chamarette. I thank them all for their remarks and best wishes. I think I have already discovered that it is not always easy to preside over a Senate in which no one party holds a majority, and I am under no illusions that this Senate will be any different. However, I will continue to try to treat all parties with fairness and without prejudice. It is up to all of us to work together in a constructive way that will reflect credit on the Senate and also on our parliamentary system of government.

PARA.TAB: I welcome all the new senators who have taken their places today. I trust that their time here in this chamber is productive and enjoyable. I have made clear on previous occasions that, as President, my door is always open. I welcome the opportunity to discuss matters of concern with all senators, even on the issue of how many questions you have had during the session. If any of the new senators want to know about this, they should talk to Senator Panizza who has developed it into an art form. In conclusion, I thank you for placing your trust in me. I will continue to tackle the task in a way that I trust all honourable senators will approve of.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Governor-General will be pleased to receive the President and such honourable senators as desire to accompany him in the Members Hall forthwith.

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to report that, accompanied by honourable senators, this afternoon I presented myself to His Excellency the Governor-General as the choice of the Senate as President and His Excellency was pleased to congratulate me upon my election.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES: ELECTION

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the time has come now when it is necessary for the Senate to choose one of its members to be Deputy President.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Senate for its Deputy President and Chairman of Committees Senator Crichton-Browne, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senator Crichton-Browne be appointed Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, I declare Senator Crichton-Browne elected as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees, in accordance with the standing orders.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on behalf of government senators, let me be the first to congratulate you on your elevation to high office. Since you arrived in this Senate in 1980, I have always thought of you as one of the more statesmanlike and above the fray sorts of people in this place. I know that is something of a minority view, but I am sure it will be confirmed by your performance in this high office. I guess it had better be confirmed because there are, conceivably, one or two hot breaths breathing down the neck if it is not. But, Senator Crichton-Browne, I do want to say on behalf of government members that we look forward to your exercising your responsibilities not only with the efficiency and dispatch for which you are well known but with some wisdom, judgment and even-handed good humour as well. I repeat my best wishes on behalf of the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators, I would like to congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne on achieving this high office. Senator Crichton-Browne comes well qualified for this position. As you know, Mr President, not only has he served as one of your acting deputy presidents and temporary chairmen of committees but he has also given long and distinguished service on both Senate and joint committees of this parliament; and, from the position of opposition, he has been the deputy chairman on several of those committees. He showed particular interest in this House, serving on House committees.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, as you know, he has demonstrated skills in matters of procedure and he also has a passion to see not only that this chamber operates with the respect that it deserves but also that the parliament functions effectively. You have seen him work in that regard through joint house committees and other such formal and informal bodies. With that strong background, I am pleased that the Senate has elected Senator Crichton-Browne to this office today. We on this side of the chamber wish him well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I offer congratulations to Senator Crichton-Browne on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I have to tell him that we have scanned the database in vain—no 100 pages of Hansard this time—to give us a reason for rejecting convention. It is our hope that he will display the impartiality, tempered with a sense of humour, that is so necessary in the job and which I think Senator Colston displayed so ably. I want to tell Senator Crichton-Browne that, in fact, our vote of support for him is just a way of keeping him from the `I didn't really mean to speak, but . . .' list, which happens so regularly in the evenings in this place. Perhaps the Senate will gain from this. We wish Senator Crichton-Browne well and we will be watching him with interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne on his election to the position of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. He has always been a personal friend of mine. I know that he got a little knock-back last time, but he was big enough to come again and prove that he could win the position. It is a very responsible position; it is overviewing the Senate committees and also being jointly responsible for the running of this chamber. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne will do that job well and responsibly. I would also like to take this opportunity of extending the National Party's thanks to the previous Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston. He did a very good job for which we thank him also. In conclusion, I know that the National Party senators wish Senator Crichton-Browne all the best.

—I, too, would like to congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne on his election to the position of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. Senator Crichton-Browne is a very—I would not say `passionate' because I do not use that word very often—strong supporter of this institution, the Senate. I believe that his election as Deputy President of the Senate will augur well for the future of this chamber in somewhat difficult times. The President, of course, is also a strong supporter of this institution and, with both of those honourable senators there at the helm, I think this will be very much appreciated by the people of Australia who regard this chamber as a necessary chamber of review and Senator Crichton-Browne's work as Chairman of Committees will be very vital to the exercise of that function by members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: I, too, would like to say that I have supported Senator Colston previously in situations such as this. Senator Colston's work in this chamber—he came here at the same time as I did, in 1975—has been exceptional. He has been able to manage this chamber in circumstances in which another person may well have foundered. He has allowed discussion and debate to take place. One has always known when it was time to cut because Senator Colston used to just prop, and that was it, one could not possibly get past it. It was very instructive. I only saw him do it once to me and I did not press it any further on any other occasion.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank Senator Colston for what he has done in his role as Chairman of Committees and as an honourable senator in this place since 1975. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne will carry on that tradition of enabling members of parliament to have their say but ensuring that the work of the parliament proceeds without undue delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join the honourable senators who have spoken in congratulating Senator Crichton-Browne on his election as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I have known and worked on a number of committees with Senator Crichton-Browne over quite a few years now. We did not always agree, but I am confident that we will have a close and productive working relationship that should be of benefit to the efficient running of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to the former Deputy President, Senator Colston. He played a very supportive role in the last Senate. He was a very loyal deputy who worked quite tirelessly in ensuring that the operations of the chamber ran as smoothly as possible.

I do want to mention, in particular, the time towards the end of the last session when we had some of the longest and latest sittings on record. I greatly appreciated the efforts of Senator Colston, particularly with regard to organising the adjournment debate which was regularly called on in the early hours of the morning. I thank him for those efforts and I wish him well in the future. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne will continue in the same tradition and, once again, I congratulate him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to add a couple of sentences to what I said earlier.
—Do you want to withdraw?

—No, I am not going to withdraw any of what I said. Senator Colston is not an easy person to overlook but I have to confess that I have been reminded by subsequent speeches—I think Senator Hill is in the same boat—that I overlooked his contribution. I do want to say very firmly and very clearly for the record that it was an absolutely outstanding one as Deputy President, that he performed the duties in that office with great capacity and great efficiency, often in extremely difficult circumstances, and that a debt of gratitude is owed to him.

PARA.TAB: It was not any want of confidence on the part of your Senate colleagues on your own side that led to the situation evolving as it did today. It was simply a matter, old son, that the numbers were not there. I think that is appreciated in the nature of things, but it ought to go on the record that your contribution was a very substantial one. I am indebted to the Senate for the opportunity to say that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Lest it be misunderstood, it was just that we were so excited about the election of Senator Crichton-Browne.
—Your first win in 10 years.

—I had not forgotten what happened three years ago. We in the Liberal Party would like to put on the record our thanks to Senator Colston for the role that he fulfilled as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I can remember that we had the occasional late night tussle, but that is all history. We always accepted that Senator Colston sought to perform his task to the highest standards of integrity. We always held him in high respect, even during debates in this place such as that terrible debate over lies, and we would like him to know that on this occasion. We thank him for his efforts over the last three years, which were very much in the interest of the Senate.

—Mr President, might I presume from the outset to congratulate you on your election. You have, if I might say so publicly, discharged your duties and responsibilities with fairness and with a sense of understanding, in some cases under very difficult and trying circumstances, such is the robust nature of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I thank the Senate for the support and the confidence which it has given unto me. I should say that there is something compellingly exquisite about an election in which we are not required to have a ballot, and I am sure you will agree with that, Mr President. I appreciate the support of the Australian Democrats on this occasion and I promise that I will be brief in the remarks that I make. There is a sense of ambivalence about my view that they do not have an opportunity on this occasion at least to cast a vote for me but I take the fact that they support me as a compliment.

I acknowledge the contribution that Senator Colston made during his period as Deputy President. Honourable senators will remember that following the last election of the Deputy President—this is not the first occasion on which I have stood before honourable senators—I congratulated Senator Colston with all the courage and conviction that I could muster. Senator Colston did discharge his responsibilities with sensitivity and fairness. As one of his acting temporary chairmen of committees, I always found him to be understanding and wise in his counsel.

I take this opportunity to thank my own Liberal Senate colleagues for their support on this occasion. They gave me the same support in 1990. At that time they made a very courageous decision, knowing that their nominee would ultimately probably not succeed. I do pledge to the Senate to discharge my responsibilities as the Deputy President with fairness, impartiality and with a sense, I hope, of proper sensitivity.

I understand that not only are Senator Colston and I swapping positions; we are also swapping offices. It may be a modest consolation, but he is now acquiring the best view in the parliament. I again thank you all for your support. I shall always be grateful for the wise counsel that I am provided with from time to time by way of interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners: Shares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
The legislation passed in December 1992 to count the increases in the value of shares held by pensioners as income, even if the shares are never sold to realise the gain:
(1) Is unjust.
(2) Has its most detrimental effect on pensioners with small holdings.
(3) Only affects Australian Stock Exchange listed shares.
(4) Discourages small scale investment in Australian companies.
Your Petitioners request that the amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (no 3) 1992 relating to unrealised capital gains on shares should be repealed.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: HIB Vaccine Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
We wish to draw your attention to the urgent need for funding for the recently released HIB vaccine. HIB disease causes suffering, death and permanent disability in babies and young children.

The HIB vaccine is recommended by the NH&MRC for all babies and children from the ages of 2 months to 5 years. It is to be added to the routine immunization schedule and is the 1st significant addition since measles in 1968. All other routine vaccinations are free.

The HIB vaccine is presently only available to those who can afford to pay for it on a user pays basis. This will effectively result in many babies and children remaining at risk of contracting the HIB disease. This is a social justice issue.
We believe it is inappropriate to add this vaccine to the recommended schedule when it is unfunded or only partially funded.
We are asking that this vaccine be made accessible to all babies and children from 2 months to 5 years of age. Please fully fund this new HIB vaccine for all Australian children.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath or Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's oldest successful democracies and has led the world in many democratic reforms.
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Religion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The U.N. declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on Religion and Beli.
(a)Denies the Freedom of Religion guaranteed in the Australian Constitution
(b)Is designed to impede or oppose the Biblical life and ministry of the Christian Church
(c)Is being introduced as law to bring changes to our nation that were rejected by the people in the last Referendum on the Constitution.
We therefore ask the Senate to take all steps to have this Declaration disallowed from the HREOC Act 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(1)Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
(2)Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
(3)Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
1. We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our concern that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating is considering a change in our national flag.
2. Our flag is unique in that it is the most potent symbol of the nation. This flag is accepted with pride as the unifying symbol of our nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray that the flag will not be changed without the people of Australia being able to express their choice through a referendum.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ARCHER; BAUME; FERGUSON; HERRON; HILL; KNOWLES; SHORT
PETITION.NAMEIDS: IE4; LE4; EP5; VW4; BH4; TH4; DJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 91 citizens), Senator Michael Baume (from 174 citizens), Senator Ferguson (from 611 citizens), Senator Herron (from 369 citizens), Senator Hill (from 3,202 citizens), Senator Knowles (from 432 citizens) and Senator Short (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 39 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: New Enterprise Incentive Scheme
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker of the senate assembled in parliament. The petition of certain residents of Western Australia draws to the attention of the senate.
The fact that the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme is one of the more successful government labour market programs.
That having been participants of the New Enterprise Scheme, many former unemployed persons are now running their own successful small businesses, employing other people and paying significant taxes.

That places in the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme are now drastically under budgeted and, as of 6th August, over 360 new small businesses in Western Australian are waiting to be approved, with few if any places available.

Your petitioners respectfully ask the senate to drastically increase the number of places in the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme and calls on the government to provide demand based funding for the program.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: That the Senate consider proposing amendments to the Child Care Act with regard to the current policy on Attendance Records

PARA.TAB: because:

PETITION.PARA: The Attendance Records are impractical for Family Day Care services.
Family Day Carers homes are not set up with separate office facilities, as Child Care Centres are.
Children who are transported to and from school may require the parent or responsible person to sign four times each day for each child.
Carers are responsible for making sure parents sign their children in and out each day.
The issue of accountability is not addressed by the Attendance Records.

PARA.TAB: We wish the Minister to look at proposed amendments. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate consider these amendments.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child:
a. Has the potential to deny parents their rightful authority over their children, even empowering the Government to represent children against their parents (Article 12)
b. Removes parents freedom to protect their children from exposure to material which the parents believe to be objectionable or harmful on religious, moral or other grounds (Art. 13)
c. Denies parental rights to discourage their children from harmful groups or beliefs (Art. 14)
d. Denies parents power to stop their children being with persons they believe harmful (Art. 15)
e. May prevent parents "interfering" in any area of life a child claims to be private (Art. 16)
We believe this Convention could be used to deny the freedom of parents to nurture and educate their children in accordance with their own beliefs, and could destroy family relationships.
We believe its use as law would be an abuse of the external affairs power of the Constitution.
We ask that the Senate act disallow this Convention from the HREOC Act.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plight of Refugee Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate, the petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Parliament, the plight of refugee women in countries disrupted by war and political unrest.

PARA.TAB: The complete destruction and absence of any sustainable infrastructure in their country of origin leaves thousands of refugee women and children no possibility of a durable solution to their plight or any hope of repatriation to their homeland.

We are aware of and applaud the humanitarian response of the Australian Government in implementing the "Women at Risk" programme. However, this programme admits only 200 refugee women annually (approximately) and does not adequately reflect the magnitude of the international plight of refugee women.

Accordingly, your petitioners request that the Minister of Immigration increases the humanitarian acceptance of refugee women, especially those who have family ties or who have ethnic communities willing to undertake the responsibility of assisting them to re-establish their lives in Australia.

As a Executive Member of the Office of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva, the Australian Government has played an important role in assisting the global refugee problem. We earnestly petition that our refugee and humanitarian programme be expanded and the intake increased of refugee women who already have family or community links in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes and pays tribute to the young organ donor, Nicholas Stone, for his unselfish decision, prior to his death at the age of 9, to donate his organs;

(b)acknowledges the unselfish and courageous behaviour of all organ donors and their families whose generosity of spirit makes possible life and sight saving transplant operations for others in the community;
(c)calls on the Government to examine the possibility of financial support for counselling services for families of donors; and

(d)records its appreciation for the foresight and compassion of all those who, like Nicholas Stone, take steps before their death to declare their willingness to donate their organs to those whose lives might be changed or saved by them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the following matter be referred to the Procedure Committee:

TAB.TAB: (a)ways in which the days and hours of sitting of the Senate and the order of business can be arranged such that more time is available for legislation and other business and late night sittings are avoided;

PARA.TAB: (2)That the Committee:
