(b)consult with the Procedure Committee of the House of Representatives; and
(c)report by 30 September 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, before I give notice I should indicate that I am aware of the standing order requiring as much brevity as possible in notices of motion. I have given consideration to that, and the preamble for this is necessary. I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)recognises:
(i)that everyone is entitled to fundamental rights and freedoms without distinction such as based on race, sex, religion or nationality, and
(ii)that the child by reason of physical and mental immaturity needs special safeguards and care;
(b)notes that:
(i)on 20 November 1989 the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child (Resolution 44/25),

(ii)on 7 November 1990 the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) advised the Senate that it would be surprising if, when Australia ratified the Convention, a reservation was not made acknowledging the pre-eminent role of the family so that in effect the Articles of the Convention would be interpreted in a way that safeguarded the primary and inalienable rights of parents,
(iii)when, on 17 December 1990, the Government ratified the Convention, it made no such reservation,

(iv)on 22 December 1992 the Attorney-General declared under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 that the Convention is an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purposes of that Act, and
(v)in the circumstances, there has been widespread concern in the community about the potential effect of the Convention on the family in Australia; and
(c)disallows the Declaration by the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that the Clinton administration is reported to have delayed signing the North American Free Trade Agreement and has expressed concern about the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on the basis that both could be used and, in the case of the GATT have been used, to depress both the United States and international standards on food labelling, product and work safety, health and environmental protection;

(b)calls on the Government to safeguard Australian standards by not agreeing to the Uruguay Round Proposals unless and until the GATT standards are lifted to at least the levels currently maintained in Australia;

(c)publish detailed comparisons between the existing and proposed international standards under the GATT, the corresponding Australian standards as well as the targets set by international conventions and agreements such as the Montreal Protocol; and
(d)encourage public debate in Australia on the best way to use international trade agreements to safeguard Australian standards and improve international standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table of the Senate, within 5 sitting days after the passage of this resolution, a statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), and any relevant documentary evidence, setting out the full facts relating to the knowledge and involvement of ministers, particularly Senators Collins, Cook and Richardson, and their staff, with respect to the proposed scheme whereby the Labor Party was to sell access to ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for presentation of the interim report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the unrealised capital gains on pensioners' shares be extended to 1 September 1993.
I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice I have just given.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee seeks an extension of time to report to enable further evidence to be taken in Canberra on 20 August.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that:

(i)the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs has received 160 submissions and about 2000 letters in relation to its inquiry into the Government's plan to treat unrealised gains on shares as income for social security and veterans' affairs purposes,
(ii)virtually every one of these submissions and letters from pensioners, veterans and financial institutions expresses grave concerns about the Government's proposal,
(iii)in the week beginning 8 August 1993, the editorials of at least four major newspapers have called on the Government to drop or amend its shares proposal, and

(iv)members of Labor's caucus are reported to have strongly criticised the shares proposal on 16 August 1993 calling on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) to explain the inevitable political fallout from this harsh and inequitable measure; and

(b)calls on the Government to abandon this measure which the Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange has described as `flawed in principle, flawed in application and discriminatory against investments in listed shares'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table of the Senate, on or before 6.30 p.m. on 19 August 1993, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) a statement of the Government's forward estimates projections of revenue for each of the fiscal years 1994-95 to 1996-97, including the assumptions upon which they are based, to assist Senators in their consideration of the Budget appropriation bills and related Budget proposals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)recognises that the present Keating Government confused the Australian public with a misleading campaign both before and since the Federal election on 13 March 1993;
(b)notes:

(i)that since March 1993, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his Ministers have broken pre-election commitments on taxation, pensioner incomes and benefits, child-care and even such fundamental services as vaccinations for babies, and

(ii)they have reneged on the provision of hospital beds to reduce surgery queues, home child-care allowances, a free dental program and have deferred or totally abandoned promises across the entire ministry; and
(c)calls on the Senate to expose the hypocritical claims of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill, I will read that notice of motion to see whether it is in order.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes the infamous Keating Budget record as follows:
(i)after 18 months of Labor being in power, when the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) delivered his second Budget in 1984, he said `the Government's policies are on track',
(ii)in 1985 he said the Budget `builds upon our very significant successes and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government',
(iii)in 1986 he said the Budget `rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy',
(iv)in 1987 when delivering the Budget Speech he said `our economic strategy is now bearing fruit',
(v)in 1988 he said `the nation is successfully emerging from the most severe economic crisis in a generation . . . this is the one that brings home the bacon',
(vi)in 1989 he said `Australia will emerge . . . without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving', and
(vii)in 1990 he said that the economy will improve `without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession';
(b)further notes that every one of the then Treasurer's statements have been proven to be false; and
(c)condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for the litany of broken promises and deceptions which will only result in further misery and despair for the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council be extended to 16 November 1993.
I seek leave to make a short statement in support of that notice of motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee has received a large amount of evidence and seeks this extension to enable it to complete its report in a very comprehensive manner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies for inquiry and report on or before 29 September 1993:

The 0055 service offered by Telecom called `Reverse Phone Directory', which enabled subscribers to match private telephone numbers with specific residential addresses and the development of a proper and enforceable code of conduct to protect the privacy of Telecom customers from developments of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)congratulates the Western Australian Minister for Education (The Hon. N F Moore, MLC) for giving students in Western Australia the freedom to choose whether or not to be a member of a student union, a freedom yet to be legislated for by any other state government in Australian history; and

(b)condemns the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) for threatening Western Australia's funding as a consequence of the State Government giving students freedom of association.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)condemns any moves by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS);
(b)recognises that graduate starting salaries are at a 16 year low yet the Government is considering a drop in the threshold at which students begin to repay their HECS debt;

(c)notes with grave concern that these changes to the HECS would hit hardest at traditionally disadvantaged groups, specifically women who are five times less likely to repay their HECS debt before the age of 30 than men;
(d)denounces any proposed cuts to benefits for secondary school Austudy recipients, the majority of whom (84 315) have adjusted family incomes of less than $10 000 per annum; and
(e)calls for a moratorium on changes to the HECS and student loans and urgently convenes a formal inquiry into the impact of HECS on higher education before any changes are implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes:
(i)that the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway will give a vital boost to Australia's and, in particular, South Australia's exports to Asia, and
(ii)the promise of the Keating Labor Government during the 1993 Federal election campaign to fund the completion of the survey work for this project; and

(b)calls on the Government to allocate in the 1993-94 Budget the $3 million required to survey in 1993 the remaining 300 kilometres of the l400 kilometre route to enable accurate figures to be finalised for the cost of building the rail link.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)condemns the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) for his attempts to dismantle the Marine Laboratories of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and its Divisions of Oceanography and Fisheries;

(b)recognises that Senator Schacht's ill-fated proposal which was against the advice of his own Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development has seriously damaged Australia's international scientific reputation;

(c)acknowledges that Senator Schacht's actions placed at risk the jobs of some 250 Tasmanian staff associated with the CSIRO Marine Laboratories and the $30 million which those organisations bring into the Tasmanian economy;

(d)further recognises that Senator Schacht's proposal received nothing but condemnation from industry bodies, the scientific community, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and eventually his own Cabinet;

(e)sincerely rebukes Tasmania's nine Federal Labor Members and Senators who, apart from Senator Coates, were prepared to sit idly by whilst Senator Schacht dismantled one of Tasmania's most prestigious scientific institutes;

(f)requests the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to immediately replace the gullible Senator Schacht in his portfolio because of the irreparable damage which his actions have done in creating confrontation between the Government and Australia's scientific community; and

(g)calls on the Government to give an unequivocal assurance that the CSIRO's Division of Marine Laboratories located in Hobart will not be amalgamated and will never again be subjected to the type of ill-conceived and illogical attack waged by Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)calls on the Government to put down an explanatory paper outlining its policy aims and intentions on savings, investments and pensioner incomes;
(b)notes the absolute confusion and havoc being brought on old people by the lack of any policy or intention by the Government;
(c)requests the Government to commit the issue to a committee competent in matters of savings and investments for advice; and

(d)notes that from the Register of Members Interests that neither the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) or the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) as the minister primarily involved in the issue have any shares in public companies and clearly have no understanding of the part played by the public company structure in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes following the swearing-in of new Senators the stunning success of the Liberal and National parties in the Senate election held on 13 March 1993 and the continuing decline in support for both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats; and

(b)calls on both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to reverse their support for proposals which would effectively diminish the role of the Senate as a states house and house of review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes with dismay the attempted sabotage of Sydney's bid for the 2000 Olympic Games by the foreign-controlled Sydney Morning Herald's incredible `beat-up' into a major front page news item of unsustainable suggestions of impropriety against a New South Wales Minister (Mr Baird) over the appointment of an International Olympic Committee delegate's son-in-law to a junior engineering job in the State Rail Authority; and
(b)calls on the Sydney Morning Herald to follow the lead of other media outlets in providing at least a fair and balanced cover of Sydney's bid rather than setting out to undermine it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes:
(i)the action by the Australian Government in opposing the Clinton administration's attempt to impose an energy tax,
(ii)that the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) were invoked in the Keating Government's case against this proposed energy tax, and
(iii)that the GATT gives overriding importance to trade and overrules considerations of environmental protection, occupational health, social justice or equity;
(b)dissociates itself from the Government's action with respect to the proposed Clinton energy tax; and
(c)calls on the Government to work actively to restructure the GATT so as to give priority to those measures which will move the world toward ecological sustainability and social justice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that:
(i)a Prices Surveillance Authority draft report has recommended the doubling of peak period landing charges for commuter and regional airlines operating out of Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport,
(ii)in addition to this alarming suggestion they have further proposed an extension of the peak period monitoring period, and

(iii)introduction of either of these suggestions would lead to further financial crisis for our struggling commuter airlines and would be yet another impost on people living outside metropolitan Australia; and
(b)calls on the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) to reject the final report if it contains these or any similar recommendations that will disadvantage rural Australians.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate condemns the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) for—

TAB.TAB: (a)his handling of the proposal to break up the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and separate from it the Divisions of Oceanography, Fisheries and Atmospheric Research;
(b)his failure to consult with the scientists, administrators and staff of the CSIRO and to consider the range of options available for intensifying the national commitment to marine science; and
(c)breaking the Australia Labor Party's election commitment to provide certainty and stability in science policy and to maintain the structure of the CSIRO.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes:
(i)that 17 August 1993 marks a decade of cheating budgets brought down by the Labor Government, and

(ii)that under Labor's decade, Australia's employment has decayed as unemployment has soared, our family structures have decayed as young people cannot get jobs, our overseas reserves have decayed, our standard of living has decayed, our rural industries have decayed, our international standing has decayed and standards of integrity in Government have decayed; and
(b)hopes that the end of this decade will not be followed by another such period of economic and social decay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes with approval the published intention of the Member for Franklin (Mr Quick, MP) to oppose any increase in the tax on super grade petrol; and

(b)invites other members of the Labor Party to join Mr Quick to actually take steps to prevent this inequitable proposal by voting against it unless revenue raised by the levy is dedicated to supporting the transport options of those people most disadvantaged by increased transport costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that:

(i)84 species of protected Australian animals including the endangered species, the sooty owl, yellow-bellied glider and tiger quoll live within the forest compartments known as 1402 and 1312 in the Nalbaugh State Forest in NSW, and

(ii)the Government of NSW via its National Parks and Wildlife Service issued a logging licence on 29 July 1993 which compromises the viability of these compartments as `jewels in the crown' of wilderness areas in NSW; and
(b)calls on the Government to honour its 1990 election promise to protect `pristine and other forests of high conservation value'.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMISSION TO ADMINISTER OATH OR AFFIRMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform honourable senators that I have received from His Excellency the Governor-General a commission to administer to senators the oath of affirmation or allegiance.

PARA.TAB: Commission laid on the table and read by the Clerk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have searched today's red but I cannot find question time and, as opposition senators certainly wish to ask questions of ministers, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to provide for questions without notice to be called on today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible that members of the House of Representatives today have the opportunity to question ministers, yet in this place the government has failed to provide us with an opportunity for question time. All I can get from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) as to why this is so is that today is a day of ceremony. Today is not just a day of ceremony. We have just had many senators giving notices of motion; petitions have been presented in this place; we are about to have the tabling of documents. This is a day of ceremony but it is also a normal day of business. We should be entitled today, on the first day back here, to ask ministers the question that we wish to ask.

PARA.TAB: This will be a test—the first test of this sitting—for the Australian Democrats and the Greens. If they are here to help keep this government honest, they will want to question and probe this government now at the first opportunity, and they will vote with us to suspend standing orders in order that we may be able to do so. If the Democrats and the Greens say, `No, we are too busy having afternoon tea' or whatever and are uninterested in this matter, unwilling to come in here and take the opportunity to question the government, they will do what we suspect they will do; that is, vote with the government and not take up this opportunity. We give notice by this action today that we intend to take every opportunity to probe and question this incompetent government. Our first opportunity is now, and that is why I have moved this motion. The government may well say, `But we have our minds on the budget and you will simply want to ask budget questions'. That is not correct. There are so many other issues before the Australian people that we want to probe and question. For example, there is the inaction of the federal government in relation to the Mabo decision—the total incompetence of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his unwillingness to draw the state premiers together in a way which would seek a constructive resolution of the very major difficulties that come out of that High Court decision. Why are we not being permitted today to question the government in relation to its handling of the Mabo issue?

Another major issue before the Australian people is the republic debate. Why do we not have the opportunity today to ask the government why it has sought to divide Australia over its efforts in relation to having a republic rather than seeking to bring Australians together to see whether some common ground can be found in relation to the constitutional reform? Notices of motion were given in relation to Senator Schacht's incredible intervention in the workings of the CSIRO.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—I can see Senator Calvert nodding his head. Why cannot Senator Calvert come in here today and question Senator Schacht on the incompetent mishandling of his portfolio during the months that this chamber was not sitting? Why is he not being given that opportunity? It is because Senator Faulkner and Senator Gareth Evans have refused to put question time on the Notice Paper for today.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short wishes to question the government on the confusion within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs over the Chinese students, but he is not being given the opportunity. I am sure that Senator Rod Kemp, for one, wants to question the government on its refusal to allow proper enterprise agreements to be negotiated through non-ACTU organisations, but he is not being given the opportunity.

Why are we not given an opportunity to question the government on the selective black-listing of journalists and industry representatives in relation to the lock-up today? Why can we not ask questions today about the Public Service performance pay debacle that the government is now seeking to extend to the military?

What about the pay TV debacle that Senator Alston wants to pursue? Since we have been away from this place, I understand that Minister Collins has gone to a Senate committee and confessed his guilt. Why do we not have an opportunity on the first day back to question him in relation to that and, as I said, the ongoing debacle in relation to pay TV—this farce in which, one by one, bidders are being called forward but know that they do not have to front up because they have another bid that is in the pipeline? What a mess! What an embarrassment! Why do we not have the opportunity to question the government on that? We demand that right today.

Above all, we should be able to question the government because of the way in which it blatantly misled and lied to the Australian people at the last election—about health care, pensions and tax cuts. Why in those circumstances are we not permitted, given the opportunity that we are entitled to, to come in today and question ministers on those matters? We demand it. We trust that the Australian Democrats and the Greens, having thought about the matter a little further, will recognise that they should not forgo an opportunity in this place, if they are going to be responsible parties, to take matters up with the government. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a limp and flatulent little effort from Senator Hill—full of wind and fulmination but without any substance whatsoever. He should know perfectly well—and he does know because I have told him—that it has been absolutely standard practice in this place, whoever has been in government, for as long as I can remember and certainly for as far back as I have checked, which is to 1976, not to have a question time on the first day back for a new Senate when a Senate is being sworn in and when a new President and Deputy President are being elected.

PARA.TAB: For a party which goes on at such nauseous length about history, tradition, norms, forms, standards, procedures and conventions in this place, it is the height of rank hypocrisy for Senator Hill to come in here and seek to tear up those conventions and practices as they have evolved over many years. They have evolved for very good reason. We have 11 new senators in this place, 10 of whom were newly sworn in today. They are here with their families and they want the opportunity to behave in a way that is appropriate without the kind of exercise that Senator Hill wants us to engage in.

Let me make very clear for the record that this has been the practice. If one looks back at what the practice has been every election year going back to 1976, one will find that there was no question time on the first day back in these situations in 1990, 1987 or 1981—and I will fill in the gap in a moment—and nor was there in 1978 or 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 1983?

—So far as 1983 was concerned, honourable senators may recall that there was a double dissolution. That meant that the new Senate was sworn in earlier than the start-up of the parliament on the budget day in the August session. So normal question time did take place on the budget day return date for the Senate in that particular election year.

PARA.TAB: Equally, there was no question time in 1985 because the election for the new Senate had taken place back in the latter part of 1984 and budget time in 1985 was in fact the first day back for the new Senate. It was dealt with in that way following that particular election. That has been the practice, the history and the tradition for the very good practical reason that I have already described. As I have already said publicly, this is in the dim hope that there will be some improvement in Senate standards in future and that Senator Hill will find more credible grounds for his attempt at procedural disruptions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is no test of the Australian Democrats; the greatest test was voting for Senator Crichton-Browne and we have already done that this afternoon. I think this is a test of the opposition. Is this an indication that opposition senators will seize every opportunity to obstruct and to hijack?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kernot will be heard.

—The point needs to be made that this motion was given very late notice because a draft order of business had been circulated and no objection was raised then. I firmly believe that this matter should have been sorted out with the whips beforehand. None of the issues that Senator Hill raised this afternoon has arisen overnight or in the last week and none of them is incapable of waiting until tomorrow. I agree that the purpose of today's proceedings is largely ceremonial. We have undertaken that ceremony and it is important that we now move on to the condolence motions. The Democrats will not be supporting this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly join the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in his motion to have a question time which I think is important. This Senate and the House of Representatives have sat for one month in eight months of this year. If the Australian Democrats cannot find some questions to throw at the government, they must be very happy with the government's performance. But I can tell the Democrats that 80 per cent of the people out there in Australia are most dissatisfied with the government. They want to know what the government intends to do on so many issues, such as on the unemployment issue. One million people out there are unable to get a job. Hundreds of thousands of kids are bottled up in tertiary education, on pretend jobs, and they want to get a real genuine job. All rural Australia wants to know what the Garnaut committee report is all about and we want to ask Senator Cook questions about it. I want to know why the government is running scared.

PARA.TAB: What is the purpose of this day? It has taken us half an hour to have a cup of tea and a chat, and that is all that is required. We are now back in here to do business. We on this side of the House—obviously I dissociate the Democrats from what I am now saying—want the opportunity to bring into this House some questions that need to be answered. We are being denied that opportunity because the Democrats are now siding with the government because they want to have a ceremonial day.

I want to remind Senator Kernot just what it costs to assemble this House to have a cup of tea. It costs hundreds of thousands of dollars because the Democrats want to have a cup of tea. We do not want a cup of tea. We want to get down to hard political debate. If the Democrats want to have a cup of tea then they should go out there and have one, but let us get on with the debate. Every time this parliament assembles it costs the taxpayers $300,000 or $400,000—a huge amount of money—so that the Democrats can have a cup of tea.

Mr President, I support the motion. I believe that the government is running scared. If this is the way in which those opposite are showing their colours by running the white flag up on the first day, they will be in serious trouble as this Senate progresses down its course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that the opposition that puts itself forward as the upholder of traditions yet again wants to dump another convention. I refer to the convention of not having a question time on budget day after an election. The Leader of the National Party, Senator Boswell, says that we have convened the Senate for a cup of tea. He has obviously by the look of him had a bit more than a cup of tea. The reason we have convened the Senate today is for the budget.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. A personal reflection on a member of this chamber is completely out of order. Senator Faulkner ought to know that. He is starting off on a very poor note and I hope that he can lift his game. He ought to apologise to Senator Boswell for that outrageous slur. I know that Senator Boswell does not drink tea all the time, but he certainly does not deserve what Senator Faulkner has served up.
—Order! I do not regard the remark as unparliamentary, but it might be better if it were withdrawn or restated in another way.

—I will withdraw. Senator Boswell did not have any cakes. As the opposition well knows, we have convened today not to have a cup of tea but to listen to the budget. The reality is that yet again we have an opposition interested only in negative carping. Those opposite are now nothing more than Her Majesty's loyal and perpetual opposition.

PARA.TAB: All these programming matters were circulated to honourable senators, including the opposition, weeks ago. The draft red order of business that Senator Hill is now in high dudgeon about was received by him on 10 August but he is a bit thick and a bit slow to wake up. Apparently he has woken up today to the fact that, in accordance with precedence and convention, there is no question time. Under my signature as Manager of Government Business, we clearly indicated what the Senate program would be for this week, and those opposite all know it. This is just pathetic grandstanding from people who are destroyers not builders—the people who have decided that there is nothing left for them in Australian politics other than to be negative.

It is quite clear that the opposition is not even going to make any pretence of aiming for a workable Senate or a workable chamber. In fact, those opposite are not even interested any more in worrying about what mischief they might put in place in the unlikely event that they ever win government. They are into spiteful, vindictive, self-serving actions to do nothing more than disrupt the government. The opposition is trying to punish the Australian people for re-electing the Labor government. That is all it wants to do. The opposition will never ever come to terms with its comprehensive rejection by the Australian people at the polls. Those opposite were done like dinners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell lies.

—Senator Ian Macdonald does not even know it. Those opposite are so stupid that they put in notices of motion congratulating themselves on how well they have done in the Senate. They ought to face facts. They lost the election. If their philosophy is that somehow they were robbed, they need to come to grips with the situation. Those opposite are a pathetic, miserable, negative, carping lot of no-hopers.

—Mr President, this motion is for the suspension of standing orders. I would have thought that the government would have realised that if it did not agree with the suggestion that we should have a question time, half an hour would be taken up in this chamber debating the suspension of standing orders so that we could have a question time. I do not know when the government was given advice of this, but I suggest that it would have been reasonable for the government to have agreed with that. This afternoon we were not going to resume until 3.30; but we resumed at 3.15. The government would have only lost a quarter of an hour—and what is a quarter of an hour between friends and people who need an idea that this parliament is being run properly? If only a quarter of an hour is involved, I do not see that it is a disruptive measure, but now it has become slightly disruptive because of the intransigence of the government in refusing to accede to the request for a question time.

PARA.TAB: I think a question time is necessary today. Why should it be necessary? Because I believe that we are in crisis in this country today. That crisis was highlighted after we received Senator Faulkner's letter outlining what the procedures were going to be here. That was last Thursday, 12 August, when the unemployment figures came out showing continuous record unemployment levels; a loss in one month of 37,000 full-time jobs; and that every Australian losing a job now, on average, will be unemployed for 58 weeks—and in Tasmania 80 weeks. If that is not a crisis, I do not know what is.

I would have liked the opportunity to ask questions about certain things of the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I believe that many people in this country, many ordinary people in the community, do not believe that we are in a recession; they believe that we are in a painful transition to a situation of continuous drops in the standard of living, with a permanent underclass of unemployed and underemployed. If that is not a crisis for which the government should be asked questions, I do not know what is.

I have raised question after question about the need for the government to look at the paid work force, and to see who is in the paid work force who wants to come out of it and who has better reason to come out of it. Thousands of people in the 50 to 60 age group, where there now are many unemployed, want to retire but cannot because they would be faced with an unacceptable loss in their standard of living. Why force those people to stay in the paid work force when there are so many outside wanting to get in there and take those jobs? Again, there are thousands of mothers with young dependent children who, if they were given true freedom of choice, would want to come out of the paid work force but cannot because one-income families are discriminated against and will be discriminated against in respect of the home child care allowance.

These are the sorts of things that I would have liked to ask the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training about today, and I hope that I still will be able to ask him about them today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Hill. I endorse completely the remarks of Senator Harradine; they do not need to be repeated, nor do the remarks of Senator Hill. Those remarks together should be enough to show the Australian Democrats that there are important matters to discuss. I can tell Senator Kernot that the line, `We can do it tomorrow; manana, manana' simply is not good enough. The crisis is here today. Tomorrow, everyone in this place will want to question the government about tonight's budget. Today is the time to ask the government about things prior to that budget—the lies that it told at the election; the divisive nature of the Mabo debate; and the whole structure of the work force and the crisis that it finds itself in and that people who want a job find themselves in. These are all legitimate matters for an opposition to want to raise—for a parliament to want to raise to check on the executive. Some of those on the back bench opposite also have this job, poorly though they perform it when they are here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans offers the debate that this side of the chamber has—as I think he referred to it—some sort of nauseous support for history and tradition. Let us turn to the other side of that debate. It is people on that side of the chamber, like Senator Gareth Evans, who want to chuck that out all the time. They say, `Let's do what is appropriate now; let's not worry ourselves with the past'. I would have thought that even Senator Gareth Evans could see the crisis that this country is in, and what is appropriate for now is for us to have a question time.

Senator Gareth Evans says that in the past we have not had a question time when we have had new senators sworn in after the election of a government. But never have I seen a government elected on such a pack of lies and misrepresentations, so it is a completely different situation. Senator Gareth Evans's government presented at the last election the worst collection of misrepresentations about our policies and bald faced misrepresentations about what it was going to do. That in itself is enough to justify our changing from what we have done in the past and saying that we want to ask the government some questions about these matters.

I would have thought that a government which announced that it wants a code of conduct for banks and a code of conduct for insurance companies should have a code of conduct for itself, and the first item on that code of conduct should be that it will be available to be questioned and it will tell the truth. We do not let used car salesmen make the misrepresentations that those opposite were a party to. The Trade Practices Commission would shut a business down for behaving in the way that this government behaves. That should be enough to allow us to have some questioning today.
Senator Faulkner's contribution is only worth mentioning for the purpose of saying that he seemed to lurch from insult to insult, as is his wont.

Senator Harradine made the point, quite rightly, that we have spent half an hour on this. The government should have realised—should have conceded—and perhaps the Democrats should have thought of it as well, that debating the need for a question time could, of itself, have been put into a question time. So there is no point in trying to portray the opposition as people who want to waste time when we could have spent this time far more productively challenging the executive for the lies and misrepresentations that this government took to the polls.

Last, but not least, it is of no surprise to me that the government does not want a question time. Senator Crowley, for heaven's sake, would not be ready to answer, or capable of answering, a question, for starters. We found that out in May. Two or three times she had to stand up and say, `I don't know what you're talking about'. Senator Schacht, who was unkindly referred to by one of my colleagues the other day as `Schacht the clot' for the messing up that he has done in CSIRO—I do not make that reference, of course—should be here to answer for that. What about old Collins over there—the bellicose bullyboy of the chamber? He should be here to answer, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You will use proper titles.

—Senator Collins behaves as the bellicose bullyboy in this chamber. Let him come and try to bully the parliament into believing that he has not messed up his portfolio as well. It is no surprise to me that the government does not want a question time. What surprises me is that the Democrats let the government get out of it, saying, `Manana, manana', when `manana' is the budget; today is the time to answer for what has happened in the past.
—Mr President—
—You will agree with us, Barney.

—Well, to a large extent, one could agree with everything that has been said—but the Democrats are absolutely right. In this chamber, we really do have to have regard to convention, propriety and the sorts of orders that our forerunners—people who were here before us—have laid down. This book of standing orders and other orders—which I hope all honourable senators, not only the new ones, will look at from start to finish—shows that the procedure that we have adopted today is the correct procedure. Mr President, we have here the office of President which you have been so properly elected to; and the office of Deputy President which Senator Crichton-Browne has been so properly elected to. They are matters of great importance.

PARA.TAB: I was going to address some remarks to Senator Harradine, but he is not in the chamber at the moment. Of course question time is important but so are other matters. I think the Democrats are absolutely correct when they say that we have to run this chamber properly. Question time is not part of the convention; it is not part of the way we have gone about our business in the past; and there is no reason why we should break that precedent. Senator Vanstone, for whom I have nothing but the highest regard, said that the government told lies during the campaign and therefore this ought to change this sort of—

TALK.START.PARA: —And you agreed with that, didn't you, Barney?

—Certainly not. The people of Australia have spoken. I have humbly accepted what they have done. They have elected me to sit on this side of the chamber—I was going to refer to our ministers in this chamber but they do not seem to be in their seats at the moment. As was the case in the debate we had on motions, I think everyone has made some very good points in this debate on question time.
—Is this a plea of guilty?

—No, it is not a plea of guilty. It is a tribute to the way in which honourable senators have used the procedures of this Senate to get their points across. I will be listening from tomorrow until Christmas to the very many penetrating questions that will come from the other side. I suggest that today we sit back and go through the condolences.
—And have a cup of tea?
—Hold on. Is it not important to have condolences? Is it not important to elect a President? Is it not important to elect a Deputy President?
—What about the budget?

—Somebody said, `What about the budget?' That is very important. I think what we ought to be doing now is preparing for the budget, getting our speeches ready. Senator Kernot is absolutely correct in her approach to this. She has nothing to be ashamed of.
—She is on your side.

—Of course she is on our side, because our side is correct. We are not always correct, but we are correct on this. The contributions that have been made so far indicate that we will have a very interesting time between now and Christmas. No doubt when Christmas comes we will all wish each other the very best. During that time we will not say anything nasty to each other—if we do, we will no doubt regret that having happened.

PARA.TAB: I think we should get about our business and put the motion. I am glad to see that the Democrats, moved by high principle, will support us. I promise to be here at 2 o'clock tomorrow. I hope that Senator Hill will ask the first question and I am sure it will be a penetrating one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired. Before I put the question, I wish to refer to some—not all—of the interjections that were made during the debate. It has always been regarded in the Senate as disorderly to make any remarks suggesting that a senator has been deliberately untruthful.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
(Senator Watson did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Tate.)
Motion (by Senator Faulkner)—by leave—agreed to:
That the hours of meeting of the Senate for today be 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. to 10.30 p.m.
Motion (by Senator Vanstone)—by leave—agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Vanstone and relating to human rights, be postponed till Wednesday, 6 October 1993.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Senate for 1992-93. I also present a document relating to the business of the Senate, the President's report on annual reports, a questions on notice summary and correspondence relating to advice by the Clerk.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Committee Reports and Other Documents Presented to the President whilst the Senate was not Sitting

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief comment about the committee reports and other documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a lecture on form and practice and so forth, and we have the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), on the first day back here, doing his dictation. Mr Presi

INTERJECT.PARA: dent, could you inform the Leader of the Government in this place that that is not the way to conduct business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. It is not competent for Senator Hill to rise to his feet and sling insults across the chamber. He is entitled to take a point of order about a matter if he wants to, but he did not do so.

—Mr President, I submit that there is no point of order whatsoever here. My time has been conspicuously wasted for the last half-hour by Senator Hill and his motion, and I am determined not to waste any more of it. There is no inhibition on conversation in this place, on people talking to other people. It may be regarded as an exercise in my talking quietly to myself while I get on with the business of getting some stuff done. I suggest there is no basis whatsoever for Senator Hill's extraordinary contribution.
—I do not think it is something that has occurred before and perhaps it would be better if it were not done. Senator Hill should really have taken a point of order instead of just starting to speak.

—I welcome the letter tabled by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The letter acknowledges that the department has been misinterpreting the requirements relating to the tabling of documents, in particular dates of submission to and receipt by the minister. As the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I know that this matter was raised in our last report on annual reports. I welcome the department's response and the indication that the correct information will be provided to the Senate in the future.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Hon. Sir Condor Louis Laucke, KCMG

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 30 July 1993, of former President of the Senate the Hon. Sir Condor Louis Laucke, KCMG, senator for the state of South Australia from 1967 to 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Friday 30 July 1993, of the Honourable Sir Condor Louis Laucke, KCMG, member of the House of Assembly of South Australia from 1956 to 1965, Senator for the State of South Australia from 1967/to 1981, President of the Senate from 1976 to 1981 and Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia from 1982 to 1992, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Condor Laucke was born in 1914 at Greenock, South Australia and was educated at Immanuel College and the School of Mines. Prior to entering state politics he worked in the family flour and feed milling business at Greenock.

PARA.TAB: He was interested in politics from a young age, becoming secretary of the Greenock branch of the Liberal and Country League in 1933. He entered the South Australia House of Assembly as the member for Barossa in 1956 and served there for nine years. From 1962 to 1965 he held the position of government whip.

In 1967 Sir Condor entered federal parliament as senator for South Australia. His time in the Senate was characterised by his good humour and unfailing courtesy toward his colleagues on both sides of the chamber. It was these qualities that led to his election as President of the Senate in 1976 and he filled this position with distinction until his retirement in 1981. He was universally well regarded and praised for his honesty, his sense of fair play and his personal charm.

Sir Condor Laucke was President of the Senate during my first three years in this place, and I personally remember him very well and very affectionately. He insisted, of course, as those on the other side still would if they had the chance, on wearing his full regalia of lace jabot, cuffs and ruffles and full bottomed wig, which made him look, as can be seen from his portrait in the Members' Hall, rather like a rakish, elderly gentleman in a Restoration comedy. He obviously thought I was a bit of a wild young man, particularly in my attitudes to the Senate, but he seemed to nurture the hope that I would grow more moderately and gracefully disposed towards the institution as I grew older in it. I am sorry to have disappointed him.

He was temporary Chairman of Committees from 1969 to 1972 and served on several committees including the Joint Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House of which he was joint Chairman and on which I worked closely with him. He also represented Australia at several parliamentary conferences overseas. In 1979 Sir Condor received his knighthood in recognition of his distinguished parliamentary service.

He retired from federal politics in 1981 and in 1982 was appointed Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia and held this post until last year. Sir Condor Laucke worked unstintingly for the people of his home state of South Australia in his 26 years in public office. He will be sadly missed. On behalf of the government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Rose, and the family in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in expressing our sincere regret at the death on 30 July of Sir Condor Laucke at the age of 78.His was a lifetime of service to the people of South Australia, particularly those of the Barossa Valley.

PARA.TAB: As was said, he was born in 1914 in Greenock in the Barossa Valley into a flour milling family. He eventually became the director and general manager of his family's business.

He was vitally interested in politics from his school days. He began his political career in 1933 at the age of 19 as the secretary of the Greenock branch of the newly formed Liberal and Country League. He was elected to the South Australian state parliament in 1956 and represented the interests of the people of the Barossa Valley for nine years until 1965. He showed particular dedication to the region's German heritage.

Sir Condor made an outstanding contribution to the federal parliament during his time as a Liberal senator for South Australia from 1967 to 1981. He served with distinction on many committees, including as Chairman for two years of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Environment, as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Air Pollution, and as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources. His contribution, Mr President, as you know, included holding the important office of President of the Senate from 1976 to 1981. I was honoured to succeed him into the Senate upon his retirement.

His interest in and support for the Barossa did not wane during his time in federal politics. In 1975, he was one of the founders of the Barons of the Barossa, the fraternity of winemakers dedicated to promoting the Barossa Valley. After his retirement from the Senate, he became Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia, a position in which he served with distinction for 10 years from 1982 to 1992.

Sir Donald Dunstan, who was Governor during that time, spoke movingly at Sir Condor's funeral of his association with Sir Condor which developed into a close friendship continuing in their retirement. Sir Condor's many years of public service were recognised with the award of Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George in 1979.

An essentially humble man, Sir Condor will be remembered for the high standard of personal integrity he showed during his long contribution to South Australia, state and federal parliaments and to the Liberal Party. He was liked, admired and respected in business and political circles in South Australia for many decades and he will be sadly missed. On behalf of Liberal and National Party senators, I extend our deepest sympathy to his widow, Lady Laucke, and to their family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government. Sir Condor Laucke had a long and distinguished career in South Australia state and federal politics. With his election as the secretary of the Greenock branch of the Liberal and Country League at the young age of 19, Sir Condor embarked on what was to become a lifetime involvement in politics. His background in business and primary production made him a great asset to the South Australian Liberal Party and he served his state electorate of the Barossa well from 1956 to 1965.

PARA.TAB: Sir Condor made a successful transition from state to federal politics when he entered the Senate in 1967 as a Liberal senator for South Australia. His nine years of hard work and his intrinsic integrity and decency were formally recognised by his parliamentary peers when he was elected President of the Senate in 1976. Sir Condor served five fruitful years in the office of President. One of his greatest achievements was his success in restoring peace and order to a place where turmoil had previously raged. Describing himself as a progressive conservative, Sir Condor was an ardent advocate for the pre-eminence of the Westminster system and parliamentary convention.

In 1981, after 48 years' commitment to politics, Sir Condor resigned his Senate position. However, he found himself unable to settle down to his family flour business, sheep farming and rose growing pursuits that would more than adequately occupy most retirees. Unable to curtail his extraordinary drive and energy, these retirement activities were promptly abandoned when he was summoned back into public life to take up the position of lieutenant-governor for South Australia.

For a further 10 years Sir Condor worked tirelessly to further the interests of his home state and the people of South Australia. Sir Condor served the people of South Australia for the majority of his life. As a state member, a senator in the Australian parliament, President of the Senate and finally Lieutenant-Governor for South Australia, his integrity and dedication has been admired by many but has been emulated by very few. I am sure that all honourable senators will join me in extending our sympathy to his widow and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join the Australian Democrats with this motion of condolence and speak briefly about Sir Condor Laucke, an ex-senator from South Australia. I never knew Sir Condor Laucke; he was only a name to me. Reading through some of the material which I obtained from the Department of the Parliamentary Library, it is clear that Sir Condor showed several very endearing features in his character. He was quite clearly a gentleman in every sense of the word. He was spoken of repeatedly, both in the pages of Hansard and in numerous newspaper cuttings, as somebody who was always fair, generous and a thoroughly decent sort of man.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that comes through very clearly is that he was clearly a practical person. I was amused and delighted when I read an article which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser in 1967 under the heading `The Miller of Greenock' and which said:
Young Laucke learnt more from his father than how to run a flour mill. He learnt something about the handling of men.
"We hope that our men have always worked with us and not for us," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: That said something to me about Sir Condor Laucke. It continued:
Mr Laucke is married, with two children.

PARA.TAB: He is now managing director of the family flour milling business, which also has mills at Strathalbyn, Angaston, Stockwell and Eudunda.
He'll still take a load of feed to poultry farmers himself when the pressure is on at the mill.
Enterprising poultry owners ring him for advice. He keeps more than 300 fowls himself to see how they progress on the feed made by his mills.

SPEECH.PARA: I was impressed reading that, again not knowing the man, for here was a very practical man who knew quite a lot in detail about flour milling and the mixing of poultry feed and who mucked in with his workers to deliver material from his business to those with whom he supplied material.

PARA.TAB: The other little piece from the Adelaide Advertiser of December 1978, which I think shed a very interesting light on another aspect of Sir Condor's character, was the occasion on which he was notified that a knighthood would be bestowed upon him. Evidently, according to this account, headed `A tear, some wine, then off yabbying', he went down into the cellar of his house, broke out a bottle of `78 Bundawunda—the name of his home—Rhine riesling, drank that and went off with his two grandchildren to catch yabbies in the local dam. Again, I was very moved that here was clearly a man who took both triumph and disaster, as Rudyard Kipling said, and treated them both the same.

The other pieces from the library which I think shed a very interesting light on the personality and integrity of Sir Condor were the speeches which were made at the time of his accession to the presidency of the Senate. On that occasion—honourable senators should remember that this was a liberal government—Senator Withers, who moved the motion, said of then Senator Laucke:

SPEECH.PARA: You have a long and distinguished record of committee service including the chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Environment from 1971 to 1973 and membership of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the famous Senate Select Committee on Offshore Petroleum Resources. In addition, you were the deputy chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Air Pollution from 1968 to 1969.

PARA.TAB: As well as your dedicated Committee service, you have been a distinguished member of this chamber. Nobody would be more respected around the Parliament in a personal sense than yourself. We on the Government side know that your personal qualities will maintain the dignity of your new office.

SPEECH.PARA: And so it goes on. Clearly, here was a man being elected to the position which you now hold, Mr President, who had shown himself over many years, both in state parliament and in the federal sphere in the Senate, as a person of great integrity, great fairness and great honesty. Those words were also reflected in a speech by Senator Wriedt, who spoke on behalf of the opposition, the now government. He said:
I think that all of us around this chamber would agree that you have established a reputation for politeness to people, which is important, and fairness.

Those endearing qualities of fairness and integrity of a very practical man show through very clearly in all the material which I have looked at on former senator and president of the Senate, Sir Condor Laucke.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats also join with the government, the opposition and the National Party in extending to Sir Condor Laucke's widow and family our sincere sympathy and condolences in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew Sir Condor Laucke very well; he was a friend of mine. He was a man whom one could not help but like. He was a very convivial character and a person of shining integrity and impeccable honesty. When I heard of his death I was very sad and also very sad that I could not attend his funeral in South Australia. I had to attend a meeting of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards. I thought to myself, `Would Condor rather me be at his funeral or rather me question the chairman of the Film Board of Review to ascertain where it is currently drawing the line in regard to extremely sexually violent material and R-rated videos?'. I decided upon the latter, fully convinced that that would have been where Condor would have wanted me to be on that day.

PARA.TAB: Condor was a very charming person with very shrewd political gifts. Senator Boswell mentioned that he brought peace to this chamber after a period of some difficulty and disruption, and he did. He did it in a very fine and nice way; those of us who were here know what I mean. He was always polite and courteous to his staff or to anybody with whom he came in contact. His Christian charity and his generosity were legend. I recall very clearly one occasion when this came to the fore. After my first wife died I was taking six of the children through South Australia and wanted to go through the Barossa Valley. I rang Condor up and he said, `Rose has put on the cakes' and my children and I had a wonderful time.

I was phoned by one of the boys, who is much older now, and he said, `Did you know that Sir Laucke had died?'. I told him that I did. He recalled that occasion very clearly. What he recalled most was a ride in Condor's Jaguar. I do not know whether he still had it when he died, but he had this old Jag, which was a great car with none of the artificial stuff in it. The boys really enjoyed that ride and I can remember that very well.

I can very well remember Condor's support for me during that crisis. All I can say about Condor is that he was a thorough Christian gentleman. My sympathies are extended to his wife, Lady Rose, and his family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on this condolence motion for Sir Condor Laucke not so much as a political colleague but as someone who had a personal relationship with him. Sir Condor has been described as a popular political and business figure in South Australia. Anyone who knew him would very much ascribe the word `popular' to him. He had a distinguished service in this place, in the state parliament and as Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia; and, of course, he was quite prominent in business in South Australia, particularly in the Barossa Valley. In many ways Sir Condor was one of the first people from a non-English speaking background to make a mark in this place, and he should also be remembered for that.

PARA.TAB: Condor was very much an old style gentleman. He believed very much in God, Queen and country, and he was very sincere about it. In that context, it is strange for someone with my politics to claim that he was someone with whom I had a personal relationship. Sir Condor was very much a man of the people, and it is in that context that I first came across him. I must state that at the time that I met him I would not have been over the age of 10 or 11. Condor was then a state member of parliament in South Australia. At the same time he was still running his flour mill in Greenock. Through that flour mill he had a very close relationship with a couple of bakers at the continental bakery in Adelaide who were very close to my father.

Through them, a friendship developed, very much because of the culture and laws of the time. We had 6 o'clock closing at that time. Dad had a shop next to the Cumberland Arms Hotel where, after the pub had closed, people would drop in for a drink before they went home. Condor would escape from the state parliament and come and meet with the Platis brothers and have a drink in the shop. On a number of occasions I thought to myself that his usefulness in parliament would not have been all that great, having spent a few hours in the greengrocer's shop having a quiet drink amongst friends. Condor would come quite frequently and spend time and talk with people who were very much not part of the Liberal party in that state, not part of the Barossa Valley society and not part of the business community, but people with whom he felt a very strong affinity.

On a number of occasions I would go into the shop late at night, after having allegedly finished homework, to see that not only had they had a few beers but also that they had managed to knock off most of the vegetables, having got drunk after a few drinks. The sort of character that Sir Condor had, allowed him to interact quite freely with people—spend a lot of time with them and pay a lot of attention to them—and to enjoy himself in doing so.

On one of those occasions that I met him he took an interest in me and talked about his life in parliament. He even suggested, as someone had suggested to him, that maybe he would see me in parliament—I think that is close to his words. He did not. I came in as Sir Condor left this place, but we did, as the batch of incoming senators in 1981, enjoy some of his hospitality and, of course, the famous Barossa Valley wine.

It was in the family context that we got to meet both Rose and Sir Condor's daughter, Rosemary. From time to time they also dropped in to share evenings of friendship as an escape, probably, from parliament. Those of us who spend evenings in parliament or a place like this can quite appreciate the attraction Sir Condor would have felt for getting out of it and spending time with people talking about basic things from football to life and whatever.

As I say, I missed Sir Condor in this place—I was never a political colleague—but his impact on my life through example is something that I have remembered for the best part of 25 to 30 years, if not more. One does not forget that sort of influence, and I do not. His passing, not as a colleague but as a family friend, is regretted by me, my parents and my sister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the tributes to Sir Condor that have been made in the Senate today as well as those made at the state funeral service at Bethlehem Lutheran Church in Flinders Street, Adelaide, which a number of us attended. I am very saddened by the loss of a dear friend and a person I respected enormously as an individual South Australian, as a father of his family, as a Liberal senator and as one who has contributed to my state enormously in all of the fields that have been mentioned, especially by Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Hill when introducing this condolence motion here today.

PARA.TAB: I attended the funeral and memorial service. The church was packed. Many current senators, especially from South Australia, and former senators were present. Mr President, you were very much with us, as were former presidents McClelland and O'Byrne. I noted some of Condor's immediate peers—Gordon Davidson, Sir Harold Young, Don Jessop and Peter Ray. I know that they have a special, fond regard for their friend, especially remembering the years they served together in the Senate.

When I attended the funeral I was struck by the authentic Lutheran service—the reading of scripture and, as the words of the service said, the consolation of the Christian in seeing death as an entry to a continuing life in paradise. The singing by a choir of Barossa residents, especially from the town of Tanunda, was a very moving part of the service. The eulogy given by the former Governor of South Australia, Sir Donald Dunstan, summed up all our thoughts admirably. He was our Governor in South Australia for about nine years. In all that time, Sir Condor was his deputy as the Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia.

The first occasion on which I met Sir Condor was at his own home when I was 21 and attending his daughter's 21st birthday. Rosemary was amongst a set of friends from her mid-teenage years until now. I was delighted to go to the family home. At that time, Sir Condor had served 10 years as the member for Barossa in the state parliament. He moved on from there to be a federal senator for some 14 years and, of course, for the last five or six of those years, he was a very distinguished President of the Senate.

I was very glad that my son, Joshua, who is now 18, especially asked that he might attend the funeral with me and so we went together. He was three when I began in the Senate. Joshua remembers that every time he came to the Senate as a toddler—he came several times a year—Sir Condor was kind and welcoming not only to him but also to his baby brother—and eventually to all three of our sons—and my wife. It was endearing that we came as a family when we came to the rooms of the President of the Senate. That graciousness, courtesy, cheerfulness and kindness was extended not only to colleagues such as me—a South Australian, a Liberal—but also, I believe, to all of us in the Senate chamber. Senator Gareth Evans, who is nodding in agreement, started on the same day as I did, and he and others have said that of Sir Condor as well.

As we attended the funeral, I recalled the delight in my small sons' eyes when they first saw this wonderful man. He looked somewhat like Father Christmas. He had lace in his cuffs and on the front of his beautiful clothes, a wig, and gracious rooms. I soon discovered that he was the first President to have his own wine. When we were his guests it was a delight to drink Bunawunda red and white. I still have a bottle or two of that wine that he gave to me. On an appropriate anniversary, or when Lady Rose or the family visits our home, we will remember through this wine the graciousness of a fine man.

I want to refer to the word that Sir Donald most emphasised in his recollections of his close colleague and deputy governor. That word was `integrity'. This is the word that comes to our mind when we think of his time here in the Senate.

There are two incidents that I wish to recall briefly. The first occurred in my first month in the Senate when I had to make my first real political decision. I had to decide whether I would vote against a budget bill of the government. Those who are aware of my speech in September 1978 will note that I commended the Fraser government, of which I was a backbench member. I drew particular attention to one element of the budget of that year which I regarded as a mistake and a penalty upon the people of South Australia—not least, a penalty on the grape growers of the Barossa Valley. There was to be a massive increase in the brandy excise. As honourable senators know, brandy is made from grapes that are left over. Those grapes, which are sold for a low price, can be used for the production of straight alcohol.

Although the grape growers of South Australia were suffering, my government was going to impose a bigger tax on brandy, which would have meant that less brandy would have been sold and stocks would have grown. I had gone through the econometric models. It was demonstrated to me overwhelming that this decision would be counterproductive to the tax collection revenue plans of the Fraser Government. I believed this so strongly.

Sir Condor, our colleagues and I made up a special delegation to the Prime Minister. This was the first time I had ever visited a Prime Minister's office. At that time—not now—Malcolm Fraser was a forbidding, tall, quiet, difficult Prime Minister for a young back bencher to face. Because I was fired up and they had heard my arguments, my colleagues asked me and put the case, which I did, I thought, clearly and logically. There was no response. After there had been some other discussions, the Prime Minister said, `This is an integral part of the budget. The budget is whole and it is, rightly or wrongly, to be supported'. We left.

I then had to contemplate whether, in my first months as a senator—and following my remarks in my first speech, which I thought were very appropriate, about the 99 that were safe and the one that was endangered—I would cross the floor on the brandy bill. My good friend Sir Condor took me aside and said, `Baden, you have done everything that can be expected of a senator. You have argued the case. You have talked about it with your colleagues. You have put it to the government. It is unreasonable to expect that you would need to demonstrate your case by crossing the floor and voting against your colleagues'. I took the weight of that advice very much into account when I did not vote against the budget measure.

For the record, the brandy excise was counterproductive and there was less revenue raised. I was grateful for the counsel of older and wiser members, especially when, as a 33-year-old Liberal senator, I was gung-ho to support my own state to the upmost against such a measure. As I said, there was a convincing case not to support this measure. With every personal courtesy, Sir Condor gave to me a wiser political perspective.

It is with a very warm heart that I think about Lady Rose and her cheerfulness, her smile and the life that she brought to their marriage and to their family, and then the way in which Condor then projected the same cheerfulness to us all. I can recount a number of times when Lady Rose added so much by being with Sir Condor when he was President of the Senate. Illustrative of this was one occasion when they were representing Australia in the Republic of South Korea. The President of the Senate attended an illustrious dinner as the guest of the President of South Korea.

At that time, politics in South Korea was a very serious affair and it was understood by many that the President of South Korea never smiled. Lady Rose was seated next to the President of Korea and it did not take more than half a minute before he was totally relaxed. All of the other Korean guests said what a person this person from South Australia must be if she can so change the normal style of such a serious man. It was of no surprise to me to hear such excellent reports of the way in which Lady Rose, by her ordinary conversation and her direct cheerfulness, made a very human and totally successful evening of such a visit in which her husband was representing Australia.

Along with my colleagues, I express my sympathy to Lady Rose, Rosemary, young Condor and all of the family, to all the friends and neighbours in Greenock and the Barossa Valley and throughout the whole of the South Australia—a state that Sir Condor served so admirably.

TALK.START.PARA: —The late Sir Condor Louis Laucke and I share a date which was a momentous occasion for each of us. On 17 February 1976, I was sworn in for the first time as a member of this parliament, albeit in another place. More importantly on that day, Senator Laucke was elected President of this Senate—an office which he held with great distinction for some 5 1/2 years.

PARA.TAB: I had known Condor for some years prior to that, both as a friend of members of my family and through our respective involvement in the Liberal Party in South Australia. He was ever ready to give advice to a young budding politician.
