Indeed, one of my many memories which stand out was when Condor accompanied me the first time I made a public speech as an endorsed Liberal candidate. This was when I shared with him a place on the Liberal Senate ticket in South Australia for 1974 double dissolution federal election.

I well recall a brisk trip in his Alfa Romeo sports car from Adelaide to Victor Harbour to join the then member for Barker, the Hon. Dr Jim Forbes, as speakers at a public meeting in the Victor Harbour town hall. Our conversation during that trip ranged far and wide across a number of political issues. His love for Australia and his concern for Australia's future at that time under the Whitlam government, as well as his commitment to the Liberal Party and his shrewd and sound political judgment, became very evident to me on that journey to and from Victor Harbour.

I note that a newspaper report described his election as President of the Senate as having been regarded with scant respect and derisive laughter by the then Labor opposition. If that was the case, those Labor senators certainly grossly underestimated Sir Condor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think that was the case; I was there. I do not recall that.
—I am referring to a newspaper report.
—That is a very unsound principle on these occasions. He was very well regarded.

—I am simply referring to a report. I am not taking that as being the case; I am saying that, if it was the case, Labor senators grossly underestimated Sir Condor. Sir Condor was known and admired by all for his politeness and courtesy, for his patience and decency, as other colleagues have said in speaking to this condolence motion today. These are qualities which are perhaps too often absent in the daily rough and tumble of politics. Perhaps if his election as President was as described in that newspaper report, those Labor senators of 1976 mistook those qualities exemplified by Sir Condor for weakness on his part. They could not have been more mistaken.

PARA.TAB: Over a long period Sir Condor demonstrated his strength as a successful businessman and politician representing South Australia. He was born in 1914, and having been educated at Immanuel College and the School of Mines in Adelaide, he returned to his beloved Greenock in the Barossa Valley to join the flour and feed milling business which his father had bought in 1899. He later became managing director of that business and successfully extended its operation to various parts of South Australia before turning his hand to parliamentary politics. This followed many years as an office bearer in the Liberal Party in South Australia.

He won the seat of Barossa in the House of Assembly in the South Australian Parliament in 1956 serving three terms there, a total of nine years, until his defeat in 1965. Barossa was originally a rural seat which, over the years during which Sir Condor represented it, gradually became subsumed into the metropolitan area by the growth of the suburbs to the north-east of Adelaide, this growing urbanisation completely changing the character of Barossa into a marginal metropolitan seat.

Sir Condor's loss in 1965, which accompanied the first ever defeat of the long serving Playford LCL government in that state, was therefore no negative reflection on his own effort or ability. Indeed, on the contrary, between 1962 and 1965 he served as government whip and was regarded by many of his colleagues in the state parliament as a potential future leader of the South Australian Liberal parliamentary party, the LCL as it then was, and hence a future premier of South Australia. Sadly, his defeat in 1965 prevented that potential being realised.

As I have already said, Sir Condor was noted for his politeness, courtesy and gentlemanly restraint. This was generally in evidence in or out of parliament and even when he enjoyed those wonderful red wines from his beloved Barossa Valley. However, I am reliably informed that there was just one occasion when, as a member of state parliament, these characteristics deserted him.

One evening his colleagues took him to dinner for his birthday and perhaps an unusually large quantity of his beloved Barossa red was consumed. But, whatever the reason, after dinner Sir Condor gave a most uncharacteristic speech in which he was completely unrestrained and aggressive in his approach, the chamber ringing with what colleagues described as Churchillian tones. That this was regarded as such an out of character speech by Sir Condor simply reinforces his normally gentlemanly behaviour.

Despite his 1965 defeat, Sir Condor was not long out of parliament. In March 1967 he was preselected for the No. 1 spot on the South Australian Liberal Senate ticket for the Senate election due later that year. He entered the Senate early, in November 1967, following the death of Senator Hannaford. In the Senate he served this chamber, the people of South Australia and the Liberal Party well, bringing his wide counsel to many deliberations. He was a shadow minister from 1972 to 1975 and then, as I have said, in February 1976 he was elected to the high office of President of this Senate. He performed the duties of President with great distinction until retiring in June 1981, being scrupulously fair and polite but nevertheless firm in his deliberations from the chair. He was justifiably knighted KCMG in the new year's honours of 1979.

It was during this period as a South Australian parliamentary colleague, albeit in different chambers, that I got to know Sir Condor even better. Whenever his advice was sought by a new young member it was freely and generously given. On several occasions after attending functions in the Barossa Valley I recall returning to his magnificent cellar, magnificent not just in the sense of what was stored there but as a magnificently furnished room in which he took great delight in extending his generous hospitality to friends. So it is no wonder that on the last Saturday night in June 1981 some 1,300 friends gathered in the enormous Tanunda show hall to pay tribute to Sir Condor on his retirement from the Senate. It was again a privilege to share the hospitality of his cellar late into the night after that function and to hear him recount his experiences over a long parliamentary career.

But even that was the not the end of his career. From 1982 he served a decade as Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia and, as in his other roles, he served this role with great distinction. His funeral service in Bethlehem Lutheran church in Adelaide last Thursday week was a grand and fitting tribute to a remarkable man and a servant of his state. Throughout his career Sir Condor valued the love and support of his wife Rose and his children Rosemary and young Condor, and in more recent years of his grandchildren. In sharing the privilege of supporting this condolence motion with my colleagues, I especially send my sympathy to these members of his family whom I am also privileged to count as friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to be associated with the condolence motion for our former President of the Senate, Sir Condor Laucke. I entered the Senate following the election in December 1975. To put it mildly, it was not a particularly good year for Labor. There were only six new faces from my party that year, two in the House of Representatives and four in the Senate. Four of us virtually replaced other Labor members and the other two were Senate representatives from the territories which had representation in this chamber for the first time.

PARA.TAB: I mention this because it helps to explain why the government of that time had a majority in its own right. In that respect, Senator Laucke as President was probably fortunate. I deliberately use the word `probably' because the government was in no mood to have its legislative program frustrated, and I have no doubt that from time to time Senator Laucke was leaned on by the government leader in the Senate. I do not for one minute imply that Senator Laucke responded to such tactics but it would not have made his task particularly easy.

My main memory of Senator Laucke is that he was a real gentleman. I still retain this memory even though he called me to order in my first speech which, of course, we used to call our maiden speech. Despite that rocky start I often consulted him on matters of procedure and, irrespective of the fact that I was from a different party, he was courteous and helpful whenever I sought his assistance. In those days there were some rough and ready characters in the opposition and it was not unusual for a senator to be suspended. Senator Laucke would almost bend over backwards to have the offending senator apologise rather than be suspended and, when suspension did follow, he actually became upset when he was required to order a senator from the chamber. I would like to mention that I was here when Sir Condor Laucke was elected President in 1976. I can assure Senator Chapman that the newspaper report to which he referred was totally incorrect.

Often when we remember our former colleagues we remember humorous incidents in which they were involved. I would like to share just three such incidents with the Senate this afternoon. The first occurred when Senator Laucke presided over his first division. He seemed a little taken aback when a division was called for but quickly regained his composure to announce, `Division required, close the doors'. Of course, he corrected his error in order for the bells to be rung but it did seem to be a novel way of conducting a division. If senators were in the chamber well and good; if they were not, too bad.

The second incident which I would like to share occurred when there was a joint sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate to choose a senator to represent the Australian Capital Territory following the death of Senator John Knight. It is history, of course, that the Senate appointed Senator Reid. Senator Laucke presided and the proceedings were telecast—an unusual occurrence in those days. Senator Laucke conducted the proceedings using a forthright delivery to fit the occasion. When the proceedings had concluded, he announced to members of both houses and to the public watching on television, `I now declare this joint sitting open'. After a perceptible pause, he corrected with, `closed'. I suppose that in our role as senators we are asked to open so many activities that his error was understandable.

The third incident had the Senate in peals of laughter. The occasion was question time. Senator Walsh rose to ask a question. I would now like to quote from Hansard, but I am afraid the situation may not seem as humorous as it did in real life. Holding up a toilet roll, Senator Walsh asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Minister for Administrative Services know that the inside of the rolls of toilet paper currently in use in Parliament House—I have a roll here—
he was holding the toilet roll up—

is clearly marked `Government of New South Wales'. In response to the Prime Minister's latest exhortation to reduce government expenditure, has the Government taken to pilfering parliamentary toilet paper from the State of New South Wales? If not, what is the explanation?
Senator Withers, who was the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Administrative Services, replied:

I think that question should have been directed to you, Mr President, because I neither order nor pay for the toilet paper used in Parliament House. I suppose that one could say at the conclusion of the parliamentary session that Senator Walsh has come to the bottom of question time by asking that sort of question. I shall leave it to you, Mr President, to answer the question whether your officers are stealing the paper or purchasing it.
With the roll of toilet paper clearly visible on Senator Walsh's desk, the President replied:
It is hardly my role.

In conclusion, I wish to state that I was saddened when I heard of Sir Condor's death, even though I believe that he had not been in good health for some time. I extend to Lady Rose Laucke and his family my sincere condolences on their sad loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, was one of those fortunate enough to have been here during the time that Sir Condor Laucke was the President of the Senate. I do not think I can add anything to the description of the man as I remember him. I do not think I have ever seen a person with official duties to perform who was so meticulous about the quality, the standing and the correctness of those duties and how they were carried out. He was a most generous man—generous of his time and generous of his goods. He was generous to other people in an ordinary, everyday way. He was a gentleman, he was a true public man and he was a friend of all.

PARA.TAB: He was a wonderful guide to new senators. He took everyone individually under his arm as they came in. He would take them into his suite and listen to them. He would ring them up after they had made a speech and make suggestions as to how they may or may not deal with a subject in future. It did not matter whether they were government or opposition; he would still treat them all the same. He would advise on various standards and procedures to anybody he thought was erring because of a lack of knowledge.

He loved to talk to people and he would invite them, one at a time, around to his suite very often, just so that he could talk to them about the things they did, the background that they had and the way that things were operating in South Australia. He had his considerable interests in business as well as pastoral and farming pursuits. He had this desire for, if not perfection, certainly very high quality in every way. I am very sad at the passing of Sir Condor Laucke. I wish to be associated with the condolence motion, particularly as it affects Lady Rose and his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly. I wish to be associated with this condolence motion for Sir Condor Laucke. I particularly wish to place on record that I knew Sir Condor Laucke, but I had met him on only several occasions.

PARA.TAB: Sir Condor Laucke was the government whip in the South Australian parliament when my father entered state parliament in 1963. I still well remember my father's words after his being in parliament a short time. He came home and said, `Condor Laucke is a gentleman and a gentle man', and I think that he will be remembered by South Australians and certainly by his colleagues as both a gentleman and a gentle man. In 1965, when he lost his seat in state parliament, I remember my father coming home and saying, `Well, my boy, you haven't seen the last of Condor Laucke'. That proved to be a fact in later years when he sought preselection for the Senate, entered the Senate and then made a major contribution in this place both as a senator and later as the President of the Senate. His contributions were then recognised when he became Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia.

My colleagues have detailed all of his activities. I do not want to go over any of that ground, except to place on record the achievements of Sir Condor Laucke. Above all, I think his greatest achievement was the way in which he was known and loved in his own Barossa Valley by his family and those he came in contact with closely. He was respected and put a tremendous amount of effort into the life of that valley, particularly the three major towns that are concerned; he will long be remembered in the Barossa Valley as one of their greatest sons. In addition to recognising his contribution to the Senate and certainly the connections that he had with my own father, I would like to extend my sympathy to his widow, Lady Rose, and his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —The day that Condor Laucke was first elected as President of the Senate was my first day in the chamber, along with Senator Colston. I can also say to Senator Chapman that the newspaper report he referred to was completely wrong. My first impression of Condor Laucke was that he was a courteous gentleman, and that impression never changed. As a new senator I felt that he went out of his way to assist me. At the end of every session I usually received an invitation to his office to try out his new vintage, which he then distributed to all senators at our farewell function.

PARA.TAB: When I look back, like Senator Colston, I feel that at times I felt sorry for him. I think that when the then Leader of the Government, Senator Withers, was in full flight, he tried Condor's patience, secure in the knowledge that he had an absolute majority.

Fortunately, I was able to attend Condor's funeral. As has been said, former Senate presidents McClelland, Sir Harold Young and Justin O'Byrne were all present. I do have one regret and that is that when we tried to organise a function last year which Sir Magnus Cormack and all of the living presidents of the Senate would be able to attend, unfortunately, Condor was too ill and the function never took place. I was able to attend the funeral and extend my sympathy to his wife Rose and his family and, therefore, I associate myself with this condolence motion. I ask all senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 17 June 1993, of Dame Marie Freda Breen DBE, a former senator for the state of Victoria from 1962 to 1968. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Thursday 17 June 1993, of former Senator Dame Marie Freda Breen, DBE, Senator for the State of Victoria from 1962 to 1968, places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Marie was born in 1902—91 years ago—at St Kilda, Victoria, and educated at St Michael's Church of England Girls Grammar School. She was elected to federal parliament in 1961, although did not take her seat in this chamber until mid-1962. Her time in this place was but a small part of a career dedicated to welfare work for women and children.

PARA.TAB: Her life in the public arena began in 1941 when she became, for a short, time the Mayoress of Brighton. From 1954 until 1958 she was President of the National Council of Women and for her outstanding work with this organisation was awarded the Order of the British Empire. Dame Marie will be remembered for her efforts during that time in gaining government subsidies for child care facilities. That is something that may be taken for granted today, but in the 1950s Dame Marie was certainly breaking very new ground indeed.

Her maiden speech in this chamber reflected her great concern for the welfare of Australian families and left no doubt as to what she saw as her priorities: the standard of living of rural Australians, medical care for all Australians and the fight for the stability of family life. She was a member of numerous organisations such as: the Family Planning Association; the Victorian Family Council, of which she was President from 1958 to 1978; and, a little ahead of her time, the Australian-Asian Association of Victoria, of which she was also President from 1956 until 1974. These are but a handful of the organisations with which Dame Marie was involved in the course of her very long and very distinguished career. In 1979 she was made Dame of the British Empire for distinguished community service. On behalf of the government, I extend our sincere sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of coalition senators, I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in expressing our regret at the recent death of former Senator Dame Marie Breen at the age of 91. It is indeed rare for a life to be dedicated to community service to the extent that Marie Breen was. She was born and bred in Melbourne and I understand that she lived there all her life. In 1941, when Mayoress of Brighton, Mrs Breen, as she then was, began a 36-year involvement with the Victorian Baby Health Centres Association. She represented the Baby Health Centres Association on the National Council of Women. Her involvement with the National Council of Women expanded to becoming honorary international secretary from 1948 to 1953 and later President from 1954 to 1958.

PARA.TAB: In 1944 it was Mrs Breen's approach to the Victorian state health minister that led to an amendment to the Local Government Act enabling municipalities to employ home help assistance. While much of her work focused on the areas of women and children's health and welfare, Marie Breen was also champion of the importance of the family unit. Through her involvement with the mothers union of the Church of England from 1938, she came to be, from 1946 to 1960, convenor of the Church of England Marriage Guidance and Education Council. She helped to train the first marriage guidance counsellors and was herself a counsellor until she became a senator.

Mrs Breen also had a strong interest in fostering good relations between countries in our region. She was, as Senator Gareth Evans has just said, a major figure in the Australian-Asian Association of Victoria and, in fact, foundation Vice-President of the association from 1956 to 1973. Mrs Breen was one of the founders of the Victorian Family Council from which the Citizens Advice Bureau evolved. From 1967 to 1974 she was the foundation President of the Melbourne Citizens Advice Bureau.

Her political involvement began as far back as 1936 when she became honorary secretary of the Brighton branch of the Australian Women's National League, a position which she held for four years. During this time she was greatly impressed and influenced by Mrs, later Dame, Elizabeth Couchman. From 1940 to 1945 Mrs Breen was President of the Brighton branch of the AWNL and a member of its executive committee.

Her record of service to the Liberal Party is truly outstanding. Among offices too numerous to mention, she was for 15 years—from 1945 to 1960—chairman of the women's section of the LCP of Victoria, and from 1946 to 1961 she was a member of its executive committee. For two years in the early 1950s she was chairman of the federal executive of the Liberal Party. She was elected to the Senate in 1961, taking her place the following year. Her time in the Senate was distinguished by her involvement in a number of committees, including as Vice-Chairman and later Chairman of the Printing Committee.

I understand that the serious illness of her husband, as a result of an accident in 1968, led to her decision not to seek re-election in the election of that year. Her retirement from the Senate, however, was anything but idle. She continued to serve the community in a multitude of ways, which included a stint as President of the Family Planning Association of Victoria from 1970 to 1971 and membership of the Housing Builders Registry Board from 1972 to 1979. She was also a member of the Australian Advisory Council of Elders.

Former Senator Breen's exceptional service to the community was recognised during her lifetime with the award of the OBE in 1958. She received the award of Dame of the British Empire in 1979. In an interview in 1989, Marie Breen mentioned that she had been privileged to meet many able women during her life and to learn from them. Her own life is undoubtedly one of those which will serve to inspire others. The people of Australia, particularly those of Melbourne, Victoria, have much for which to thank Marie Breen. On behalf of all coalition senators, I take this opportunity to extend our sincere condolences to her daughters and their family in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to join in the condolence motion moved by the government and extend my sympathy to Dame Marie Breen's family—I acknowledge that they are in the gallery today. Dame Marie Breen exemplified the spirit of public service and voluntary enterprise. She had a successful career in federal politics but will perhaps be remembered and revered for her lifelong mission to improve the health and welfare of women and children.

PARA.TAB: Dame Marie Breen's involvement in this laudable area spanned many decades. She was President of the National Council of Women from 1954 to 1958 and President of the Victorian Family Council from 1958 to 1978. She served as Victorian President and executive member of the Queen Elizabeth Hospital for Mothers and Babies from 1943 to 1978. She was involved with the Marriage Guidance Council of Victoria for many years, as well as the Family Planning Association of Victoria, of which she was President from 1970 to 1971.

Remarkably, Dame Marie Breen was also a forerunner in her recognition that there was a need for Australia to build solid and strong links with Asia. To help foster such links of understanding and tolerance, Dame Marie Breen served as Vice-President of the Australian-Asian Association of Victoria from 1956 to 1974. She was chairperson of the overseas students coordinating committee from 1961 to 1972 and she was also on the UNICEF committee.

Dame Marie Breen began her political career in 1941 as Mayoress of the Melbourne suburb of Brighton. She held the office of state vice-president of the Victorian Liberal Country Party for nine years from 1953 to 1962. She was elected to the Senate that same year and served with distinction as a Liberal senator for Victoria for six years. During her term in the Senate, Dame Marie was always hardworking. She was Chairman of the Printing Committee and was also a member of the Library Committee, the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary and Government Publications and the Senate Select Committee on the Metric System of Weights and Measures.

A promising political career was prematurely cut short when family circumstances caused Dame Marie to retire from the Senate in 1968. Putting personal ambition behind her, Dame Marie Breen chose to serve her family with the dedication and devotion with which she served the people of Victoria when in this place. I extend the sympathies of National Party senators to Dame Marie Breen's family and many friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add the condolences of the Australian Democrat senators to the family and friends of Dame Marie Breen. As a Victorian, I am very well aware of her record as a tireless worker for the welfare of women and children in my home state. Her death is a loss to all of us. Dame Marie served as a senator from 1962 to 1968 before retiring somewhat prematurely to care for her husband, Robert, when he became seriously ill. As has been mentioned before, she received an OBE in 1958 and was made a Dame of the British Empire in 1979 in recognition of her services to women and children. It is these services which formed the basis of her life's work.

PARA.TAB: Dame Marie was active in many organisations which sought to improve the availability of services for women. She was President of the National Council of Women during the 1950s and had a 14-year association with the Marriage Guidance Council of Victoria. She was President of the Victorian Family Council for 20 years and an executive member of the Queen Elizabeth Hospital for Mothers and Babies for more than 30 years. There were many other organisations too numerous to mention which benefited from Dame Marie's commitment and support.

Dame Marie had a strong belief in what she called the `volunteer spirit' and the need for people to contribute their time, energy and compassion to others in the community. She wanted to see an increased commitment to families in rural areas, to the medical and health needs of women and young children, and to organisations which sought to prevent family breakdown. She also took a keen interest in women's issues and development issues in Asian countries—and in that respect she was very clearly ahead of her time.

Without in any way neglecting her duties as a senator, Dame Marie's first priority was clearly the contribution she could make to Victorian women and their families. She always saw those women as being the primary focus of her work and as having first call on her time. In that she set an example to us all. Her death is a loss to Victoria and Australia. I extend my sympathy and that of my Democrat colleagues to her daughters, and to her family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to the life and work of Dame Marie Breen. I regret not having had the opportunity to meet Dame Marie, but the tributes paid by Mrs Jean Cheshire, Dame Phyllis Frost, Father Dan Conquest and the Reverend Lawrence Reeve at her funeral moved me greatly and reflected the deep regard and affection which she inspired from all who knew her. In recent days I have had the opportunity to speak to members of Dame Marie's family and learn more about the magnificent contribution that she made to this community—not only, of course, to the Liberal Party but to the wider community. I should mention that in the gallery this evening we are honoured with the presence of Dame Marie's daughter, Pru, and granddaughter, Virginia.

PARA.TAB: Dame Marie Breen was a Liberal senator for six years, from 1962 to 1968. It is a great source of pride for the Liberal Party that it was in the forefront of endorsing women for parliament. In the early 1960s there were five women in the federal parliament, four of whom represented the Liberal Party. Dame Marie Breen was among that path-finding group of Liberal women, which included Senators Wedgwood, Buttfield and Rankin, who firmly established that women had an important role to play in the parliament of this nation.

Perhaps inspired by Dame Marie Breen's magnificent community record, the Victorian Liberal Party approached her to stand for the Senate in 1961. In seeking women candidates, the Liberal Party was well in advance of community sentiment. Dame Marie Breen herself, in an interview she gave, summed up the prevailing community attitude in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: There was not any wild desire to have women in parliament amongst the male population. It is better now, but it was not very much to the fore in those days.

There is no doubt that Dame Marie Breen was a remarkable woman with great strength of character. From my conversations with those who knew her, a picture has emerged of a person with very strong personal values, and particularly the great Christian values of family, public service and community. In many ways, her life, which was dedicated to building and strengthening voluntary organisations, embodied one of the great traditions of the Liberal Party. I refer to the commitment to voluntary work as the basis for building a strong community.
Dame Marie Breen was able to give effect to her values through her ability to organise and motivate those around her. All of those to whom I have spoken speak about her superb administrative skills.

Dame Marie was born in 1902 and educated at St Michael's Church of England Girls Grammar School. Her earliest recollections, which were recorded in an interview conducted with her in 1983, foreshadow a life of service to others. She speaks `of being allowed to help in small ways' with the patriotic efforts pursued by her parents during World War I.

PARA.TAB: In 1928, Dame Marie married Robert Breen, a solicitor. They were a devoted couple, and the marriage formed the focal point of Dame Marie's life for the next 40 years. They had three daughters, Jeannette, Prudence and Marie—two of whom followed their parents into the world of politics. Jeanette served in both local government and as a member for Brighton in the Victorian Legislative Assembly from 1976 to 1985. Prue was also active in local government while the youngest daughter, Marie, pursued an artistic life as a painter. It was Robert who introduced Marie to the world of politics, and both of them were founding members of the Liberal Party. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the following documents:

SPEECH.PARA: Budget Documents—
1.Budget Statements 1993-94
2.The Commonwealth Public Account 1993-94
3.Commonwealth Financial Relations with other levels of Government 1993-94
Budget Related Documents—
1.Government Securities on Issue at 30 June 1993
2.National Income and Expenditure 1992-93
3.Income Tax Statistics 1991-92 Income Year
4.Women's Budget Statement 1993-94
5.Social Justice Strategy 1993-94
6.Australia's Trade Development Program 1993-94
7.Program Performance Statements
Report of the Auditor-General
I seek leave to make a statement relating to the 1993-94 budget.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is delivering in another place his budget speech for 1993-94. It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the budget proposals of the government. Mr President, the greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work; too many have been out of work for too long. The primary objective of this budget is jobs—jobs in the short term by providing a further stimulus to the economy this year to sustain Australia's economic growth until the motor of the world recovery kicks in, and jobs in the medium and longer term by boosting the capacity of Australian business to expand production on a world competitive basis. This is a budget to strengthen the recovery and make it sustainable.

PARA.TAB: Australia has had a number of economic recoveries in the post-war period only to see them taper off prematurely, but this recovery is different. It is different because firmly embedded into Australia's economic structure we now have two vital ingredients—inflation at levels lower than seen for 30 years and interest rates at their lowest in 20 years. These have been the twin goals of every government for a quarter of a century, but it is this government which has attained them, and harnessed them for the future benefit of all Australians. That makes this recovery different. This will be a quality recovery—a durable recovery.

Mr President, this budget establishes an economic framework over four years; a framework for continuing low interest rates and continuing low inflation which, combined with reduced company tax and generous investment incentives, will support increased business investment for future growth in production and employment. This budget sets us on a prudent path leading to lower government deficits and higher national saving. This budget proposes measures which, overall, will cut the deficit four years from now by $9 billion. These steps will see the public sector directly contribute some $17 billion to the improvement of national saving over the three years to 1996-97.

The budget also takes action on government programs put forward in the context of the last election. Well over 100 separate spending commitments will be implemented. These will be funded over the course of the next four years. These commitments give effect to the government's plans to provide extra help to families with children, extra assistance to those out of work, improved health services and other initiatives to make this society even fairer and more cohesive.Other commitments include action to enrich the culture of our country, protect its environment and support those living outside the major cities.

This budget will also provide new support for our emerging exporters, who are demonstrating such remarkable success in capturing new markets for products made and developed by the skilled hands and creative minds of Australia's working men and women.

The budget also provides relief for middle Australia by lowering marginal tax rates for those on incomes between $20,700 and $50,000. This will reduce the tax paid by a person on $600 per week by $8 per week. Not only will this promised tax cut be delivered, but also it will be delivered eight months early, commencing on 1 November 1993—just eleven weeks away. This early payment is largely made possible by higher dividends from businesses like Telecom and the Reserve Bank. It is only right that taxpayers should benefit from the higher earnings of these public bodies.

The government has decided to go further with the tax cuts by extending the benefits to low income taxpayers. Those on incomes below $23,200 will receive a new rebate paid on assessment. This will relieve about 90,000 taxpayers of their entire tax bill and ensure that a tax cut of $100 or more is paid to all other taxpayers annually. The combined effects of the budget measures will result in a deficit of $16 billion this year. This will provide an extra stimulus of around $2 billion to Australia's economy at a time when a stimulus is needed to sustain the recovery.

Australia's subdued recovery in part reflects the time taken to recover from the sapping effects of the debt build-up and falling asset prices of the late 1980s. Of more importance, though, is the continuing weakness of the world economy. Whereas a year ago growth in the industrialised economies was expected to be three per cent in 1993, it is now expected to be only a little over one per cent. Japan and Germany, the world's second and third largest economies, have yet to emerge from recession. Against that background Australia has done well and will continue to do so. Our GDP growth in 1992-93 was 2 1/2 per cent—a rate the envy of the industrialised world.

Our relatively good performance can be attributed to two factors. First, the government's foresight in building up budget surpluses in the late 1980s, and then using that capacity to provide a major stimulus to the economy when it was required; and second, our growing trade and investment links with the fastest growing region of the world—the dynamic economies of Asia.

Mr President, the short-term outlook for the world economy remains subdued and, therefore, places a constraint on our own growth. The world outlook, however, is expected to improve during 1994. Australia's challenge is to position itself to take full advantage of stronger world growth as it comes on stream and to continue our integration with the Asian economies. Above all, this requires the further development of world class industries able to seek out and exploit new opportunities. That assures the best long-term prospect of reducing unemployment and raising Australian living standards.

Policy will have its part to play by building on the substantial structural reform achieved over the past ten years; by maintaining the much improved competitive position of our export industries—especially through low inflation; and by adjusting fiscal policy so that sufficient domestic saving is available to fund the additional investment required.

Mr President, at the July Premiers' Conference all Australian governments agreed on the key challenge for fiscal policy today. The conference benefited from a major report on national saving commissioned from Dr Vince FitzGerald, a response to which the Treasurer is releasing tonight. That fiscal challenge is to continue the stimulus to activity over the next year to encourage economic recovery and job growth, while setting in train medium term adjustments to significantly increase public sector saving.

From next financial year, the process of withdrawing the stimulus and cutting the deficit will begin. While the growth path of the economy will assist, on its own it will be insufficient to accomplish the task. This budget therefore contains measures which will accelerate the process. Four years from now, the deficit will be cut to less than $6 billion, or around one per cent of GDP.

This meets a key election commitment of the government. It will be achieved through five complementary steps. First, the second round of tax cuts will be deferred from 1996 until a time when fiscal conditions permit, probably in 1998. Second, outlays will be reduced by $2 billion. Third, the income tax system will be tightened to remove or reduce certain concessions, and to tax non-cash benefits in a manner more equivalent to the taxation of the ordinary income of wage and salary earners. This will raise over $600 million. Fourth, rates of excise on petroleum products and tobacco will be progressively increased. Fifth, wholesale sales tax rates will be increased in two stages over the next two years.

The effect of these outlays and revenue measures will reduce the prospective deficit for 1996-97 by $9 billion, but these changes will do more than that. They will halt the erosion of Commonwealth indirect tax revenues, thus preventing Australia's tax system becoming lopsided. The share of tax revenue, other than from income tax, has fallen by almost a third—from 8.3 per cent of GDP in the mid-eighties to 5.9 per cent last year. Failure to act on the indirect tax side would create pressures for more weight on income tax, a weight which would fall most heavily on middle income earners.

The government will meet its announced objectives without the introduction of a massive new indirect tax. The government will maintain indirect tax exemptions for the necessities of life. The government will maintain the system of higher tax rates for luxury items such as fur coats, jewellery and expensive cars. Compared with the taxation situation applying last financial year, the benefits flowing from the income tax cuts plus the new rebate amount to $1.7 billion this financial year, rising to $3.8 billion.

The indirect tax increases raise $1.3 billion this financial year, rising to $3.0 billion. In other words, in each year the benefits from the tax cuts will greatly exceed the extra indirect tax revenue—with these benefits being delivered to middle Australia.

I now move to the main aspects of the measures, full details of which are provided in supporting documents. Excise on petroleum products will rise by 3c a litre from tonight and a further 2c a litre a year later. An additional increase on leaded petrol will commence in February 1994 at 1c per litre rising to 5c per litre by a year later. This recognises the harmful effect of lead in petrol, particularly on the children of Australia, and will accelerate the conversion of the motor vehicle fleet to unleaded petrol. Even if all these increases in fuel excises were implemented overnight, Australia would still have the third lowest petrol prices in the industrialised world—and among the lowest fuel taxes.

Excise on tobacco products will rise three per cent tonight and in four similar steps over two years. Excise on beer and spirits will remain unchanged. From tonight, the existing wholesale sales tax rates will increase by one per cent, and by a further one per cent in 1995. Wine is currently more lightly taxed than beer and spirits. From tonight, tax on wine will apply at the 31 per cent rate. But the government is committed to retaining the exclusion of wine from excise.

From tomorrow, lump sum payments of unused annual leave and long service leave will be taxed as normal income. Concessions will remain for those now aged 55 years or over, and those who leave their jobs through redundancy or for invalidity reasons. From April 1994, salary package benefits, such as membership of social clubs and similar items, will be fully subject to the fringe benefits tax arrangements, together with domestic travel expenses and accommodation costs in excess of reasonable levels.

Of the entire net revenue increase over the next four years from the budget tax measures: not $1 will go towards increased expenditure; not $1 will go towards meeting the government's spending commitments made at the time of the last election. These spending commitments have been funded over the four years by reducing outlays in other areas.

I now turn to the key spending and savings measures. In the health area, savings will be achieved by reducing double dipping on Medicare benefits; reducing Medicare fraud and overservicing through new cooperative arrangements; and enhanced auditing of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The safety net for the PBS will be tightened for non-card holders.

Further savings will come from restricting access to Medicare benefits for optometry services. That will place optometry on a basis comparable to the new dental health program. The growth of defence spending will be reduced. The pension age for women will be increased to 65 in line with the pension age for men. But this will be gradually introduced over 20 years—minimising the impact on those approaching retirement.

The government is concerned that some families of fairly comfortable means have been able to exploit negative gearing to meet income test rules. From 1 January 1995, the income tests for a range of programs including Austudy and family payments will be changed so that net losses from negative gearing of rental properties are added back to other income.

Secondary Austudy for students living at home will start in future at the age of 17. However, the additional family payment system will be extended. This will result in tighter targeting, and improved benefits to those families eligible for rent assistance.

New arrangements for the higher education contribution scheme will mean students commence repayments earlier and at higher rates, but with the income-contingent feature of the repayments preserved. The income test ceiling for the basic family payment will be lowered to $60,000, removing the benefit from the highest income six per cent of families currently receiving the payment.

Mr President, this budget takes as a key objective the implementation of the government's election commitments. Over 100 of these commitments will have been met since the election and in this budget. Full details are set out in a special report included with the budget documents. The implementation of the remaining few is still being resolved.

I will deal with some of the major commitments briefly. The new Commonwealth dental health program will provide all health card holders with improved access to emergency care from January 1994—and basic dental care from six months later. The new child-care cash rebate of 30 per cent of claimable costs will be introduced from July next year, to be paid to eligible families regardless of income. A total of 230,000 Australian families will benefit from this measure, with payments of up to $28.20 per week for one child, and $61.20 for two or more children.

The new home child care allowance will be paid from September next year. It will provide payments of up to $30 per week and will replace the dependent spouse rebate for couples with children; 840,000 Australian families will benefit. This is a substantial and progressive change to Australia's income support system.

The new seniors health card will be provided, from 1 July next year, to low income retirees not currently receiving the pension. This will entitle around 200,000 older Australians to benefits which include concessional pharmaceuticals and hearing aids, and access to the new dental health program. The pension assets test will be eased with effect from September this year. This will benefit around 60,000 non-pensioner and part-pensioner retirees.

Mr President, this budget also contains a number of initiatives additional to those raised in the election context. The government said in the election that it would not forget the unemployed, nor leave them behind. To address this problem more fully, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has established a committee on employment opportunities, comprising recognised experts in this area. The committee is examining current policies on unemployment, and possible alternatives, and will prepare a discussion paper by December this year.

That will form the basis for broad community debate, leading to a government white paper on the issue. This will provide the forum for consideration of any new approaches for dealing with this very real social and economic problem.

But for now this budget will provide increased support for Australia's unemployed in two substantial ways. First, the total number of labour market program places available in this financial year will be increased to over 500,000. Two-thirds of these are for people who have been unemployed for 12 months or more. Second, we will increase by $6 per fortnight the rate of newstart allowance paid to single adults without children, unemployed for more than 12 months.

One sure way to reduce unemployment is through the expansion and development of Australian industry. That requires business investment. And to secure that business investment, Australian governments need to create the most favourable environment for the expansion of productive business and jobs. Creating that environment requires the establishment of a stable framework for business planning. Crucial to that, there must be confidence that Australia's prospective budget deficit is being reduced substantially over the medium term.

At the same time, this government is actively promoting Australia's economic transition through its taxation policy. Action has already been taken to implement a number of election commitments in this area. Central to these was the reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, effective from 1 July.
We have given investment an additional fillip by introducing a general investment allowance and have expanded the development allowance. This budget goes further by providing a boost to exporters.

Nowhere is Australia's economic transition more evident than in our trading performance. Exports now account for 20 per cent of the total goods and services we produce, compared with 13 per cent a decade ago. The composition of our trade has changed and matured. Exports of the more sophisticated manufactured goods have grown at 20 per cent annually over the last seven years. The destination of Australia's exports has also shifted dramatically, with Asia now taking almost 60 per cent of our merchandise exports. This partly reflects the much higher growth rates in Asia than in the older industrialised world. It also reflects our developing trade successes in the region. We must build on the progress to date and encourage greater engagement with the Asia-Pacific region.

One initiative the Treasurer is announcing tonight is the establishment of a committee jointly with the Northern Territory Government to consider strategies to develop the potential of Darwin as Australia's northern link to east Asia.

McKinsey's recent study of emerging exporters revealed that much of the impetus for our recent export growth has come from 700 small to medium sized manufacturing exporters. These exporters earned over $8 billion in 1990-91, double the level of four years earlier. According to that study, 90 per cent of Australia's manufacturers—more than 6000 businesses—are not yet exporting, but most could be, suggesting an undeveloped source of potential exports and employment.

The challenge is to see many more of these companies achieve their potential. Accordingly, $94 million will be provided over the next three years to fund a package of measures designed to encourage more small to medium sized firms to commence exporting and to intensify the efforts of existing exporters.

These measures include the establishment of first stop shops, improvements to the export market development grants scheme, and the establishment of a `Market Australia' campaign. Further details of this government's strategies to improve Australia's trade performance can be found in a separate paper, released tonight.

Mr President, other policy settings are also crucial to boosting Australia's competitive position. Wages policy is making its contribution by supporting a more decentralised and flexible system to secure faster productivity growth. Workplace bargaining is becoming the centrepiece of the system, with now over 1,000 federally registered enterprise agreements. Work practices can now be better attuned to the needs of individual firms.

Such changes could not have been achieved without the support and commitment of Australia's trade union movement. The Government's accord with the ACTU will maintain the framework for reform, and increase the focus on workplace bargaining. The Government will protect vulnerable workers with legislation to guarantee minimum wages and conditions.We will also support an arbitrated safety net adjustment.

Mr President, continued and accelerated structural reform is critical to increasing growth in the economy and expanding job opportunities. We have carried out extensive reforms in the past decade. Some of the payoffs are already evident and include lower domestic air fares, lower phone charges, greater labour productivity in shipping and on our railways, and better ship cargo handling rates and turnaround times.Such reforms improve Australia's prospects in an increasingly competitive world. This process will be taken further when the government considers the report of the national competition policy review, which we expect to receive in the next few days. I expect the recommendations of that review will lead to improvements in the regulatory environment for business, and further efficiency gains.

Mr President, the budget presented tonight marks the commencement of a new era in Australian public finance. It is the first Commonwealth budget crafted within the framework of a national fiscal strategy—with its figuring informed by July's National Fiscal Outlook report. It will be the last Commonwealth budget to be brought down in August. From next year, the budget will be delivered before the end of June. That will allow decision makers to plan for a full financial year, fully informed of the details of government policy.

Tonight's budget is designed to fortify the framework of Australia's economic growth. In the short term, it provides a continuing stimulus while the economy is still being buffeted by weak international growth.Despite these headwinds, growth is expected to be a little stronger in the year ahead, and at a rate few other industrialised countries will exceed.

Growth this year will be aided by continuing steady growth in private consumption, stronger public sector demand and a contribution from net exports. Business investment is expected to improve. This augurs well for the future. It will help the recovery to gain momentum. Employment growth will begin to recover, but not fast enough to make major inroads into unemployment this year.

However, Mr President, this budget is not just about this year. It is part of a longer-term strategy—a strategy to build the savings of the nation as the economy recovers, so that private investment can be financed, and more of it financed at home; a strategy that builds on and complements the impressive progress already made in improving our economic strengths. Over the next four years, the economic transition we embarked upon ten years ago will be taken further: the transition from being inward looking and highly protected, to a modern world-class economy; the transition from excessive reliance on ties with Europe, to participating in the opportunities provided by the economic dynamism of the Asia-Pacific region.

No longer is Australia a European outpost on the far side of the world; we have seen the tyranny of distance give way to the blessing of proximity. We have redirected our trade focus and diversified our export base. We are 30 per cent more competitive than we were ten years ago.Productivity has grown by five per cent over the last two years. The profit share has recovered to the high levels of the late 1960s.

But beyond all else, the two most historically important achievements are those on inflation and interest rates. It is 30 years since inflation has been so low, and monetary policy will play its part in keeping core inflation low. It is 20 years since interest rates have been so low. These are achievements to be proud of. They are the vital building blocks for better investment and export performance. They result from a coordinated and coherent strategy of reform across all sectors of the economy. In the 1980s, Australia led the developed world in structural reform, and we are staying the course in the 1990s so as to maximise the benefits of the reforms to date.

Mr President, this budget details a coherent and carefully designed plan for achieving the government's announced fiscal objective of reducing the deficit over four years. It continues the government's strong record of fiscal responsibility established in the 1980s while delivering on election commitments. And it does so by keeping Australia a low tax country and at the same time delivering substantial income tax cuts. Next month, Australia will be confirmed by the OECD as the country with the lowest level of taxation in the industrialised world. The decisions announced tonight are designed to keep Australia in the low tax league.

Overall, tonight's budget reinforces the strengths on which Australia's long-term prosperity depends. It provides a prudent path to the future: a path leading to an Australia which saves more; a path leading to an Australia which can invest more in its own undoubted strengths; and a path leading crucially to more jobs for our people.
I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the statement and documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table budget related document No. 4 entitled Women's Budget Statement 1993-94 and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time Menzies formed the Liberal Party in 1944, Marie Breen belonged to the Australian Women's National League, a group that decided to join with the Liberal Party providing that equal representation would be given to women.

PARA.TAB: Her husband, Robert, was an active member of the ANA and the Young Nationalists and was also involved in local and state politics, standing as the United Australia Party candidate for Footscray in 1945. Robert later became mayor of Brighton. In her role as mayoress of Brighton, Marie Breen became very much involved with community life and philanthropic activities. She said, `It was rather like the house that Jack built. One thing led to another'.

She was active in the Victorian Baby Health Centres Association and was an executive member for 36 years. She became convenor of the Mothers Union and was integral in the establishment of, and became Vice-President of, the Marriage Guidance Council of Victoria. Dame Marie Breen's compassion and humanity are reflected in her involvement in many causes and in her role as a prominent voice for women, children and families.

Senator Gareth Evans, in his condolence speech, pointed out that, in the area of child-care, for example, Dame Marie Breen could rightly be described as a pathfinder in promoting that particular area. She played a key role in the establishment and operation of the Victorian Family Council which took a keen interest in less fortunate families and addressed issues such as housing for low income groups and provision of playground facilities for children living in high-rise accommodation.

Under the aegis of the National Council for Women, she was instrumental in the establishment of the citizens advice bureaus and strongly supported the establishment of an institute of family studies. Dame Marie's enormous efforts in welfare work for women and children were officially recognised when she was awarded an OBE in 1958 and in 1979 when she was made Dame of the British Empire, or DBE. Dame Marie held a wide range of offices in the Liberal Party and was a member of the executive committee and chairman of the women's section. She was state vice-president from 1955 to 1961.

As a Liberal Party senator from 1962, she continued to promote her firm belief in the central and stabilising role of the family. As Ann Millar, the Acting Director of Parliamentary Research in the Senate Procedure Office notes in her forthcoming book about women in Parliament, entitled Trust the Women:

SPEECH.PARA: In her public speeches, Senator Breen placed considerable emphasis on the importance of family life, stating on one occasion that `stable national life depended very largely upon a stable family life'. However, she did not see that as excluding other areas of political debate, rather, that all topics had an effect on family life and that therefore women had an important role to play.

Although she had been long involved in public affairs, Dame Marie recounts her terror at having to present her maiden speech and the prospect of every word being recorded in Hansard. However, history records that she quickly overcame her nervousness. Particularly through her work on Senate committees, she contributed a great deal to the work of federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: Her friends have reminded me in so many ways that Dame Marie could be described as a pathfinder. A number of other senators have mentioned that she was a very strong advocate of closer relations with our Asian neighbours. She was Vice-President of the Australian Asian Association which in her words `has been extremely successful . . . in developing a better understanding of the Asian people'. Interestingly, Sir Edward Dunlop, to whom we are also paying tribute this evening, was president of that association at one time.

Before becoming a senator, Dame Marie travelled to Korea where she spoke at an anti-communist rally. In the mid-1960s, in an official capacity, Dame Marie and her husband travelled to Malaysia, India and Indonesia, where she spoke on behalf of Australia at a major rally in Jakarta.

After six years in the Senate, Dame Marie's promising political career was cut short when she resigned to nurse her husband who had been gravely injured in an accident. With the warmth and determination that was so characteristic of this remarkable woman, she nursed her husband every day for 13 months. Sadly, he did not recover. There seems little doubt that had Marie Breen stayed in the Senate she would have risen to high political office.

There are other features of this remarkable woman which should be recorded in the Senate this evening. Marie Breen was a committed and practising Christian all her life. Her faith was reflected in her longstanding record of service to the church. The Friday night discussion group meetings, for example, which she organised for the St Peter's youth fellowship in the 1940s and 1950s where topical and contentious issues were discussed are still, I am pleased to record, remembered by those who attended those particular discussion groups.

Marie Breen was a very talented pianist and singer and at one stage in her youth she hoped to pursue a musical career and study at the conservatorium. However, her mother convinced her that she should instead learn more practical skills, such as secretarial skills, so that she could help her brother in his legal practice. While Marie Breen did as her mother wished, her artistic gifts and interests were not wasted. Dame Marie, together with her daughter Jeannette, sang with the Brighton philharmonic choir and even had a season in the chorus of the National Opera. Her interest in opera and ballet continued throughout her life.

Dame Marie also had a prodigious memory. Her daughter Pru related to me how she had an immense collection of books which she had not only read but could remember in detail. It was not surprising that so many of her friends regarded her as a fount of knowledge and information.
Marie Breen had a wide range of devoted friends. Jean Cheshire, a close friend, wrote a poem for Dame Marie's 90th birthday. Jean Cheshire wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Your interests and involvements did not stop at your front door,
In Parliament and community you courageously held the floor,
You were an inspiration and fearless to the core,
When you saw injustice and the need to change the law.

Dame Marie Breen leaves three children, nine grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. The life of Dame Marie Breen was active and full. It was a good and purposeful life dedicated to her family and those around her and to the general betterment of others. The Liberal Party and, indeed, Australia is richer for her legacy and it is appropriate that we honour her memory in the Senate this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words in tribute to the late Dame Marie Freda Breen, former Liberal and Country Party senator for Victoria from 1962 to 1968, who died on 17 June 1993. As a senator for Victoria, I am fortunate to follow a distinguished line of women senators, one of whom was the late Dame Marie Breen. Today that line has been augmented with the swearing in of my colleague Senator Judith Troeth. I am sure she will continue that tradition that has been left to us by women such as Dame Ivy Wedgwood, Dame Marie Breen and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I am sure that, had Judith made her maiden speech, she would be joining me on this occasion but since she has not, I am sure she will agree with all I say.

PARA.TAB: In her lifetime, Dame Marie worked assiduously to improve the lives of Australian women and children and she took a keen interest in the welfare of others, especially those overseas. She helped advance many causes, such as marriage guidance and family planning, at a time when they were not fashionable. We have heard a number of times tonight that she was a woman ahead of her time. Her strength of spirit and level of commitment were admired and commented on by many. As President of the National Council of Women from 1954 to 1958, she was active in gaining government subsidies for creches and nurseries for children at a time when no such facilities existed.

Dame Marie was also involved in establishing—and maintained a long association with n 1968.—the Marriage Guidance Council of Victoria, the Family Planning Association, the Victorian Family Council and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital for mothers and babies, to name just a few. She was president of the last three organisations at one time or another.

As we have heard, Dame Marie was also a prime instigator in the formation of the Citizens Advice Bureau. She served as a vice-president of the Asian Association of Victoria, as a chairperson of the Overseas Students Coordinating Committee and on the UNICEF committee.

So often our Prime Minister has tried to change history. Some of the women on the left side of politics forget our history and forget the contribution of women such as Dame Marie Breen—women who are ahead of their time and who not only talked about issues of social justice but also acted on those things. They actually committed their lives and dedicated much of their time to areas such as women's affairs, health of women and children, overseas students and overseas issues—the sorts of things that many women on the left now claim they were the first to talk about. That is not so. We should never forget history and the calibre of women such as Dame Marie Breen who set the standard and provided role models for many of us who followed in their footsteps long before it was fashionable to do so.

It was chiefly for her community work that Dame Marie Breen received an OBE in 1958 and was later made a Dame of the British Empire in 1979. As we heard, she was mayoress of Brighton in 1941, state President of the Victorian Liberal and Country Party in 1953 and was elected to the Senate in 1961. She served in the Senate as a member of the printing, library, parliamentary and government publications committees and the Senate select committee on the metric system of weights and measures.

As Senator Kemp has said, had Dame Marie not left the Senate to care for her husband, who was very ill after a tragic accident, we may well have seen her bring her skills and attributes to bear more fully in the chamber. I am sure the chamber and Australia would have been richer for it had she been able to stay here longer. She was remembered fondly when she retired from the Senate in 1968. Former opposition Senator Cohen said at the time—I think it is always telling when we find someone from the other side saying these things—`She is a lady for whom I have a great deal of affection and respect'.

Of her work, Dame Marie said in an interview as late as 1991 that she hoped that there would always be a volunteer spirit because it typifies the caring for each other that people need to express—a lesson we could all well remember. Dame Marie also said—this is another lesson we should remember—that she should soon be forgotten after her death but that hopefully the organisations she worked for and helped to establish would survive. Not only have those organisations survived; they have flourished. As I said in my maiden speech, we ought to all remember the temporary nature of our tenure here and on this earth. Dame Marie Breen was only too well aware of that. Her contribution has remained and will continue in those organisations.

We remember Dame Marie as a woman of great character and achievement. From all we have heard about her tonight, she was a renaissance woman whose life was one of service to others. I am sure that all senators join me in extending our deepest condolences to Dame Marie's daughters—Jeannette; Pru, who was here earlier with her daughter; and Marie—and to other family members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to express my regrets at the passing of Dame Marie Breen, a Liberal senator for Victoria for six years from 1 July 1962 to 30 June 1968. She died on 17 June this year aged 91 and was, on anybody's reckoning, a very remarkable woman. She was nearly 60 when first elected to the Senate. She came into the Senate after the 1961 election. Honourable senators will recall that this election was a very narrow squeak for the then Menzies government. It was a very important time to be coming into politics.

PARA.TAB: Dame Marie retired at the end of her one six-year term to care for her husband, who had been severely injured some time earlier in an horrific accident. Very sadly, he died shortly after her retirement from the Senate. As Senator Kemp and others have mentioned, she was a very devoted carer for her husband during that very sad time.

I did not know Marie Breen closely. Indeed, I had not seen her for many years. However, I did have the privilege of knowing her a little during her term in the Senate. For almost two years of that period, I worked in the old Parliament House as the private secretary for the late Harold Holt and, subsequently, William McMahon. I recall that she was held in very high regard by her parliamentary colleagues and, very significantly, by those on both sides of politics.

Dame Marie had a very wide range of interests and experiences. She achieved a great deal at a time when it was extremely difficult for women to have access to public office. She was very heavily involved as an office-bearer in many family related and people related organisations—the Citizens Advice Bureau, the Church of England Marriage Guidance and Education Council, the Victorian baby health centres association and the Family Planning Association, to name but some of the more significant ones.

She was one of those Australians who took an early interest in developing Australia's relations with Asia. The current Prime Minister, Mr Keating, is busy attempting to rewrite history, implying that it has been only under his prime ministership and in recent years that Australia has discovered the significance of Asia. That, of course, is nonsense and people such as Marie Breen are a striking testimony to that.

Dame Marie was a member of the Australian Asia Association of Victoria for almost 20 years from as far back as 1956. She was Vice-President for most of that time. Indeed, she was chairman of the association's women's group from 1957 until she entered the Senate in 1962. Her chairmanship of that association's women's group was but part of her wider involvement with women's issues and movements. In particular, she was also President of the National Council of Women from 1954 to 1958. It was particularly her welfare work for women and children which led to her being honoured with the award of OBE in 1958 and, later in 1979, she was made a Dame of the British Empire, or DBE.

In this work for women and children, Dame Marie epitomised the true spirit of voluntarism. In an interview she gave just two or three years ago, she said, `It typifies the caring for each other that people need to express'. Much of this sort of spirit has been lost in the Australian community. Remembrance of Marie Breen is an important reminder to us of the significance of that spirit and activity of voluntarism.

Marie Breen lived a long and very full life of service to her family; to women and children; to our relations with Asia; and to the Liberal Party, for which she made an enormous contribution. Through all these groups she made a very significant contribution and gave a life of service to our nation. I join with other senators in extending my sympathy to her remaining family—her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. I hope that their undoubted cherished memories of Marie Breen and her very significant achievements will provide comfort for them at this time.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sir (Ernest) Edward `Weary' Dunlop AC, CMG, OBE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 2 July 1993 of Sir (Ernest) Edward `Weary' Dunlop AC, CMG, OBE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Friday 2 July 1993, of Sir (Ernest) Edward `Weary' Dunlop, AC CMG OBE, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent weeks all Australians have mourned the loss of Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. He was 85. Through his work as a surgeon in prisoner of war camps in Asia during the Second World War and his postwar work assisting veterans, Weary Dunlop, as he was universally known, was a figure not just honoured and revered but genuinely loved by his fellow Australians. I certainly feel privileged to have met and talked with him on several occasions over the past few years.

PARA.TAB: He was born into a farming family in northern Victoria in 1907. After an active and purportedly happy childhood, he gained qualifications in both pharmacy and medicine. His student days in Melbourne were full to the brim, as he was also a brilliant sportsman and became a champion at boxing and rugby union. He was in London undertaking postgraduate work in surgery when the war began. He loved his work, but the outbreak of war made life at St Mary's Hospital in Paddington seem like, as he said, a `charmed circle'. By pulling some strings, he managed to enlist in the 2nd AIF from London, and was posted directly to Jerusalem in November 1939 with the rank of captain.

During his two years in the Middle East his appetite for adventure meant that he was rarely far from the centre of action. He served in Libya, Greece and Crete, and volunteered for service with the 2/2 Australian Casualty Clearing Station in besieged Tobruk. He declined command of that unit, preferring to retain the surgical post of major. On his way back to Australia with the 7th Division, his ship was diverted to Java in a desperate bid to stem the Japanese move southward. He was taken prisoner of war in February 1942. He was moved to Batavia, Singapore, and finally to Konyu camp, along the route of the now notorious Burma-Thailand railway.

At Konyu and at further camps along the line, Dunlop and his fellow prisoners faced some of the most appalling conditions ever experienced by Australians at war. Men were daily forced out to work, clearing the jungle to make way for the railway. Malaria, dysentery, tropical ulcers, cholera and beri-beri were all common, exacerbated by malnutrition and brutal punishment by Japanese and Korean guards.

Time and again Dunlop intervened to stop desperately sick men being forced to work. He fashioned surgical instruments and equipment out of whatever was at hand and operated on his patients by oil light. He used all his wiles to obtain food and drugs. He saw his men out in the morning and was there to greet them when they arrived back exhausted at night. He was often sick himself and was punished and three times threatened with execution for his intercessions on behalf of the sick. Although forbidden to do so, he kept a radio and a detailed diary.

His experience as a prisoner fostered in him insights into humanity that shaped the rest of his life. In his diary he allowed himself only snatches of despair and ill-feeling towards the Japanese. In May 1943 he admitted to a `searing hate' arising in him whenever he saw a Japanese. He was as capable of hatred as he was of love, but ultimately he could not suppress a deep compassion from developing for the Japanese when he understood the wretchedness of their position by the end of the war. At the end of his war diary he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: This has been a war against monstrous things, but one for which we all share responsibility because of the selfish pre-occupations which allowed matters to reach such hideous proportions.

Sir Edward resolved then to make the welfare of ex-prisoners of war a life-long mission. In the postwar years, as he rose to prominence as a surgeon in Melbourne, he was tireless in the service of his former comrades, once again intervening on their behalf whenever he could. Remarkably, he lacked any sense of bitterness or desire for recrimination against the Japanese. Instead, he set about promoting links between Australia and Asia, and with Japan in particular. He was active in the health programs sponsored under the Colombo Plan, initiated by Australia in 1950 to promote cooperation with and assistance to South East Asia. In 1969 he led an Australian medical team into South Vietnam to provide care for civilians injured in the war.

PARA.TAB: Honours were heaped upon him in Australia and overseas, particularly in Thailand and Sri Lanka. He was made a knight bachelor in 1969, Australian of the Year in 1976 and a Companion of the Order of Australia in 1987.
