Through it all he remained essentially a very humble man and, like many ex-service people, not very comfortable in talking about his wartime experiences.

In the tributes that have been paid to him since his death, so many people have remembered his unfailing ability to see some good in everyone, including his enemies. It was that ability that drove his courage, his sense of duty and his capacity to forgive. With his great love and understanding of humanity, Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop will be very sadly missed. On behalf of the government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the opposition with this condolence motion for Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. In July we saw the death of quite a remarkable Australian; one of the great Australians of our lifetime. He was born in Victoria 85 years ago of Scottish extraction and through his life he exhibited all the great virtues of his forebears.

PARA.TAB: He became a pharmacist and rapidly moved on to study medicine at the University of Melbourne, where he graduated with first class honours in 1934. He was not only a brilliant scholar, as Senator Evans has said, but he was also a brilliant sportsman. As well as being the heavyweight boxing champion for the University of Melbourne, he represented Australia playing rugby union with the Wallabies against the old enemy, the All Blacks. It is not unusual to find people in medicine who have a brilliant scholastic career and are brilliant at rugby as well.

After graduation he travelled to the United Kingdom because he wanted to be a specialist surgeon. He enrolled at St Bartholomew's Hospital, in London. Within 10 weeks he was admitted as a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. To be admitted as a fellow today would take something like seven years. It is just a measure of how times have changed that the period taken at that time was so short.

After becoming a specialist surgeon he taught at the British postgraduate medical school at Hammersmith and was appointed as a specialist surgeon at St Mary's Hospital in Paddington. I do not suppose that that collection of Victorian red brick buildings in Praed Street today is any different in appearance from what it was when he was appointed to the staff there in the late 1930s.

He was with some very distinguished company there, including the head of the surgical unit, Arthur Porritt, who was a New Zealander. He was a sprinter in the Olympic Games in 1928, and later became Sir Arthur Porritt. He was President of the Royal College of Surgeons when I was living in England and knew him. He later became Governor-General of New Zealand.

Probably the most famous person there at the time was Alexander Fleming, who discovered the bacteriocidal effects of penicillin. Through the war years the pharmacological application of this discovery was developed by Sir Howard Florey, from Adelaide, and the world gained one of its greatest chemotherapeutic agents.

The outbreak of the war found Sir Edward wanting to enlist in the 2nd AIF. In his autobiography he said that he had some delay before he could enlist because there were no facilities for him to enlist from London. Nevertheless his service number was VX259. So the delay must have been measured in hours or at most one or two days; it certainly it did not run to many months. When people enlisted in the 2nd AIF they were given a number serially for each state—V was for Victoria and Q was for Queensland. His number of VX259 meant that he would have been the 259th person who enlisted from Victoria. There would not have been too much of a time delay there in the process.

He was a captain in the Australian Army Medical Corps before he went to England. It was as a medical officer that he joined the 2nd AIF at Palestine in the Middle East. He served in the ill-fated campaigns in Greece and Crete and was in Tobruk. He sailed with the first Australian corps to, firstly, Sumatra and then to Java. It was in Java in 1942 that he was captured and he spent the rest of the war as a POW. He started off as a captain and at the time of capture he was a lieutenant-colonel. He was promoted to colonel but he refused to accept the rank at the time because it meant that he would have been separated from his troops.

That led to the legendary part of his career. He was a senior army officer and as such he was not only medical officer to the prisoners but also a camp commandant. After the war he pursued his surgical career with great success not only in Victoria but in Australia. His postwar career was marked by an involvement to the full in public affairs; he did what he could for the community in whatever ways were open to him.

He was very active in promoting international relations, particularly with Asian countries and the South East Asian region. There has been quite a degree of distortion about our history promulgated in recent years, that somehow or other Australian interest in Asia goes back only two or three years. Nothing could be further from the truth. Dick Casey and Spender developed the Colombo Plan under the Menzies prime ministership. We heard on an earlier condolence motion the involvement of Dame Marie Breen in this. Right from the early part of the Colombo Plan and the Australian involvement in Asia, Sir Edward Dunlop was doing what he could visiting those countries, teaching and developing good relations with the regional states in Asia.

His principal concern was the welfare of the veterans, the ex-POWs in particular, who served with him in prison camps. In his treatment of and concern for the welfare of those people he demonstrated that great compassion and that ability to look forward, to not carry a grudge and to avoid the corrosive effects of hate in his life. He bore no enmity at all for his previous captors.

I would like to dwell for a moment on his time as a prisoner of war because, as I said, he was not only a medical officer looking after prisoners; he was also the commandant of a camp. He worked tirelessly, although he was sick and malnourished himself, and with great courage looking after the men under his command. One of the characteristics of the incarceration of the Australians and all the allied prisoners who suffered under the Japanese was that they were subject to brutal attacks by their guards. One of the procedures adopted by those of senior rank, whether corporals, sergeants or officers, was that when the privates were being bashed by the guards—as they frequently were—the person of superior rank would stand in and take the bashing for them. Weary Dunlop did this on innumerable occasions as a colonel. It is also a matter of record that, on several occasions, he was sentenced to death by the Japanese and his execution was stayed only at the last moment.

The camp of which he was the commanding officer was characterised by having one of the lowest death rates of all the large camps in Thailand. Dunlop himself explained that that was not because of the medical skill that he and the other medical officers in the camp possessed and delivered to the troops under their command. He explained it on the basis of leadership and he did that in a very self-effacing way. It was true.

Leadership today is a very undervalued commodity in contemporary Australian society. It is not absent from society but it is relatively rare; it is relatively scarce. What we have in this country today is a collection of what could best be described as managers, not leaders, in so many levels of human activity. They are worried about getting things done without a fuss and they are worried about the bottom line. There is not the respect nor the reward for leadership that there should be in this country. There is very little understanding of its value. Those attributes of leadership—dedication; energy; knowledge of what needs to be done; devotion to the cause; ability to comfort and cosset those they are leading; ability to inspire those they are leading to rise to achievements that they would not normally attain; selflessness; preferment of the interests of those they lead before their own, even to the extent of laying their own lives on the line—are the qualities that Weary Dunlop had in abundance.

All of those qualities today, of course, are in contrast to the teaching of contemporary sociologists. They do not fit in in a country where human relations are run under the aegis of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission because it sees leadership as being elitist and authoritarian. Leadership, as Dunlop demonstrated, does not diminish anyone's human rights in any way at all; in fact, it enriches them. It is an essential attribute for a country to possess. It should be evident at all levels in society. Society is not great because of a prime minister or a president. A society is great because the community works together for common goals and because it stays together in small, cohesive units, all led by someone who is a leader of that small group.

The great achievements of the Australian Defence Force turn on the leadership that it has possessed over the years. Maybe we have paid too high a price in the wars we have been involved in, principally the First World War and the Second World War where we had very high casualty rates, where so many leaders were killed—both officers and NCOs. Those with superior rank in the Australian Defence Force always led by example, whether they were corporals or colonels.

Our army history is replete with examples where company commanders were killed and platoon commanders took over the company; where platoon commanders were killed and sergeants or corporals took over; where section commanders were killed and privates led the section. I hope that as a nation we can draw inspiration from Dunlop's life and the leadership that he showed his fellow Australians—he was the personification of great leadership attributes.

TAB.TAB: I was surprised at the public response to Weary Dunlop's death. I had the privilege of meeting him on only one occasion some years ago and had a long talk with him. I read his book when it was published and I have read a large number of articles about him. But the response of the Australian community was absolutely unrehearsed. It was a natural and an overwhelming expression of admiration for this man and his life. It was not developed in any way at all by any special interest groups, least of all by the government, and yet the media were totally dominated by his death for days afterwards. Those of us who were in St Paul's Cathedral in Melbourne for that huge funeral service will never forget the tangible expression from ordinary Australians—the expression of respect for, and admiration of, his life.

PARA.TAB: I draw a great deal of comfort from the public response to Weary Dunlop's death. It was the voice of the silent majority of Australia—the silent majority which is normally never heard. People were moved out of respect for this man and the work of his life. I hope it is a sign that this country is growing up and maturing, that the buccaneers of the stock exchange or the commercial world and the Ned Kellys are no longer taken as the heroes of this country, and that this country recognises real worth in human character. If we all keep the example of his life before us, I am sure that this country will be a much better place for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to extend my deepest sympathies to Sir Edward Dunlop's family and join in the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). The passing of Sir Edward has been mourned by all Australians. He was a great man, a hero, and his tremendous courage, valour and endurance provide an inspiration for us all.

PARA.TAB: Sir Edward Dunlop—surgeon, soldier, scholar and sportsman—was a brilliant and abundantly gifted man who excelled in each of these roles, yet always remained self-effacing about his many achievements. One of his greatest achievements—and certainly that for which he is renowned and revered—was the unfaltering and superb leadership he provided for his fellow POWs during his incarceration in Japanese prison camps for the latter half of the Second World War.

For a surgeon who had dedicated his entire existence to the healing and preservation of human life, the unbearable human suffering endemic in the camps could have made him collapse into hopeless despair. However, due to his remarkable reserves of inner strength and endurance, Sir Edward was able to bear the unbearable; indeed, he became the rock on which his fellow captives leant.

Sir Edward's surgical skills saved hundreds of lives; his personal courage saved countless more. Many times he put his own life on the line to save sick and dying men. His leadership abilities enabled him to introduce some degree of organisation and order to the wretched chaos that had previously prevailed in the camps.

Of the 22,000 Australians who became Japanese prisoners of war, perhaps in some respect the ones who fell under his command could consider themselves more fortunate than the others. He was indeed, as a fellow POW, Donald Stuart, put it, `a lighthouse of sanity in a universe of madness and suffering'.

Sir Edward began his brilliant career as a pharmacist but further study led him to qualify in medicine and surgery in 1934. He joined the army in 1939 at the outbreak of the war and served as a medical officer in Jerusalem, Greece, Crete, Tobruk and Java. When Java fell, he remained with his hospital and served as both commanding officer and chief medical officer in POW camps in Java, Changi and on the horrific Burma-Thai railway line.

In the postwar years, Sir Edward put his traumatic POW experiences behind him and was able to offer his medical expertise in treating tropical diseases as a member of the Australian surgical team in South Vietnam in 1969. In his latter years, Sir Edward concentrated on his twin missions to provide support for Australian veterans and to foster good relations and exchanges of learning and skills with Japan and other neighbouring Asian nations. He dedicated many years service to the ex-prisoners of war and relatives associations as well as serving as a Colombo Plan

SPEECH.PARA: adviser to Thailand, Sri Lanka and India. He was president of the Victorian branch of the Australian-Asian Association and patron of the Australian-Thailand Association and the Sri Lankan Association of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Sir Edward was a much deserved Australian of the Year in 1977 in recognition of this tireless humanitarian work. The publications of his war diaries in 1986 was not an attempt to reopen old wounds, but, rather, to put a new complexion on what he went through. His hatred had long since died and he had been able to find forgiveness for his captors. The diaries were to be a tribute to the men who languished under the incessant spectre of death, disease, starvation and torture, with the hope that as long as this dreadful history is remembered it will never be repeated.

It is a great honour to join in this condolence motion for such a heroic, noble and courageous man. He will be remembered personally by thousands of people whose lives he touched and by millions more who knew of him by reputation for his sterling conduct and unfailing humanity both during and after the war. He will be in our memories for as long as we continue to honour our heroes; to honour those with strength of character, mind and spirit as well as the strength to forgive the unforgivable. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending our sympathy to Sir Edward's family and many friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I wish to join in this condolence motion to the family of Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. Truly great Australians are rare enough, great humanitarians are even rarer and Sir Edward Dunlop was both. Weary Dunlop's achievements in helping his fellow Australians in time of war are well known to most of us. Sir Edward will also be remembered for his work for the survivors of war and their families and for his medical contributions to nations across Asia. In the last couple of lines of his war diaries, he says:

PARA.TAB: There will be strenuous and exciting days working to get the last of these maimed as damaged men on their way home.
I have resolved to make their care and welfare a life-long mission.

SPEECH.PARA: He never let them down. Regardless of whether it was in sport, medical science, our defence forces or in Australia's regional relations, Sir Edward made a memorable and enduring contribution to this country and by all accounts impressed all those with whom he came into contact.

PARA.TAB: We have heard how Sir Edward came to be a prisoner of war in 1942. His physical strength and fitness, his training as a surgeon, his knowledge of men, his ability to lead and inspire others to follow—which is probably more important—to deal with his captors and to organise the foul disease-ridden camps the Australians found themselves in were remarkable qualities which he displayed during this time. The unbelievable horror of those times lives today in the pages of the war diaries of Weary Dunlop. They are certainly emotionally moving and, at the same time, they are immensely inspiring.

I believe what comes to us in the war diaries is a demonstration of his extraordinary courage and his remarkable tact and skill in getting the best for his men under what surely must be the most horrendous of conditions. He shows us the love and loyalty which obviously existed between him and Helen Ferguson, whom he married after the war, and also his wonderful sense of humour and most obvious charm. All of this inspired devotion in friends, colleagues, acquaintances and indeed many people throughout Australia and South-East Asia.

After the war, of course, his service to others was evident in all that he was involved in. His own medical practice in Melbourne, where he managed to combine a continuing and devoted care and concern for all his comrades of the war camps, was one such example. His involvement in the development of Australia's role in the Colombo Plan was another. He lectured, taught and operated in Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India, and thereafter never stopped working for closer relations with our neighbour nations to the north.

Few Australians have been as active or as committed in promoting the exchange of knowledge, skills and culture with Asian countries and none as honoured as Weary Dunlop was in return by Asian nations. It is people like Sir Edward Weary Dunlop that inspire us and teach us. His nobility of character and his dedication to others set him apart as a true Australian hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the six weeks that have passed since the death of Sir Edward Dunlop, much has been said and repeated of his early life, his academic career, his unique enlistment through Australia House, London, after the declaration of war, his distinguished war service and his extraordinary skills and courage under appalling conditions as a prisoner of war. I would like to join other senators in expressing the feelings of all Australians who knew Sir Edward Dunlop, or knew of him.

PARA.TAB: Weary Dunlop was gifted in his profession and embodied qualities of selflessness, love, compassion, courage, leadership and, above all, humility. He was also a man of remarkable intellectual breadth. The opening paragraph of the preface to Sir Edward's war diaries—and it took some 40 years of persuasion before he agreed to their publication—reflects his humility:

SPEECH.PARA: I have shrunk from publishing these diaries for over forty years. It seemed they might add further suffering to those bereaved, and add to controversy and hatred. What at the time was maintained simply as a military duty was in no sense designed for publication or to have any literary merit.
The very last sentence of the diaries, written on 16 August 1945 when survivors were preparing for repatriation, says:
I have resolved to make their care and welfare a life-long mission.
This resolve of Sir Edward never diminished over the 48 postwar years that he lived so fully.

PARA.TAB: On his return to Australia, he rose to great eminence in his surgical career. Senator Evans and others referred to his work in education, in forging links and exchanging skills and culture with Asian nations. Many richly deserved national and international honours have been bestowed on Sir Edward over the years. Despite all these commitments and his patronage of, or participation in, some 40 organisations, he was not diverted from that resolution to make the care and welfare of his fellow prisoners of war a lifelong mission. An article in the news bulletin of the Ex-Prisoners of War and Relatives Association published in July, after his death, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Weary's determination to fulfil that promise to his P.O.W. mates had not diminished in interest, nor wanted in its sincerity in all that time. No ex-P.O.W. or widow was ever turned away, and there would be thousands today who would testify to that and agree that their present position physically and financially is due to the sincere interest displayed in their cause by "Weary".

My department has been assisted in its charter over the years by having the advocacy of Sir Edward Dunlop on behalf of veterans. He willingly participated in many joint committees of veterans organisations and the department, as well as making representations on behalf of many in need.

PARA.TAB: As Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I had the opportunity to work with him for only a few months. However, it gives me a great deal of personal satisfaction that I met him at my first formal meeting with the officials of the major ex-service organisations in Victoria only a month before he died. I will certainly remember that occasion. In a room of very prominent Australians, Weary Dunlop exuded the presence that speaks of a very great man.

His association with my department will live on through the Sir Edward Dunlop Medical Research Foundation. In his later years Sir Edward made representations based on his view that insufficient medical research had been devoted to the needs of ageing veterans; research which, in his vision, would subsequently benefit the ageing population in our community at large. His vision was taken up with my department by the Veterans Affairs Coordinating Council of Organisations in Victoria. This resulted in the incorporation of the Sir Edward Dunlop Medical Research Foundation as a public company in May 1987.

The work to establish the foundation, which has a national role in funding research, was a joint venture between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the ex-service organisations in Victoria. Although the foundation operates independently of the department, I would point out that accommodation and administrative support are provided by the department in furthering the foundation's work. The main aim of the foundation, endorsed by Sir Edward, is:

SPEECH.PARA: To do and undertake all things necessary for, or tending toward or likely to promote, the maintenance and improvement of the medical and similar care of veterans and their dependants, their health and general welfare.
In accepting the request to be patron of the foundation, Sir Edward wrote on 6 June 1985:

I feel very honoured indeed that you should seek permission to name the foundation "The Sir Edward Dunlop Medical Research Foundation". Whilst feeling in no way worthy of this signalisation, I am of course very anxious to be associated with any measures which will add something to the care of veterans.

Like everything else that he did in his life, Sir Edward followed through. He was a very active patron and frequently attended meetings of the board of directors to advise, to suggest and to support. In fact, he attended a meeting of the board only one week before his death. While he would personally seek no overt recognition, I am sure there can be no more fitting and lasting memorial to Sir Edward Dunlop than a medical research foundation bearing his name.

PARA.TAB: Sir Edward's memory will live on in the minds and hearts of many Australians who have been touched in some way by his life's work. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will be proud to play its part by continuing to provide the support the foundation needs to carry on the work that he resolved would be his lifelong mission. We have lost a truly great Australian in Weary Dunlop. I join other honourable senators in extending my deepest sympathy to his family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join the condolence motion moved by Senator Evans and supported by other colleagues in the Senate. Every nation has its heroes, but few have one of the calibre of Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. As someone said, there might be some that were equal but none better. His approach to the deprivation that was the lot of prisoners of war throughout South-East Asia in World War II was typical of his whole approach to life itself.

PARA.TAB: Weary Dunlop was a man of great dedication. I saw a little of this when, as a Queenslander who had moved to Melbourne, I was a student at Melbourne University where Weary Dunlop himself had studied medicine and acquired his questionable nickname. Honourable senators will probably be aware that nicknames in years gone by were a common practice and the name developed from Dunlop Tyres, hence Weary Dunlop.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say, having known the man, that somehow either the man fitted the nickname or the nickname fitted the man; I am not too sure. It is to his honour that the ethics and standards he set for his fellow men have now made that rather nonsensical whimsical nickname a very revered title in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Like Weary, I also played rugby union at Melbourne University although, unlike him, I never made it as an Australian representative against the New Zealand All Blacks. But as patron of the Melbourne University rugby union club, Weary Dunlop made it a practice to attend a match every Saturday. While he was marching up and down the sidelines in the wet winters of Melbourne, in that dreary drizzle—I can say that now, having gone back to Queensland—we could hear the thundering crowds at the MCG attending that other game. But there would be the tall, lanky figure of Weary Dunlop cheering on the Melbourne University side.

In fact, he was there on a day when I was injured. When I came off the field with what looked like a pretty serious injury he looked at me and said, `I'm going to have to take you to the Royal Melbourne Hospital, give you an anaesthetic and fix that up. But, meanwhile, stay with me and watch the end of the game'. So Weary and I plodded up and down the sidelines for about another 35 minutes and he then took me off to the Royal Melbourne Hospital.

I can remember it well because when I arrived a female anaesthetist—this is not a sexist comment in any way—said to me, `When did you last have a meal?'. I have forgotten the exact answer that I gave, but she said, `Sorry, Dr Dunlop, you can't operate for another two hours'. To a man who had been on the Burma railway, using jam tin lids to amputate limbs with or without anaesthetic, this was a bit rich. I can remember his saying to this anaesthetist, `Doctor, every time you give an anaesthetic it is a crisis in your life. Give him the pentothal now'. So they put me straight onto the anaesthetic.

Subsequently, he asked me to come to his home where he could check his work to see whether it had been successful. I can remember spending a very pleasant afternoon with him and his wife, Helen, in their Toorak Road house in Melbourne. In fact, it was there that I learnt that his wife had come from the city of Toowoomba in Queensland.

I was one of those people who had the rare privilege of crossing the path of one such as Weary Dunlop. So it was a pleasure for me that I was able to renew his acquaintance right here in 1988 at the opening of the new Parliament House. I think it was fitting that a man of such distinction should have been present at such an event.

I attended the opening of the new Parliament House with my three sons and of course, as everyone would know, there were a lot of very prominent figures promenading in the Great Hall. But it was interesting that the only person my sons wanted to meet was Weary Dunlop. I think it said a lot for the man that in this day and age young men of 17, 18 and 19, upon seeing all of those great figures in the Great Hall, said, `Look, Dad, all we want to do is meet Weary Dunlop. We understand that you know him'.

Notwithstanding the cruelty and suffering that Weary Dunlop incurred as a POW, when the war was over not only did he not harbour any hatred or have any desire to carry out a campaign of retribution but he forgave his enemies. He went out of his way to befriend the Japanese who, only a few short years earlier, had inflicted such incredible cruelty not only upon him but also upon his close mates on the Burma railway. That, I think, reflected the man.

It was a privilege and an honour for me to have known this great Australian. Australia is very much richer because of his life. Weary Dunlop should serve as a role model for all Australians because he had the secret of happiness. For those who do not know it, the secret of happiness is giving and not taking. And that was the secret of Weary Dunlop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the condolence motion for Sir Ernest Edward `Weary' Dunlop. Many people of my generation did not have the opportunity to meet Weary Dunlop. As I discovered after his death, some Australians who were captured by the Japanese and survived the war had not met him either—but, almost invariably, they knew of him and how he had assisted so many held captive during World War II. He was a remarkable man not only during the war but also during peace.

PARA.TAB: I consider myself fortunate to have met him, even if it were only once. It was a quite recent meeting. In April this year I was transiting through Bangkok on my way to India when I saw him in the Bangkok airport; he and I had been on the same flight from Sydney. I took the opportunity to introduce myself and told him that I was pleased to be able to speak to a living legend. We had a short conversation and then went our separate ways. Neither of us were to know that, in a few short months, crowds would gather in Melbourne to pay their last respects to this truly remarkable Australian.

I had the honour to represent the Senate at Weary Dunlop's funeral in Melbourne. The cathedral was packed and thousands were gathered outside. The Reverend Canon Albert McPherson succinctly described the reason why so many had gathered to pay their respects. In part, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We come together to mourn the passing of Ernest Edward `Weary' Dunlop: to give thanks for his life; to acknowledge his many services in peace and in war to this nation and this state; and to express our sympathy to his family and those many people who deeply mourn his passing.

As I left the cathedral after the casket was carried to a gun carriage, I was aware that Australia was the poorer for Weary Dunlop's passing. But to put those feelings in a more positive light, Australia was certainly richer for having Weary as one of its citizens.

PARA.TAB: Much has already been said about Weary Dunlop this evening, and it is not necessary for me to repeat those comments. I do, however, extend my condolences to Weary's family. If it helps at all, they should know that their sorrow over their loss was shared by hundreds of thousands of their fellow Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with all previous tributes about Weary. I think the point about Weary that has not been brought out was his essential humility. I think it was that humility that made everybody who had any contact with him fond of him and not feel threatened by his demeanour.

PARA.TAB: Weary was a wonderful character. In his honour I am wearing the tie of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons of which he was one of our most famous members. He annually attended the scientific congress to keep abreast of things; even as late as last year he attended it and gave us his wisdom, but always in a deprecating way. Senator Boswell has alluded to the fact that he was also a distinguished fellow of the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, and he maintained that membership throughout his life.

In addition to Weary Dunlop's humility, he had a great sense of humour. I was once sitting next to him at a conference and said to him, `Weary, as you get older, do you find your progress impeded in relation to your activities?'. Weary said, `Well, I am reminded of a fellow I was sitting next to at a dinner in London who called himself the Lord Privy Seal. The funny thing about him was that he was neither a privy nor a seal'. Weary added `But I said to him, "Lord Privy Seal, how do you find things as you get a bit older?". The peer said to me that he had been sitting next to some lady at a dinner one night and this lady had asked him the very same question: "How do you get on as you get a bit older?" The peer told me that he had said to the lady, "Well, my dear, as I get a bit older, I find that I am losing touch with my limbs". She said, "My Lord, if it is any consolation to you, the limb that you are losing touch with at the moment is not your own".' That was Weary; he was a wonderful character.

He dedicated his life based upon what had occurred to him in the prison camps, but he did it in a self-effacing way. He became loved by everybody with whom he came in contact—and I think that was due to the essential humility he displayed in everything he did. He passes on now. He left a legacy behind that is an inspiration, as Senator Parer said, to the young men of this country. He did what he could, as a good doctor does today, despite the denigration of his profession. Despite that denigration, there are literally thousands out there who are doing the same today—and they should not be denigrated by those who seek to make political capital out of them. Weary deprecated that trend too in many conversations I had with him. In many respects I thought in this context of the film Chariots of Fire which many honourable senators will have seen.

Weary Dunlop had a wonderful life. He was an inspiration to many. While we mourn his passing, we pay tribute to a great man. I join with all others in offering my condolences to the members of his family who are left behind—as we know, his wife predeceased him. He leaves a great legacy to his children—his sons in particular—and to his grandchildren which will be an inspiration to many future generations of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this place for the first time since my departure in 1990. Being one of the last speakers for the evening, I wish to offer my heartfelt condolences today at the death of Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. Like others who have spoken here this evening, I stood with many thousands of Australians at St Paul's Cathedral in July to pay tribute to the late Sir Weary Dunlop. Like others, I was acquainted—albeit fleetingly—with Sir Weary, having met and spoken with him on several occasions at several functions and having exchanged correspondence with him from time to time. But ours was not to the extent of Senator Parer's acquaintance, which goes back many years.

PARA.TAB: The reason I rise to speak tonight is that my generation was fortunate enough not to be called to arms. We were not called to serve in many of the great conflicts that have scarred the 20th century. Not having been called, as were Sir Weary Dunlop and his comrades, it is nevertheless our duty to remember the deeds and the actions of those who gave so much for our country. My generation is duty-bound to remember, to recall and to bring to life in the present the experience of the past.

As evidenced by today's condolences, the Australian nation is engaged by Sir Weary Dunlop as it has seldom been by any other public figure. There was, after all, something in the essence of the man—some constant value—that touched all Australians across all spectrums of life. Like others who have spoken before me today, I do not find it hard to isolate those very values. The public record boasts of a life lived to the full, and there are few distinctions and honours achievable which eluded the man.

Finally, there was something else in Weary Dunlop that I believe drew people towards him and kindled their confidence and enveloped their trust. There were many sides to the man. To my mind, his capacity to appeal to such a wide cross-section of society was based on his very Australianness. He embodied all the qualities that Australians aspire to and share in to differing degrees.

These seem to be days of doubt and confusion as to what we mean by our `national identity'. Increasingly, we seem to be questioning what it is that we stand for and what qualities we ought to hold up before the world. This is a wasted feeling, and wholly unnecessary when we look at figures such as Weary Dunlop who selflessly expressed the simple but hard-won values of the past. Weary Dunlop reminds us that we must not sever the long line of collective national experience which marks the men and women of the nation and stamps the traits of the nation.

Weary Dunlop was a bridge to the past. Weary Dunlop's legacy is more than just his personal heroism and private qualities. He was a constant reminder that in this nation's history can be found all the sources of inspiration and values that any nation needs to define its place in the world.

At St Paul's Cathedral, when we mourned the passing of Weary Dunlop, we grieved for the passing of an era, for a loss of the past. We grieved for the man but the national hurt was even more than that. It was a sense of dislocation from our past that swallowed us up, the sense that something precious from our history was gone forever. Australia needed Sir Edward Weary Dunlop. It needed him to sustain the links with the nation's history, to keep alive the great continuity of nationhood which links one generation to another and which moulds us together as a people.

Like Weary Dunlop, so much of the Australian character was forged in war. The better qualities of his nature, like those of Australia, represent a triumph over suffering and adversity. This is remembered by the nation when it recalls the Gallipoli campaign, the approaching 75th anniversary of the western front campaigns, and equally its modern day hero such as the VC recipient `Dasher' Wheatley. This has been the Australian story and one which should be renewed for every generation.

Weary himself saw to that. I recall an incident at the Canberra airport some years ago. He was in his early eighties at that time and a small girl, approximately eight or nine years old, approached him through the crowded airport simply for an autograph. Weary cheerfully obliged, so his story and the story of his generation was passed on to the newest of Australia's generation. We have to hold on to the memory of Weary Dunlop in the same way that we have to hold on to the memory of our past.

This is not empty nostalgia or misplaced melancholy for some bygone era, nor is it an empty romance. If we are searching around for embodiments of values, we need not invent an image of ourselves or adapt some contrived bureaucratic self-perception. We only need to go back to our roots and our origins. If we are lost and thrashing around to affirm our identity, it is only because we have stopped remembering or else we have swallowed some national lie about ourselves which has written the likes of Sir Weary Dunlop out of our history. To this end, I honour Sir Edward Weary Dunlop and extend my condolences to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many of my colleagues I, too, would like to pay my deepest respects and express my deepest sympathy to his family at the passing of Sir Edward Dunlop known, I think universally, as `Weary' Dunlop. I only had the privilege of meeting him on rare occasions over the last 20 years or so, but at all times in the presence of Weary Dunlop one really did have the feeling of being in the presence of a quite remarkable, inspirational and yet essentially very humble man.

PARA.TAB: His achievements—one only has to look in the Who's Who or know anything about him—were absolutely enormous right throughout his very long life and right across a very wide range of fields. It was that inspirational quality about him and that essential humility in the face of adversity, stress, punishment and crimes perhaps of the worst nature that brought him to attention, but he really had a much wider life than that.

I, like Senator McGauran and some of my other colleagues, had the tremendous experience—I think I would call it that—of being at his funeral. It was an experience that really got to you, partly because of the huge crowd that was there. People spilled over the intersection of Flinders and Swanston Streets. There were many thousands of people outside on a cold, bleak day. Of course, St Paul's Cathedral itself was overflowing. The whole atmosphere of the funeral service, despite the size, was very much in keeping with the character of Sir Edward.

What really impressed everyone there was the speech by Sir Ninian Stephen, who delivered the main eulogy. I would like to read into the record of the Senate some of the things that Sir Ninian said of Weary Dunlop because I think they epitomise what all of us here and the nation as a whole feel about him. Right at the start Sir Ninian said:

SPEECH.PARA: All are here to pay tribute to Sir Edward, to express their sorrow at his passing, their deep respect for the man, their high admiration for his achievements and their sense of loss in his death. In doing so they represent the feelings of the millions of Australians and of countless admirers overseas.
Sir Ninian went on to say:

In this present age there is a dearth of heroes. And it is as a hero that we remember Weary Dunlop. He was virtuous, kind and immensely brave, utterly steadfast in the path of duty and invincible in his courage.

For all his life was a quiet triumph, every test he put himself to, he passed; every task he set himself he fulfilled. As sportsman on the rugby field, as boxer in the ring, as surgeon, as soldier, as loving husband and father and as honoured friend to very many.
With perhaps only Douglas Mawson, of all Australians, he shares a lone eminence of sustained heroism and superb achievement.
His long life was an inspiration to us all. In death the inspiration remains, inspiring us to try as best we may to follow his example of courageous and unflagging nobility.
Bitterness never entered his soul, for he knew its corroding influence and forthrightly rejected it.
He was loved and respected at a distance by millions and intimately by his family and those fortunate enough to be his dear friends, themselves many thousands at home and overseas.

It is lives such as his that teach us that man can aspire to and achieve true nobleness of character and by doing so can inspire us all; Weary Dunlop would have been surprised to hear himself described as saintly, but to many his dedication to all that was good and his own sheer nobility of character seemed saintly; they set him apart, although he would have laughed and gently teased whoever told him that.
Sir Ninian concluded by saying:

His death does not leave us the poorer; instead, because it concentrates our thoughts on him and on his life and example we are enriched and inspired. If we cannot emulate him, his great gifts of mind and of character eluding us, we can at least try to guide our actions by the pre-eminent standards that he made his own and by which we will remember him.

I am pleased to have those words in the record of this parliament because I think they reflect very accurately the life of a very great Australian. Through that life, he was not just inspirational. His achievements and the nature of the man will guide us all in an inspirational way for many years to come. We are the poorer for his passing, of course, but we will be even poorer if we forget the standards and the great virtues that he stood for and lived by.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have received letters from the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate seeking a variation to the membership of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht)—by leave—agreed to:

That Senator Tierney be discharged from further attendance on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and that Senator Colston and Senator Troeth, having been duly nominated in accordance with standing order 24, be appointed as members of the committee.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That, as a mark of respect to the memory of the deceased, the Senate do now adjourn.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the report by the Australian Film Commission (AFC), Reassessment of Funding Priorities for Cultural Activities in which the AFC recognised a priority to fund a series of developmental initiatives in Queensland, is there a commitment on the part of the AFC to increase the industry and cultural development funding to Queensland; if so, is there an adequate budget allocation set aside for such a purpose, as requested in a letter to the AFC dated 26 November 1992 from representatives of the major Brisbane-based film culture and film support organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Film Commission's (AFC) reassessment of funding priorities for cultural activities carried out in 1992 identified a need to redress film support to Queensland.

The AFC does not have the financial flexibility to allocate the amount requested in the letter of 26 November 1992 from the major Brisbane-based film culture and support organisations. As a matter of policy, a proposal of this kind would require substantial development by the applicant and analysis by the AFC before any decision to provide support is taken. The applicant would be required to provide a detailed outline of the project, including the proposed budget. Information about the aims and objectives of the organisation, management and financial structures and program delivery strategies would also be required.

However, there have been funds earmarked to begin a process aimed at assisting organisations in determining the most appropriate way to share limited resources, to reduce duplication of administrative structures and to establish a structure which will assist in establishing and maintaining a strong, vital film culture for Queensland. It is envisaged that both the AFC and the Queensland Film Development Office will have input into the process and that possible long term funding will be considered in this context.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department; and how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister; if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department does circulate media releases for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to organisations apart from national media organisations.

Media releases are distributed to ensure as wide a circulation as possible so that veterans, war widows, their families and carers are aware of any change to existing services or the introduction of new services.

Releases are circulated to national and local electronic and print media; to the veteran and support community through Ex-service organisations at national and state level only, and to their own publications; to Pensioner News, Senior Scene and other similar specialised papers, the medical and allied health community and any other target audience appropriate to the media release. Targeting varies according to the media release. For example, a release on a local Joint Ventures Scheme presentation may go only to the local media and ex-service community, whereas a release on a national Government program would be disseminated more widely.

(2) In the past 18 months, 125 Ministerial media releases were circulated. The estimated cost of printing and circulation was $8,400. The number of copies circulated for each release varied according to subject matter. In total, approximately 4,300 copies were distributed as part of the process described in part (1).
(3) In the past 18 months, the Department has circulated six of the Minister's major speeches. These were only circulated internally and costs were confined to photocopying.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 31 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What Commonwealth funding has been provided to each, and which, of the Central Trades Committees during 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93 and so far this financial year.
(2) For what reason is Commonwealth funding provided and what functions do the Central Trades Committees perform.
(3) What Commonwealth funding has been provided to the Local Trades Committees during 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93 and so far this financial year.
(4) For what reason is Commonwealth funding provided and what functions do the Local Trades Committees perform.

(5) What is the function of the National Labour Consultative Council, who are the members of the council, what organisations do they represent, and what Commonwealth funding has been provided to the Council in each of the past four financial years.

(6) What is the function of the Location of Australian Government Employment Committee, who are the members of the Committee, what organisations do they represent, and what Commonwealth funding has been provided to the Committee in each of the past four financial years.

(7) Which of the Work Place Resource Centres are companies limited by Commonwealth Guarantee, for each centre, what is the function, who are the members of the boards, what organisations do the members represent, and what Commonwealth funding has been provided in each of the past four financial years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no Commonwealth funding provided to Central Trades Committees.
(2) The functions of the Central Trades Committees are to:

establish standards, policies and procedures to ensure consistent and equitable decisions are made by Local Trades Committees in dealing with applications for Australian Recognised Trades Certificates;
establish recognition criteria;
consider applications for pre-migration assessments of trade skills from individuals whose training and employment experience does not meet established criteria;
determine eligibility for non-criteria countries;
provide an avenue for review of decisions; and
determine trade classifications to which the Act applies.
(3) There is no Commonwealth funding provided to Local Trades Committees.

(4) Local Trades Committees determine eligibility for recognition of trade skills, and issue Australian Recognised Trades Certificates where appropriate, to permanent Australian residents in the following groups;
migrants who have received formal or informal trade training overseas;
Australians who have gained their skills on-the-job and have not served an apprenticeship; and
members of the Australian Defence Forces who have received trade training while in service.

Local Trades Committees can also authorise the employment of probationary trades persons, and can refer any matter within their power and functions to the Central Trades Committees for decision and direction.

(5) The function of the National Labour Consultative Council is to provide a forum for the Commonwealth, employers and unions to consult on manpower and industrial relations matters of national concern. The members and the organisations they represent are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Hon Laurie Brereton MP—Minister for Industrial Relations (Chair)
Mr Peter Core—Secretary, Department of Industrial Relations

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI)

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Chris O'Malley—Catholic Church Insurance Pty Ltd
Mr Bill Powell—Printing and Allied Trades Employers' Association
Mr Karl Stewart—Mines and Metals Association
Mr Alex Stuart—Master Builders—Construction and Housing Association
Mr Bert Evans—Metal Trades Industry Association
Mr Noel Kimberley—Australian Road Transport Industrial Organisation
Mr Graeme Wheeler—Australian Chamber of Manufactures
Mr Jim Bacon—Tasmanian Trades and Labor Council
Mr Michael Easson—Labor Council of NSW

PARA.TAB: No funding has been provided to the National Labour Consultative Council by the Commonwealth. The Department of Industrial Relations provides administrative and secretariat services to the Council.
(6) The functions of the Location of Australian Government Employment Committee (LAGE) are,

ANSWER.PARA: on reference from the Government, to report and advise on:

PARA.TAB: proposals by departments and authorities, other than business and trading authorities, to relocate functions or positions;
the appropriate location of all newly-established or proposed Australian Government bodies; and
general matters relating to the location of Australian Government employment.

The Committee is required to have regard to Government policies, efficiency and economy in administration, impact on clients, staff and employment, consequential costs to the Commonwealth and others and accommodation and facilities availability in its consideration of proposed relocations.
Membership of the LAGE Committee comprises:
Departments of Industrial Relations (Chair), Arts and Administrative Services, Environment, Sport and Territories, Finance, Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Public Service Commission;
the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Public Sector Union and the Council of Professional Associations.
There has been no Commonwealth funding provided to the Location of Australian Government Employment Committee in the past four financial years.

(7) The seven Workplace Resource Centres which were established during 1989 and 1990 no longer exist. In 1992 they were amalgamated to form the Australian Centre for Best Practice Ltd (ACBP) which commenced operations on 1 July 1992 as a public company limited by guarantee incorporated under Corporations Law.
Commonwealth funding provided in each of the past four financial years is set out in the table below:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How long was Dr Anne Summers employed as an adviser to the Prime Minister prior to 13 March 1993 and what was her total salary during that period of employment.
(2) What was her home base for travel allowance purposes.
(3) How much travel allowance did she receive during that period in total and what was the daily rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Dr Anne Summers commenced employment as a Consultant to the Prime Minister on 2 June 1992 at an annual salary equivalent to that of a SES Band 3 Officer of the Australian Public Service (ie currently $88,620 pa).
(2) Dr Summers' home base for travel purposes was, from 2 June 1992 to 30 October 1992, Canberra and thereafter, Sydney.

(3) Dr Summers received travelling allowance payments totalling $16,915.39 during the period 2 June 1992 to 13 March 1993 for travel undertaken away from her home base. The daily rate of travelling allowance paid to Dr Summers was the same as that paid to SES Officers of the Australian Public Service and are set for each location visited. The current rates range between, for example, $206.25 in Sydney for each 24 hour absence from home base to $157.25 in Hobart.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How soon after the atomic bomb attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki did Australian servicemen enter these areas.
(2) How many Australian members of the British Commonwealth Occupational Force (BCOF) served in the Hiroshima and Nagasaki prefectures.
(3) How many Australian members of the BCOF were exposed, directly or indirectly, to atomic radiation while serving in Japan, and what levels of radiation were they exposed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1, 2 & 3) Australian servicemen attached to US units as specialists and advisers may have been at the site of the explosions shortly after the Japanese surrender. It would not be possible to determine the exact number without considerable research and I am not prepared to commit the resources necessary to compile this information.
Australian servicemen served with the BCOF in Japan from February 1946, ie six months after the atomic explosions at Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
There was a maximum of 12,000 Australian servicemen (Army and Air Force) with the BCOF at any one time.
Hiroshima was in an area where many Australian BCOF members served.
It is estimated that thousands of Australian BCOF members and their dependants visited Hiroshima and Nagasaki because the cities had become a tourist attraction.
The levels of exposure to nuclear radiation in and around Hiroshima and Nagasaki at that time, and the numbers of Australian Service personnel exposed, cannot be determined with accuracy.

For the honourable senator's information, the Australian Archives hold a number of documents relating to Australian participation in the occupation of post-war Japan. The majority of these files have been declassified and are available for access by members of the public.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What authority do the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) security personnel have to prevent people meeting airline passengers inside airport terminals.
(2) Under what authority are FAC security personnel preventing representatives of car rental companies from entering Launceston and Hobart airport terminals.
(3) What specific instructions relating to car rental representatives have been issued to security personnel at these airports.
(4) Have these instructions been issued to security personnel at other FAC controlled airports; if so, which airports; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Corporation has broad powers to regulate activities of airport users under the authority of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. Provided people are acting lawfully, there is no objection to them meeting airline passengers inside airport terminals. As some terminals are leased, lessees may have their own regulations for users of those terminals.
(2) Pursuant to Section 9(2)(b) of the FAC Act, the powers of the Corporation extend to granting leases, licences or authorities to use;

(iii) ". . . . . . an area, a building, or part of a building, at a Federal airport or Federal airport development site for a purpose specified in the lease, licence or authorisation, which purpose may be or include-
(iv) the selling, for delivery at the airport or development site, or supplying, of any goods or services;
(v) the carrying on of, or soliciting for, any business;. . . .".
Under Section 3.1 of the Federal Airports Corporation By-Laws dealing with the Regulation of Trading at Airports it is specifically stated that:
"A person shall not, at a Federal Airport, either personally, or by his or her servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of another person;
(a) sell, for delivery at a Federal Airport, or supply, any goods or services;
(b) carry on, or solicit for, any business; or
(c) erect, display or distribute any advertisement or public notice;

ANSWER.PARA: except in accordance with the conditions of a lease, licence or authorisation granted or given by the Corporation under the Act.

PARA.TAB: People meeting airline passengers inside terminals to conduct business transactions for which they do not hold `authorisation' pursuant to Section 9(2)(b) of the FAC Act contravene the Act and are subject to their trading activities being halted subject to Section 3.1 of the FAC By-Laws.
(3) Security personnel are asked to monitor the contractual obligations of car rental operators inside the terminals and to take notes of any breaches of licence conditions.

A list of authorised car rental operators is made available to airport security personnel. Where unauthorised operators are found to be on airport, the instruction to airport security is to advise the airport management and request the operator to contact the Operations Manager.

(4) The instructions, issued at all FAC airports, regarding the issues of policing and monitoring the activity of all operators are simply an extension of the public statement made by the Corporation in its Summary of Car Rental Rights and Obligations issued on the 1 February 1993.

In essence this statement was that the Corporation would enforce any requirement set out in the car rental agreements and would prevent any person who had not signed an agreement from operating a car rental business at airports.

In subsequent advice to all airports it was further stated that the value of the rights granted to operators contracting with respective airports must be assessed in light of the degree to which the Corporation is prepared to ensure that contracting parties receive value for money and especially that they are not compromised by activities of operators which are in breach of the FAC Act and FAC By-Laws.

It was further stated that the means through which policing and monitoring activities were to be conducted would be best left to each airport with the proviso that it is an area in which the Corporation is accountable, and for which the Corporation will need to demonstrate not only the implementation but also the positive effect of the measures introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 1822 (Senate Hansard, 18 August 1992, p.108) relating to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:
(1) What is the current number of full-time and part-time employees.
(2) What is the breakdown of current full-time and part-time employees in each state, by: (i) major metropolitan; and (ii) non-metropolitan areas.
(3) What are the projected full-time and part-time staff levels at the end of 1993 and 1994 by: (i) major metropolitan; and (ii) non-metropolitan areas.
(4) What are the comparative figures for 1987 and 1990 staff levels, by: (i) major metropolitan; and (ii) non-metropolitan areas, be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) ceased to exist on 5 October 1992 with the introduction of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 and the commencement of the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA). At 13 May 1993 the ABA employed 190 full-time and 4 part-time staff.
(2) At 13 May 1993 the ABA had 190 full-time staff and 4 part-time staff located in major metropolitan areas. No staff are located outside metropolitan areas.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Staff levels projections are as follows:

PARA.TAB: (4) In 1987 the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had 137 full-time and 1 part-time staff located in major metropolitan areas. In 1990, 125 full-time and 1 part-time staff were located in major metropolitan areas. The ABT had never had staff based in non-metropolitan areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the tender by a number of companies for the discreet protection of VIP limousines contract:
(1) Has this contract been let; if so, who was the successful company and was it an Australian company.
(2) What was the value of the tender.
(3) How many cars are involved.
(4) Why is it necessary to have cars with this protection in Australia if high profile visiting dignitaries bring their own cars.
(5) To what use are these cars put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Chicago Armor and Limousine Manufacturing Corporation. The company is not Australian. A total of two Australian companies tendered for the work but neither complied fully with tender specifications.

The specification called for a particular type of steel for the opaque areas which has the ability to resist attack from NATO (and other) weapons. The Australian companies offered products which were considerably thicker and heavier in weight.
Using the thicker and heavier material would increase the vehicles tare mass to a level that would make the vehicles dangerous to handle.
Neither tenderer complied with the specification in relation to transparent armour, which was polycarbonate backed laminated glass.
All of the materials offered by the Australian companies would have had to be imported because they are not available in Australia.
The prices tendered by the Australian companies were also higher than that offered by the successful tenderer.
(3) Four.

(4) Only the United States of America President and Vice President bring their own cars, so armoured cars need to be provided for all dignitaries with a threat assessment visiting Australia. The decision in the current case was taken on basis of technical and operational advice from inter alia staff in DASFLEET, COMCAR, Australian Federal Police, Protective Services Coordination Centre and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
(5) The vehicles would be used for visits of guests of the Government to Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. The spare vehicle would be held in Canberra for use as required in other cities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: On how many occasions have the Australian Federal Police used legal telephone taps in Western Australia and/or assisted, or worked in conjunction with, the Western Australian Police Force where telephone taps were used during:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Of the above intercepts, two were joint operations and in one the AFP was assisted by the Western Australian Police. However, the AFP has no jurisdiction to be able to assist the States in investigating State offences which do not breach Commonwealth laws.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the television documentary entitled Shoalwater up for Grabs, shown by Channel 7 on 29 November 1992, is it correct that the Aboriginal people shown in the documentary are not from the Shoalwater Bay area and are not traditional owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Senator's question raises the question of whether certain Aboriginal people shown in a television documentary are traditional owners for the Shoalwater Bay area.
I am unable to form an opinion on the question the Senator has raised upon the limited information available to me.
I suggest that the Senator take this matter up with the makers of the television documentary.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current situation regarding the winding up of Quintex (sic) Limited.
(2) Have the affairs of Mr Skase as a director of that company been fully investigated by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC): if so, what were the results of those investigations.
(3) Have any charges been laid against Mr Skase: if so, what are they and when are they likely to be dealt with by the courts.

(4) Have there been any complaints made to the ASC regarding the liquidation of the company Quintex (sic) Limited, or about the auditors or liquidators of the company: if so, what is the general nature of those complaints and what action has been taken in relation to those complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Qintex Limited is currently in liquidation at the petition of creditors of the company. Mr Rex James Dwyer and Mr Richard Anthony Barber, of Messrs Price Waterhouse, were appointed as liquidators on 22 November 1990. The latest liquidator's account of receipts and payments in this liquidation was lodged on 1 December 1992 and showed that no amounts had been received or paid on account of Qintex Limited for the preceding 6 months.

Receivers and managers have also been appointed to Qintex Australia Limited, a subsidiary of Qintex Limited. Mr D.A. Crawford and Mr J.G. Allpass of Messrs KPMG Peat Marwick were appointed as receivers and managers on 21 November 1989, at the petition of creditors.

(2) The affairs of Mr Skase as Chairman of the Qintex Group of companies, including Qintex Limited and Qintex Australia Limited, have been investigated as part of the ASC investigation into the affairs of the Qintex Group and its officers, more particularly for the period from 1989 until its collapse.

The investigation was begun by the National Companies and Securities Commission in November 1989 and continued by the ASC and has concentrated on breaches of directors' duties, financing dealings in own shares market manipulation and financial operations in relation to the Group.
(3) As a result of the investigation, charges under the Companies (Queensland) Code have been laid against Mr Skase.

Two charges under subsection 229(4) of the Companies (Queensland) Code were laid in the Southport Magistrates Court on 27 May 1991. The charges relate to a payment of $19 million by a Qintex subsidiary, IPH Finance Pty Limited, which ultimately was paid to Kahmea Investments Pty Limited. Mr Skase was arrested and released on bail in relation to these charges.

Two indictments containing a further 32 charges were presented in the Brisbane District Court on 31 August 1992. Most of the charges allege offences by Mr Skase involving improper use of his position as an officer of IPH Finance Pty Limited in authorising various payments to Qintex Group Management Services Pty Limited to gain an advantage for Kahmea Investments Pty Limited or himself. The total amount of payments involved in these charges is alleged to be $7,448,213.

A further charge alleges an offence by Mr Skase of not acting honestly in the discharge of his duties as an officer of IPH Finance Pty Limited by authorising payment of $2,850,000 to Qintex Group Management Services Pty Limited with intent to defraud IPH Finance Pty Limited.

In addition, two counts on a second indictment allege Mr Skase was knowingly concerned in the giving of financial assistance by Qintex Australia Limited in connection with the acquisition by Kahmea Investments Pty limited of shares and convertible unsecured notes in Qintex Limited, the holding company of Qintex Australia Limited.

Mr Skase has waived his right to a committal hearing and will be tried in the Queensland District Court on these two indictments. The trial was provisionally listed to commence on 23 August 1993, but because Mr Skase's medical condition precludes travel to Australia at present, it has now been listed to commence on 14 March 1994.
The case will be mentioned in the District Court on 30 November 1993 to review the trial date pending further medical evidence being presented to the Court.
The Magistrates Court charges are being held over pending determination of the matters before the District Court.

(4) There have been no formal complaints made to the ASC regarding the liquidation of Qintex Limited. There have been no formal complaints made concerning the auditors or liquidators of Qintex Limited.

However, various public enquiries about the conduct of the auditors and liquidators, such as in relation to action taken by the liquidators to recover from shareholders unpaid amounts on their Qintex Australia Limited shares, have been received by the ASC.
The financial management systems and reporting by the Qintex Group, including the conduct of auditors of accounts, have been examined as part of the overall investigation by the ASC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the relocation of nursing home beds from Brancaster Nursing Home to the Shire of Muswellbrook:

(1) What is the legislative or other basis for the statement from the Minister's adviser that the Minister `cannot intervene or refuse approval where the parties to a nursing home transfer meet the legislative requirements'.

(2) In view of the acknowledgement by the Minister that the Muswellbrook local government area has no nursing home accommodation, does the Minister intend to take into account the needs of Muswellbrook and approve funding for 40 nursing homes in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953, specifically subsection 135A(1), provides that information about a person or an individual nursing home acquired in the performance of duties or functions under the Act cannot be divulged to a third person. Consistent with this provision, information specific to individual nursing homes or, indeed, information which might reveal information with regard to the affairs of individual nursing homes and persons involved in their operations, cannot be divulged.

The Minister's powers to grant approval in principle for transfer of nursing home beds depend upon applications from proprietors. Where an application for transfer of nursing home beds has been received, the Minister must consider the application against principles formulated under:

subsection 39A(6) of the National Health Act 1953 to decide whether the nursing home beds are needed in the region, with consideration being given to whether the existing nursing home ratio for the region significantly exceeds the State average; and

subsection 39BA(4) of the Act to decide whether the proposed proprietor is a suitable person to provide nursing home services. If an applicant and the proposal meet all the requirements of the legislation for the proposed transfer it is usual practice for the Minister to approve the transfer. If, on the other hand, more than one applicant is involved then the Minister weighs up the relative merits of each application. Clearly then, within the provisions of the Act, the Minister is bound to have regard to the Principles formulated under 39A(6) and 39BA(4) in exercising his discretion to approve an application. Therefore the statement you quote in part (1) of your question does not accurately reflect the requirements of the legislation.

(2) When granting approval in principle for new nursing home beds, the Minister gives priority to areas of highest need, particularly those areas where the nursing home ratio is significantly below the State average. The Minister receives advice from the NSW Aged Care Advisory Committee (ACAC) which would consider, among other things, comparative needs across NSW regions. This is usually done on the basis of planning regions rather than areas within planning regions but the Shire of Muswellbrook has been given the opportunity to provide information to the NSW ACAC.

The NSW ACAC met on 4 May 1993 to consider the regional targeting of new nursing home and hostel places for 1993-94. The ACAC's recommendations on areas of greatest need and the number of places to be targeted to each of these regions will be forwarded to the Minister in early June.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What funding, grant or other form of payment, has the department and its agencies approved to trade unions since 1 July 1992, in each case, please provide details of: (a) the name of the trade union; (b) the purpose of the funding; and (c) under what program the funding was made.
