(3) Could these details be provided by 8 February 1993.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Details of funding, grants or other forms of payment approved by my department and its agencies since 1 July 1992 are provided in the attached tables.
(2) The Australian Trade Union Training Authority will continue to hire training rooms if required and found economical and convenient.
A payment of $16,060, under Sub-program 1.1, is to be paid to the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers' Union (Vic) upon presentation and acceptance of the final research report.
A final payment of $8,000, under Sub-program 1.1, is to be paid to the Queensland Nurses' Union upon presentation and acceptance of the final research report.
Six requests for funding from trade unions have been received as at 13 May 1993 but are yet to be approved by me. They are:
Automotive, Metal and Engineering Union—funding for booklet "Practical Approach to Enterprise Bargaining using a Best Practice Concept" under the Workplace Reform Program for $20,000;
Food Preservers Union (WA)—funding for a Work Change Adviser under the Workplace Reform Program for $30,000;
Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union—funding for a workplace bargaining project in the pulp and paper sector under the Workplace Reform Program for $25,000;

Automotive, Metal and Engineering Union, Vehicles Division—funding for implementation of the classification structure in the Vehicle Retail Services and Repair Award under the Workplace Reform Program for $40,600; and

Vehicle Builders Union of SA—funding for assisting migrants to understand the role of unions and to participate in the decision making processes and to integrate language and literacy on-the-job training under the Migrant Workers Participation Scheme for $73,592.

Merchant Services Guild and the Australian Stevedoring Supervisors Association—application for funding contribution to the educative and legal costs associated with amalgamation (level of assistance yet to be determined).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the proportion of the Senate vote counted at 30 minute intervals during the election night of 13 March 1993: (a) nationally; and (b) for each State and Territory.
(2) What were the comparable statistics for the Senate count in March 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Attached is a table identifying the percentage of vote counted by State and nationally for the Senate at the 1993 election, and comparable statistics at the same time for the 1990 election.
Two points are worth making:
The figures represent the times they were entered into the computer system used to record and display figures used in the National Tally Room in Canberra.

The figures were directly input into the computer at a divisional level in 1993. As you can see, they were up to 2 1/2 hours faster than in 1990, when figures were manually compiled at a divisional level, and phoned to each State office, for input to the computer system.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) At what stage of development is the proposed Indonesia-Australia nuclear science and technology agreement.
(2) Will the agreement be tabled in both houses of Parliament; if not, why not.

(3) What will be the benefits for Australia in each of the following areas from the Indonesian nuclear science and technology agreement: (a) scientific; (b) commercial; (c) industrial; (d) national interest; and (e) environmental.
(4) Does the agreement with Indonesia contain opt-out clauses if commercial and safeguards agreements are broken by either party; if not, why not.
(5) Has Australia signed nuclear science, technology and information agreements with other countries; if so, which countries.

(6) If Australia has nuclear science, technology and information agreements with other countries: (a) which of these countries have undergone International Atomic Energy Agency Board (IAEA) safety and/or safeguards inspections; and (b) have any of these countries undergone bilateral inspections.
(7) What is the membership criteria of the IAEA Board.
(8) Are there any countries represented on the IAEA Board that do not possess nuclear facilities such as power or research reactors.
(9) Has the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) ever invited the IAEA to undertake a safety inspection of HIFAR; if not, why not.
(10) How many staff work on safeguards matters within: (a) the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; and (b) ANSTO.
(11) How many staff work on diplomatic and technical matters within the safeguards areas of: (a) the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; and (b) ANSTO.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The conclusion of the Nuclear Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement with Indonesia is under discussion with Indonesian authorities.
(2) Yes. See answer to question on notice No 1257 of 25 February 1992 (Senate Hansard pp.180-181).

(3) The objective of the proposed Agreement with Indonesia is to enhance existing and mutually beneficial scientific and technological cooperation in the peaceful nuclear field, including in such areas as nuclear medicine, radiation protection, nuclear-related safety information and applications of radioisotopes.

(4) Full details of the agreement will be made public in the normal way after signature. The Agreement would not provide for commercial transfers of uranium to Indonesia (see my answer to the question without notice in the Senate on 10 December 1991—Senate Hansard, pp.4485-4486).

(5) No. Australia has nuclear cooperation agreements with a number of countries primarily for the transfer of uranium and some of these also provide a general umbrella for wider nuclear cooperation such as nuclear science and technology exchanges. The agreements in the latter category are those with Canada, Egypt, Japan, Republic of Korea, Mexico, Philippines, Russia and the United States of America.

(6)(a) A basic condition of Australia's nuclear cooperation policy is coverage by IAEA safeguards. All the countries listed in the answer to part (5) have safeguards agreements with the IAEA to enable IAEA safeguards inspections to take place. The IAEA has carried out safety review missions of some civil nuclear facilities in each of these countries.

(b) Pursuant to those agreements under which uranium has been transferred, the Australian Safeguards Office maintains regular contact with its bilateral partner through an exchange of information and visits.

(7) Article VI.A of the Agency's Statute provides that the Board of Governors shall be composed of 35 members, 13 of whom are designated annually for membership by the outgoing Board as the "most advanced in the technology of atomic energy including the production of source materials" and taking account of geographic distribution. The remaining 22 members of the Board are elected on a geographic basis by the General Conference for two year periods.

(8) All designated members of the Board such as Australia operate nuclear facilities. Of the current elected members of the Board, Ecuador, Nigeria, Paraguay and Saudi Arabia do not operate nuclear facilities.

(9) No. Reviews run by the IAEA specifically related to research reactor safety come under the Integrated Safety Assessments of Research Reactors (INSARR) Program. This Program began in the 1970s and has applied mostly to developing countries to assist in the formulation of their regulatory standards. Before INSARR commenced, the IAEA periodically reviewed the safety of research reactors provided to member states under project agreements with the Agency. These circumstances did not apply to HIFAR. HIFAR's exemplary safety record, as attested by ongoing independent review, has not warranted an INSARR review. In any case, in accordance with Australia's view that ultimate responsibility for the safety of nuclear facilities rests with the sovereign state within whose territory the facilities are situated, final responsibility for the safe operation of HIFAR rests with the Executive Director of ANSTO.
(a) 12 staff
(b) 2 staff.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) At the preliminary meeting of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) held in Kyoto in April 1993, why did Australia take the lead in co-sponsoring a resolution for a Revised Management Procedure which paves the way for resumed commercial whaling.

(2) Why did Australia propose a resolution on Japan's "scientific whaling" program, "Resolution on Special Permit Catches by Japan in the Southern Hemisphere", which appears to condone such hunting rather than condemn it.

(3) What were the reasons for the Director of ANPWS (Dr Peter Bridgewater) setting up a meeting in Madrid in March 1993 with a select group of IWC Commissioners to explore the possibilities of making an agreement to allow commercial whaling to be resumed.

(4) What action has Australia undertaken, or what action is Australia planning to undertake, to advance the commitment given in the Minister's press release of 21 December 1992, to co-ordinate international support for the Antarctic whale sanctuary at the next IWC meeting.

(5)(a) What position will Australia take on the extra quota allocation which the Japanese delegation has requested as "relief for the coastal populations"; and (b) will the Australian delegation vote on this matter if a three-quarter majority voting system is not exercised.
(6) Will the Australian delegation revoke its support of the Revised Management Scheme, which includes the Revised Management Plan for allocation of commercial quotas; if not, why not.

(7) If Australia does not revoke its support of the Revised Management Scheme, will the Minister guarantee that the Scheme will not be furthered until all its components, including control and surveillance and the maintenance of the protection status of stocks, satisfy the most stringent environmental standards.

(8) Will the Australian delegation condemn the Norwegian unilateral recommencement of whaling and threaten harsher measures if Norway decides to carry out its plan to proceed with commercial whaling despite the moratorium.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There was no such meeting.

(2) Australia's position at IWC 44 (1992) and 45 (1993) concerning scientific whaling was to oppose the use of the provisions of Article VIII of the 1946 International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling, which allow for research involving killing whales, indicating particular concern where permits granted under national legislation to take whales for scientific purposes under those provisions appear, by their scale and nature, to subvert the intent of the moratorium on commercial whaling.

At IWC 44 Australia and a number of other countries co-sponsored a resolution introduced by the USA on special permit catches in the southern hemisphere, inviting Japan to reconsider and improve proposed research. The resolution was adopted by consensus.

(3) There was no meeting in Madrid in March 1993. A meeting was held in Madrid in mid-February for an informal exchange of views on a range of issues under discussion at IWC 45. The meeting was arranged by Dr Bridgewater in his capacity as Vice-Chairman of the IWC. It was intended that the meeting could assist in undertaking some preparatory work for the Agenda at IWC 45.
(4) Australia wishes to ensure the success of the Southern Ocean Sanctuary proposal and will strongly support its further development.

At the recent IWC meeting, Australia strongly supported proposals for further work to be undertaken on the sanctuary proposal, including: the development of a timetable for its implementation, agreement on management issues, and consideration of outstanding political, legal, ecological, geographical, financial and global environmental issues relating to the sanctuary. The recent meeting has also agreed to Australia hosting an intercessional planning meeting of IWC members to facilitate that work.

(5)(a) At IWC 45 Australia opposed special relief allocations for small-type coastal whaling operations, on the grounds that evidence provided to date indicates a strong commercial component in trade and distribution of the products of such activities.
(b) Australia opposes suggestions that such an allocation could be determined by a simple majority vote on a Resolution. At IWC 45, the request did not achieve support.

(6) Australia will not revoke its support of the Revised Management Scheme. If whaling should ever resume, a high level of security would need to be afforded to exploited cetacean populations to provide the most conservative achievable management regime.

(7) Yes. Australia will support further development of Schedule amendments to incorporate additional provisions to the Revised Management Scheme to provide the most conservative achievable management regime. These include: 1) an effective observation and inspection scheme; 2) data standards; 3) agreed guidelines for conducting surveys and methods of analysis, to ensure that aerial and shipboard surveys meet stringent standards; and 4) agreed arrangements to ensure that all catches are taken into consideration. At IWC 45, a resolution to bind the Commission to implement the Revised Management Scheme in 1994 was defeated, largely on the initiative of Australia.

(8) The Australian delegation (and 14 others) signed a document condemning the proposed action by Norway. Two other delegations said they would be making unilateral representations to Norway. While Norway's decision is regretted, under provisions in the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling (1946) Norway lodged an objection to the 1982 vote on the moratorium on commercial whaling, therefore allowing them to legally proceed with commercial whaling if they so chose.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given the recent sacking of the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) Chairman and Chief Executive Officer (Mr Barry Carbon) and the sacking of three other members of the five member EPA Board by the State Minister for the Environment (Mr Minson), is the Minister prepared to give full faith and credit, under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, to PER and environmental impact statement (EIS) assessments drafted by the State EPA.

(2) With reference to the decision made by the Western Australian Government to allow oil and gas exploration in Ningaloo Reef Marine Park: (a) will Commonwealth powers be used to prevent oil and gas exploration inside Commonwealth areas of the park; (b) what level and type of funding, if any, has the Commonwealth given to the Western Australian Government for management of Ningaloo Reef Marine Park; (c) will the Commonwealth invoke the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 in order to undertake a Commonwealth environmental impact assessment of the proposal, given that any oil extracted from the seabed is likely to find its way into interstate or international commerce; (d) will the Australian Heritage Commission be requested to give advice in respect to the environmental impact of oil and gas exploration in the Marine Park, as provided for under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975; and (e) if the Commonwealth is not prepared to intervene to stop exploration in areas of State jurisdiction in the park, will Commonwealth powers be used to prevent oil and gas exploration where such activity is affecting or has the potential to affect Commonwealth areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) See Senator Schacht's answer to Senator Coulter's Question Without Notice on 5 May 1993 (Hansard Page 137).
(2) (a) Yes.
(b) The level and type of funds that have been provided to the State by the Commonwealth for management activities in the park are:
Bicentennial funds—$1.3 million
States Cooperative Assistance Program—$299 000
Ocean Rescue 2000—$158 000

(c) If a decision by a Commonwealth Minister or authority is required in relation to an environmentally significant proposal, consideration will be given to applying the provisions of the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

(d) In the absence of any specific proposal to explore for oil and gas in the park requiring a Commonwealth decision, I do not propose to request advice from the Australian Heritage Commission at this time.
(e) The Commonwealth would consider what powers are available to it should any exploration in areas of State jurisdiction have the potential to affect Commonwealth areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Chiltern Regional Park in Victoria:

(1) Will advice be requested from the Australian Heritage Commission in relation to the gold mining development agreed to by the Victorian Government, as provided for under s28(2) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975; if not, why not; if so, what would be the terms of reference for the advice.
(2) Will Federal export and/or foreign investment powers be used to prevent mining in the Chiltern Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. There is no Commonwealth decision involved, and no trigger of the Environment Protection Act 1974, regarding gold exploration in Chiltern Regional Park and, therefore, s28(2) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 does not apply to the situation.

(2) No. Gold does not require export approval. Regarding foreign investment, mineral exploration does not require Commonwealth approval and as the joint venture companies; Osprey Gold NL and Warren Jay Holdings Pty/Ltd are Australian and CRA Exploration Pty/Ltd is naturalised, there is again no requirement for foreign investment approval.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were any Australian companies amongst the 350 companies from 34 countries which took part in the international arms show in the United Arab Emirates which started on 14 February 1993; if so, which companies were they, and what products did they display.
(2) Did any Australian Government officials take part in the exhibition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The question presumably refers to the International Defence Exhibition (IDEX'93).
I understand that several Australian companies did participate in IDEX'93 and exhibited a range of specialised equipment.
I should also point out that Australian companies reach their own commercial judgments on what exhibitions they attend and what products they display.
(2) Australian participation in IDEX'93 was not officially sponsored by the Department of Defence. Hence no Defence officials took part in the exhibition.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 2324 (Senate Hansard, 17 December 1992, p5523) concerning the Piparwar coal mine project in India, if the mine project is subject to the processes of the Indian Government's Environment Protection Act 1986, why did the former Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) comment in December 1991 that the project was not covered by that Act because approval had been gained in 1985, before the Act came into operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has advised me that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Under the Indian Environment Protection Act 1986 (EPA) no mining project can commence without an approved Environmental Management Plan (EMP).

Critics of the Piparwar project commonly claim that because there is no formally cleared EMP for the project it is proceeding illegally. This is not accurate. Mining at Piparwar was sanctioned by the Government of India in 1985, prior to the implementation of the Act, and thus there is no legal requirement for an EMP.

An EMP for the project was prepared in 1989 prior to the implementation of the project. In November 1991, the Government of India advised that the Environment Department had assessed the EMP against the requirements of the EPA and recommended it for approval pending compliance with the requirements of the Ministry of Environment and Forests.

Approval requires clearance by both the Environment and Forestry Appraisal Committees of the Ministry of Environment and Forests. The Government of India has clarified that clearance by the Forestry Appraisal Committee is contingent upon provision by Central Coalfields Limited (CCL) and acceptance by the State Forestry Department of compensatory forest land equivalent to the amount of forestry land within the mining lease.

The Government of India has advised in relation to the forestry provisions currently being applied to the project that mining at Piparwar can proceed on forestry land provided the State Government has received and accepted compensation for pockets of land as they are progressively mined. Thus, in 1991 the construction of a river diversion channel was stopped when the channel reached the boundary of a portion of forest land. Construction did not resume until the Forestry Department had accepted from CCL 13.1 hectares in compensation for an equivalent amount of land to be absorbed by the diversion. Updated advice from the Government of India is that CCL has now found sufficient land to compensate the State Forestry Department in full and that the project now meets the forestry requirements specified in the EPA.

The Government of India has recently advised that final clearance of the EMP is expected shortly. At the request of the Ministry of Environment and Forests, CCL has been asked to review the status of the project and update the EMP. The updated EMP has now been cleared by the Forestry Appraisal Committee and clearance by the Environmental Appraisal Committee is expected to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has any Commonwealth money been paid to the operators of private prisons in Queensland, or have such prisons been involved in any way in Federal Government funded training schemes in the past year; if so, could all details, including the type of scheme, the money advanced and the acquittal procedures, be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Funding has been provided under the JOBTRAIN and JOBSTART programs to the Arthur Gorrie Correctional Centre.

JOBTRAIN provides funding for the purchase of special training courses and places on existing courses for unemployed job seekers. Under JOBTRAIN two Correctional Officers Training Courses have been contracted with the Arthur Gorrie Correctional Centre, run by Australasian Correctional Management, at Ipswich Road, Rocklea, Brisbane:
Fourteen people attended a course from 18 January to 19 February 1993. Full payment of $9,818.25 was made after completion of the project.
Twelve people attended a course from 29 March to 5 May 1993. Full payment of $8,618.25 was made after completion of the project.
Under JOBTRAIN the CES monitors the trainees' progress through regular contact with the training provider and the participants. This included monitoring attendance records.
The Arthur Gorrie Correctional Centre has recruited 45 trainees under the JOBSTART wage subsidy program. To date payments of $57,360 have been made.

Under JOBSTART the CES monitors JOBSTART placements through contact with both employers and the subsidised employees and selective visits to employers' premises. The JOBSTART payment to employers is monthly in arrears. On the claim submitted by the employer, the employer certifies that the employee for whom he/she is claiming subsidy did work for the period of the claim in accordance with the award/agreement conditions specified in the JOBSTART schedule. This certification is countersigned by the employee to whom the claim relates.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the informal vote percentage for the House of Representatives at the 1993 elections highest in South Australia of all the States and Territories.
(2) Has the percentage of informal votes for the House of Representatives been the highest or equal highest in South Australia at every general election since 1984.

(3) Has the Australian Electoral Commission recently conducted any research into the causes of informal voting, including the high informal vote in particular States; if so, what were the results of that research.
(4) Could the high informal vote in South Australia possibly influence the final result in any electorates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) The Commission last conducted an informal ballot paper survey following the 1987 general election. This survey revealed:
(a) that the reasons why papers were rendered informal were, in order of importance, defective numbering, the use of ticks or crosses, leaving the ballot paper blank and writing on the ballot paper;
(b) that there was no significant difference across state borders in the relative importance of these major causes of informality.
There is no apparent reason why voters in South Australia have had greater difficuLty than their colleagues in other States in filling out the House of Representatives ballot paper successfully.

Although the recent election saw a significant drop in most parts of the country in informal voting for both Houses of Parliament (nationally from 3.19% to 2.97% for the House of Reps and from 3.4% to 2.56% for the Senate), it is the Commission's intention to carry out an examination of informal papers from this election in order to learn what they can from these papers about the reasons for the wastage of votes through informality. It is the results of surveys such as these that assist the Commission to shape its public information and advertising programs which have been successful in reducing the informal voting rate in recent elections.

(4) Looked at purely from a statistical point of view the results in four divisions in South Australia (Adelaide, Grey, Hindmarsh and Kingston) could have been affected by informal voting. That is, if all informal votes had been formal and had been cast for the major party which lost the election, that party could have won in that division. Based on the results of earlier informal ballot papers surveys, however, it must be said that such a result is highly unlikely: these surveys showed that informal ballot papers, to the extent that they can be read, were intended to go to all parties, but with more of them intended to be cast for the ALP than for the Coalition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports of a recent visit to Darwin by the nuclear powered submarine USS HOUSTON:
(1) What plan and guidelines were used to brief staff at Royal Darwin Hospital in dealing with nuclear emergencies when only 24 hours notice of the arrival of the vessel in port was given.
(2) Are such briefings adequate.
(3) How often can the citizens of Darwin expect to be exposed to the potential hazards presented by visits from nuclear powered warships.
(4) What representations has the Federal Government made to the United States Government in relation to the number and type of warship visits to Australian ports for 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Northern Territory Government was advised of the visit on 15 January and subsequently responded on 3 February that all the appropriate government departments had been informed. Medical staff at Royal Darwin Hospital were briefed in accordance with the Safety Plan for the Visit by Nuclear Powered Warships to Port Darwin.

(2) The Safety Plan is produced by the Northern Territory Emergency Service under the provisions of the Northern Territory Disasters Act. The Northern Territory Government would be the appropriate authority to respond to questions on the adequacy of Northern Territory emergency procedures.

(3) Visits by Nuclear Powered Warships are made on an irregular basis. The visit by USS HOUSTON was the first to Darwin by a Nuclear Powered Warship since USS POGY in March 1985. There are no Nuclear Powered Warship visits to Darwin programmed.

(4) US warships, as do warships of other nations, conduct visits to Australian ports in accordance with individual national operational requirements. Australian Government approval is sought by the nation concerned for each visit by a foreign warship. Visits by Australian warships to foreign ports are conducted on the same basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a press article by Patrick Lescot of Agence France-Presse, of 25 April 1993 entitled `Pol Pot changes his name but not his goals':
1. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article.
2. What implications for Australia's assessment of refugee applicants from Cambodia has been drawn from the announcement by the Khmer Rouge that it will boycott the elections in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. Yes, I am aware of the article and of the public statements that were made by the Khmer Rouge prior to the elections in Cambodia.

2. The position adopted by the Khmer Rouge in relation to Cambodia's transition to a democratic regime is regrettable but does not appear to have had a major impact on the election process. The massive voter turnout in the recent Cambodian elections indicates that this position has been rejected by the Cambodian people. The next stage of the peace process is about to commence with the convening of the democratically elected Constituent Assembly, in accordance with the Paris Agreements. This committee is to draw up a constitution within three months. The Assembly will then transform itself into a Legislative Assembly and a new government will be formed on the basis of the constitution.

An important part of the settlement is the return of Cambodia to the Cambodians. Major decisions about the future of government of Cambodia should be made by the Cambodians. Obviously the international community will continue to monitor the situation closely and provide appropriate assistance. It should be noted that as part of the settlement the Commission on Human Rights (CHR) has agreed to the appointment of a human rights representative for Cambodia.
Australia has maintained a close interest in the development of democratic processes in Cambodia and will continue to monitor their effects, particularly from a humanitarian perspective.

Australia assesses applications for refugee status on a case by case basis using the criteria defined by the 1951 United Nations Convention and the 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees. General situations such as war, or civil unrest, are relevant to the consideration of asylum claims only in so far as they relate to individual claimants and their own circumstances. Where individuals consider they are at risk in Cambodia the opportunity exists for them to have their refugee claims assessed. Applications for refugee status lodged by Cambodians are received and considered both in Australia and overseas.

A wide range of information, including reports of current political and military developments in Cambodia such as that referred to by the honourable senator, is considered in reaching decisions on applications for refugee status from Cambodians.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department at any time been consulted regarding toxic and or radioactive waste dumps at:
(a) Gurulmundi near Miles in Queensland;
(b) Esk in the Brisbane Valley in Queensland;
(c) Gladstone, Townsville and Mount Isa in Queensland; and
(d) any other locality in Queensland.

(2) If the Government has not been consulted, has the Government conducted any studies or done any work or had any investigations carried out in relation to toxic and or radioactive waste dumps at all or in any of the above sites.
(3) What are the details of the form of consultation and investigation carried out and of the advice given or results of such consultations and investigations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: With regard to toxic wastes:
(1) (a) Yes; (b) No; (c) No; (d) No.
The Minister for Resources has Commonwealth responsibility for radioactive waste repositories. He has advised me as follows with regard to radioactive waste policy:

(b) Esk has been selected by the Queensland Government as a site for an interim radioactive waste storage facility. The management of radioactive waste generated within Queensland's jurisdiction is a matter for the Queensland Government.

(c) Mount Isa. The Mount Isa Development Strategy Group is investigating a number of economic development options for Mount Isa. One of the options being investigated is a national radioactive waste repository. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has provided the Group with advice on matters discussed in the Public Discussion Paper, A Radioactive Waste Repository for Australia: Methods for Choosing the Right Site, released by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in October 1992.
(d) No.
(2) N/A for toxic wastes. For radioactive wastes, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has not conducted studies or investigations at the sites referred to in (b) and (c) above.

(3) With respect to 1 (a), Gurulmundi, my department has been asked for comments in general correspondence and it has spoken from time to time with the Queensland Government and the Murilla Shire Council. I have exchanged letters with the responsible Queensland Minister on the importance of the Queensland assessment process taking into account a full range of potential environmental impacts including those associated with the management of groundwater.

My department has been advised by the Queensland Government that legislation has been prepared specifically on the Gurulmundi landfill. This is the Gurulmundi Secure Landfill Agreement Act 1992 which sets up a Landfill Management Committee with representatives from the Murilla Shire Council, the Brisbane City Council (which will operate the landfill) and the State Government. Under the legislation there is to be an environmental monitoring program. Monitoring will include collecting baseline data before the landfill begins operation.

The Murray-Darling Basin Commission was also informed regarding correspondence my department received on the Queensland EIS. The Commission has written to the Queensland Government advising of its interest that all appropriate environmental measures be taken.

My department has been advised by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation that, at the request of the Director of the Queensland Bureau of Emergency Services, the Bureau of Mineral Resources (BMR) carried out an investigation of the geological Stratigraphy of the Proposed Site in September 1991. The full text of that BMR report, together with other (non-BMR) investigation results, was included as an Appendix to the Gurulmundi Final Impact Assessment Study Report released by the Queensland Government in October 1991.

As the Commonwealth Government is not directly involved in the establishment of a toxic waste landfill at Gurulmundi it would be appropriate to seek any further information on this from the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the development by the United States Defense Department of extremely low frequency (ELF) radio communications technology in which communications with United States (US) nuclear armed submarines can be transmitted from mainland US:

(1) What was the Australian Government told about the development by the United States Defense Department of extremely low frequency (ELF) radio technology, prior to the signing of the new management and cost sharing arrangements for the North West Cape Communications Base in Western Australia.
(2) What purposes will the North West Cape Communications Base serve now that ELF systems have been developed and made fully operational.
(3) What is there to stop the Australian Government closing the North West Cape Communications Base immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The primary role of the North West Cape Communications Base is Very Low Frequency (VLF) and High Frequency (HF) communications. The Extremely Low Frequency (ELF) transmissions from the United States mainland, as referred to by the honourable senator, provides a complimentary, not an alternative, channel of communications for US submarines. In general terms, lowering the transmission frequency allows greater penetration of the sea by radio waves and this, for instance, would enable communications to be established with a submarine at greater depth. However, the increased penetration comes at a cost in terms of data transmission rate and consequently the major utility of ELF transmission is as a `cueing' signal to call the submarine to a shallower depth to receive more detailed communications by other means (such as VLF, HF or satellite communications). Australia has no perceived requirement for, and is not pursuing, ELF communications technology but has an ongoing requirement for the VLF and HF capability supported by the North West Cape Communications Base.

Australian authorities have been aware of ELF development in the United States but it was not a relevant factor, and did not require to be raised, in the negotiation of new management and cost sharing arrangements for the North West Cape Communications Base.

(2) The North West Cape Communications Base continues to serve an important purpose as one element of the worldwide United States submarine communications system, and constitutes the primary communications link with Australian submarines.

(3) The North West Cape Communications Base provides the only Australian controlled capability to communicate with dived Australian submarines throughout our entire region of military interest. It is also a key element in HF radio coverage of the strategically important north west sea and air approaches to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 12 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Standard Gauge Rail Link to the Brisbane port:
(1) Why has the Federal Government spent $40 million on this project which jeopardises the possibility of an efficient national freight rail infrastructure.

(2) If the Government cannot afford to connect the new Brisbane port to the national freight rail grid properly, why does it not support the option of dual gauging an existing narrow gauge line, the option preferred by National Rail Corporation consultants, Booz, Allen & Hamilton, which will cost less than $10 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Government has committed $30 million for the proposed Rail Link to the Port of Brisbane under the One Nation rail infrastructure program. The proposal is a Queensland Government initiative, with a total estimated cost of around $89 million.

The link will provide, among other things, a standard gauge access between the Port of Brisbane and the national intercapital, mainland rail network. Upon completion of the Melbourne—Adelaide standardisation project, that national network will consist of a standard gauge link between Brisbane and Perth, including connections to ports.

Together with the efficiency gains that will be attained by National Rail in the interstate rail freight sector, projects such as the Rail Link to the Port of Brisbane are helping to ensure that operations in that sector can be conducted efficiently and, over time, on a fully commercial basis without subsidisation from governments.

(2) The option chosen by Queensland Rail (QR) for linking the Port of Brisbane to the national intercapital, mainland network involves a combination of the construction of new dual gauge track, and the dual gauging of existing narrow gauge track. This combination, while more costly than a single track dual gauge option, obviates the need to double-handle interstate rail freight traffic to and from the Port due to gauge differences.

Booz Allen & Hamilton, who undertook some consulting work for the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force, developed a preliminary estimate of around $10m to dual gauge an existing track. Consultants also found that this would not provide the operating flexibility of a separate line and that operation of passenger trains in peak periods could cause increased freight operations out of these hours, including night time operations.

QR's option will provide it with greater scheduling flexibility, and will improve nationwide transportation movements and waterfront efficiency. The flexibility for QR to schedule coal, grain and freight trains in the day time was identified in the course of the Queensland Impact Assessment Study (IAS) as a significant operational benefit. This is noteworthy because the IAS found that the single most common source of complaint against the existing rail line is the noise from diesel-electric locomotives hauling freight trains, particularly late at night.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have there been criticisms to the effect that the information provided to Commonwealth employees between 1975 and 1990, concerning the options available to members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) who were resigning from Commonwealth employment was not adequate for an informed decision to be made.
(2) What information did the Government provide to employees to inform them that in the case of resignation a member could preserve his or her benefits in the scheme.

(3) What information was made available to employees on the possibility of `rolling over' their resignation benefits into an Approved Deposit Fund (ADF) or other `roll-over' vehicle after 1 July 1983.

(4) Is it a fact that former members of the CSS who had resigned and received a refund of their contributions, and then rolled that amount over into an ADF, were allowed to retrospectively preserve their benefits in the CSS.
(5) Is it a fact that many or all of those people referred to in (4) have not recommenced employment with the Commonwealth.
(6) How many cases referred to in (5) have been allowed.
(7) How many retrospective benefit elections have been allowed for those who have: (a) recommenced employment with the Commonwealth; and (b) not recommenced employment with the Commonwealth.

(8) Does the Government consider that the form s2A concerning the treatment of a resigning member's superannuation benefits between 1975 and 1990, adequately explained the preservation option available to members of the CSS.
(9) What explanatory material was made available to resigning members when the form s2A was provided to them.
(10) Was the Retirement Benefit Office (RBO) aware of shortcomings of the s2A form, if so, what were these and when was the RBO made aware of these shortcomings.
(11) Why did the RBO take 8 years to replace the form after recognition of problems.

(12) How many applications have been made to the RBO for late elections to preserve benefits in the CSS and how many of these former members claimed that they were unaware or misunderstood the preservation option.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware that there have been many requests for late elections to preserve benefits in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS). I also understand that many of those requests have contended that the person was not fully informed of the preservation option at the time they elected to take a refund of contributions with interest.

(2) The Commissioner for Superannuation, who is responsible for the administration of the preservation provisions of the CSS has advised that the employers of members of the CSS have been provided with extensive information on the preservation of superannuation rights since May 1971 when preservation was introduced into the CSS.
The Commissioner provided the following information about preservation to employers who had the responsibility for counselling members resigning from Commonwealth employment.
advice about the introduction of the preservation provisions into the CSS and changes in the application form to cater for an election to preserve superannuation rights.
new entrant brochure which contained information on the value of transferring preserved benefits from previous employment on becoming a new member or on again becoming a member of the CSS.

ANSWER.PARA: Information papers No 1 and No 7 dated April 1976 and 2 August 1978 respectively—

PARA.TAB: these papers provided extensive information on preservation of superannuation rights.
this leaflet provided information on the member's options on resignation and included reference to preservation of superannuation rights as an option.

ANSWER.PARA: Amendment Issue No. 4 to Manual of Instructions to Employers dated May 1979—

PARA.TAB: inserted Chapter 11 in that Manual. Chapter 11 contained extensive information on preservation of superannuation rights.
(Chapter 11 of the Manual of Instructions was replaced by the Superannuation Manual, dated August 1979 which also contained detailed information on preservation.)
provided details of the difference between preservation of superannuation rights and rolling over to an approved deposit fund (ADF).
information statements issued to members annually following the 1986/87 financial year (other than 1988/89) contained reference to preservation of superannuation rights.

ANSWER.PARA: There were also numerous circulars issued advising the superannuation schemes that were declared "eligible superannuation schemes" for the purposes of paying a transfer value from the CSS where the member had elected for preservation of superannuation rights.

In addition, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) (now CFM Ltd) provided a range of information to employers for distribution to contributors about the performance of the Fund as well as topics about which SFIT received enquiries, including preservation. These included:

PARA.TAB: issued approximately three times a year from March 1987 onwards.

ANSWER.PARA: Leaflet entitled "Thinking of Resigning? Don't Throw Away Your Super!"—

PARA.TAB: leaflet issued in 1988 which briefly set out options available to contributors leaving the CSS before retirement age giving some details about preservation.

ANSWER.PARA: Booklet entitled "Understanding The Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme"—

PARA.TAB: this booklet was sent to workplace destinations in October 1988 in the ratio one for each ten contributors. The booklet briefly covered information about entitlements and superannuation investment opportunities.

ANSWER.PARA: SFIT publications were sent to libraries at Government Departments and Statutory Authorities and to relevant industrial organisations.

PARA.TAB: (3) A circular was issued to employers on 10 June 1986 advising that lump sum payments, including resignation payments could be rolled over to an ADF. In addition a circular dated 20 May 1988 provided details of the difference between preservation of superannuation rights and rolling over to an ADF.

(4) Yes. It has been the practice to allow late elections for preservation in such cases because the act of `rolling over' to an ADF is a prima facie indication that the members intended to preserve their benefits until genuine retirement.

(5) Statistics of the reasons for accepting or not accepting a late election to preserve superannuation rights and whether the member has recommenced Commonwealth employment are not kept. However, anecdotal evidence suggests that in most cases where the member has rolled over his or her lump sum to an ADF and the late election has been accepted, he or she has recommenced public employment.
(6) See above.
(7) See above.

(8) The form contained three options. The member was instructed to choose one of the options listed on the form. The form was not intended to explain any of the three options listed. Rather, as the AAT has observed, the form put the reader on notice that advice was available and, if the member was unsure on any point (including the preservation option), he or she should have made enquiries of his or her employer.
(9) It is impossible to say as it was expected that this material would be provided by the member's employer.

(10) The RBO reviewed all its forms in 1987 to accommodate automated data entry processing. In the process of the review the RBO sought ways to improve the entire range of its forms to assist members. Information on preservation of superannuation rights was included on the resignation form during this process.
(11) See above.

(12) For the period 1 July 1988 to 13 April 1993 there were 613 requests for late elections received. Of these, 49 requests were accepted, 425 were rejected and 139 remained to be decided. Reasons for not electing in the required time are not kept.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister received a report from the department on the recognition of prior service with the Australian Defence Force as a continuous service with the Commonwealth when redundancy payments are being calculated for Commonwealth employees.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Ombudsman's report on the same issue.

(3) If there is any difference of substance in the findings or recommendations in the two reports, will further consultations be undertaken with ex-service organisations before reaching any decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I have received the report from my Department and am considering it.
(2) Yes.

(3) Extensive consultations have already taken place, and are covered in the report. This, together with the Ombudsman's views, should provide sufficient information for me to make an appropriate judgement on the matters raised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did any of the senior management of Qantas negotiate increased separation benefits, prior to the sale of part of Qantas to an overseas buyer, in order to protect their own interests in the event that their appointments might become redundant after the sale; if so, what were those benefits.
(2) Was this approved by any member of the Qantas Board; if so, who was the member.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) Qantas has advised that its senior managers are employed on a contract basis. The Board determines (rather than negotiates) the period, remuneration and conditions of employment, including provisions for termination. The contracts are reviewed on an annual basis. All senior management contracts underwent an annual review in the 12 months prior to the sale of equity to British Airways. The exact details of the employment contracts are personnel-in-confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it, or was it, a practice of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) that all general managers were appointed on the same salary.

(2) Was one general manager paid more than the others; if so: (a) what was the name of the manager; (b) how much was the salary increment; (c) did the chairman of the CAA Board approve the salary increment; and (d) who was the relevant Minister at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Authority determines a salary range for each position based on the application of a proprietary job evaluation methodology. This method is supported by Jacques Martin Hewitt International and various market surveys performed by that company from time to time. Following a competitive selection process, and prior to signing a contract of employment, each General Manager appointee negotiates a salary package within the pre-specified range with the Chief Executive Officer (CEO). The procedure then involves the CEO discussing the proposed salary package with the CAA Board Chairman before completing the appointment of each individual.

(2) All General Manager appointments have been processed in accordance with (1). The CAA Board reviewed all the proposed salary ranges with the then CEO prior to the first set of General Manager appointments in 1991. The question of any salary "increments" outside the predetermined range has not arisen. The Minister is not involved in the selection process other than to approve the creation of the positions in the first place prior to them being publicly advertised.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Arts and Administrative Services: Minutes and Briefing Paper

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister's office or department maintain a register of minutes and briefing papers received; if so, what has been the stated subject, author and date of each item received since 13 March 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes a register is kept, however, as this information includes confidential material it is not appropriate that it be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many square metres of office space are either leased, owned or occupied by the department and agencies.
(2) What is the break-down by State and Territories.
(3) How many department and agency employees occupy the office space.
(4) What is the break-down by State and Territories.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) 71,805 m squared of office space as of 1 May 1993. This figure includes special purpose areas, eg public contact areas, hearing rooms, storage, etc. Excluding these areas, leaves 60,685 m squared. The figure represents a peak in accommodation holdings, as in Victoria and New South Wales the Department is in the process of moving accommodation in some offices. During the transition period there can be some short-term duplication of holdings which are reflected in the figures. By 30 June 1994 the portfolio's gross holdings should be around 66,230 m squared and the space net of special purpose areas should be around 56,106 m squared.

ANSWER.PARA: Including Special Purpose Areas Excluding Special Purpose Areas
1 May 93 m(2) 30 June 94 m(2) 1 May 93 m(2) 30 June 94m(2)

PARA.TAB: This figure represents average staffing levels and does not include temporary or part time staff or consultants and contractors for whom space must be made available. While precise numbers of such staff fluctuates considerably, a number of around 10% of the full time staffing level is considered appropriate to be added for purposes of assessing accommodation needs.
(4) ACT—1167; NSW—767; Victoria—502; Queensland—170; SA—83; WA—172; Tasmania—21; NT—28.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office issued, or does it intend to issue, a draft ruling dealing generally with the taxation treatment of retirement village dealings and arrangements; if so, when will the draft ruling be issued.
(2) If the draft ruling has been issued, please provide a copy.
(3) What specific areas or issues is it intended that the draft ruling will deal with or address.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has issued a draft Taxation Ruling dealing with the taxation treatment of amounts received by retirement village proprietors from residents. That draft Ruling was released on 27 May 1993.
(2) The honourable Senator will be provided with a copy of the draft Ruling.

(3) The draft Ruling deals with each of the arrangements, of which the ATO is aware, that are used either to sell individual units or otherwise give to residents rights of occupancy to units in retirement villages, including sale by strata title, lease and licence arrangements and company title arrangements.
