QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Does the department use the umbrella title `Yugoslav' or `Yugoslavia' in official records and publications to also refer to the people of Bosnia and Croatia; if so,

QUESTION.PARA: does the Government propose to change official use of the word `Yugoslav' in its records and publications to reflect the new countries in south-eastern Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Department does not now use the words `Yugoslav' or `Yugoslavia' in its official records and publications, except in the general sense of "the former Yugoslavia", or "the former Yugoslav Republic of. . . ", where an immigration provision (eg Special Assistance Category and Humanitarian Temporary Entry Permit) applies specifically to all of the Republics of "the former Yugoslavia"; or where it might be desirable to avoid reference to specific ethnicities or national origins; or where Australia has not yet accorded official recognition (thus: "refugees [collectively] from the former Yugoslavia"; "the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia").

Official statistical publications from the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research refer to "Former Yugoslav Republics". This is an interim measure as, often, no further detail is available. The standard footnote reads `including the now independent republics of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia'. This practice of statistical reporting follows the policy adopted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The departmental usage described here dates from the recognition of Croatian and Slovenian independence in January 1992, at which time it became inappropriate to refer to `Yugoslavia' as a single state or country of origin of migrants to Australia. Bosnia-Herzegovina was recognised by Australia in May 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the departmental salary ranges for the following classifications: (a) Administrative Service Officer 1 to 6; (b) Senior Officer; (c) Senior Executive Officer Band 1 to 3; (d) Information Technology Officer; (e) Senior Information Technology Officer; (f) Professional Officer (Social Worker); (g) Senior Professional Officer (Social Worker); (h) Professional Officer (other); (i) Senior Professional Officer (other); and (j) general.

(2) What are the staffing levels for each of the following programs according to the classifications listed in (1): (a) Program 1—Income security for the retired; (b) Program 2—Income security for people with disabilities and the sick; (c) Program 3—Income security for the unemployed; (d) Program 4—Income security for families with children; (e) Program 5—Provision for special circumstances; and (f) Program 6—Corporate and other services.
(3) What were the staffing levels, according to job classification, for each of the six programs in (2) in 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The departmental salary ranges for the Department of Social Security for the classifications listed are as follows:
(a) Administrative Service Officer: Class 1 $12,701 to 23,397; Class 2 $23,959 to 26,568; Class 3 $27,289 to 29,452; Class 4 $30,415 to 33,024; Class 5 $33,924 to 35,971; Class 6 $36,638 to 42,088.
(b) Senior Officer: Grade C $43,367 to 47,107; Grade B $48,133 to 55,234; Grade A $57,247.
(c) Senior Executive Officer: Band 1 $61,147 to 68,663; Band 2 $77,403 to 84,763; Band 3 $94,441 to 102,399.
(d) Information Technology Officer: Class 1 $29,452 to 33,675; Class 2 $36,638 to 42,088.
(e) Senior Information Technology Officer: Grade C $43,367 to 47,107; Grade B $48,133 to 55,234; Grade A $57,247.
(f) Professional Officer (Social Worker): Class 1 $25,550 to 35,843; Class 2 $36,638 to 40,946.
(g) Senior Professional Officer (Social Worker): Grade C $43,367 to 47,107; Grade B $48,133 to 55,234; Grade A $57,247.
(h) Professional Officer (other): Class 1 $25,550 to 35,843; Class 2 $36,638 to 40,946.
(i) Senior Professional Officer (other): Grade C $43,367 to 47,107; Grade B $48,133 to 55,234; Grade A $57,247.
(2) Staffing levels for each of the above classifications cannot be provided by program because the Department does not operate or allocate salary or administrative funds on this basis.

The Department's organisational structure comprises National Administration, 20 Area Offices and a network of over 200 Regional Offices. More than two thirds of the Department's staff are based in Area and Regional Offices.

These offices and their staff cover functions which range across the six Social Security programs. This operational arrangement is essential to deliver services which deal effectively with clients whose situations and needs are diverse and to manage efficiently the changing priorities of, and competing demands for resources, to deliver client services. This means that operating funds (such as salary) cannot be accounted for strictly according to program elements.

As set out in the Portfolio's 1992-93 Program Performance Statements (Appendix D), a Resource Attribution Model has been developed which assigns salary and administrative costs to the program structure to indicate the resource requirements and usage of each program element. This model, however, does not distinguish between classifications of staff.
The attribution model is based on the Department's Regional Staffing Model (RSM), Area staffing structures and actual usage in National Administration.
The total staff numbers by program in accordance with the attribution model for 1992-93 are as follows:
(a) Program 1—Income security for the retired: 2,231.3 staff years
(b) Program 2—Income security for people with disabilities and the sick: 2,455.2 staff years
(c) Program 3—Income security for the unemployed: 7,708.3 staff years
(d) Program 4—Income security for families with children: 4,524.1 staff years
(e) Program 5—Provision for special circumstances: 1,068.2 staff years
(f) Program 6—Corporate and other services: 2,430.0 staff years

(3) The introduction of program budgeting in Budget agencies was in its early stages when the 1988-89 Explanatory Notes for the Social Security portfolio were released. There were then three Social Security programs. The attribution of resources to this structure, therefore, is not comparable to the attribution for 1992-93. In addition, client population and eligibility changes and an organisational restructuring of the Department which included the abolition of State Offices have contributed to changes and refinements in the attribution model.
The share of resources attributed to the 1988-89 program structure is set out below:
Program 1—Pension, Benefits and Allowances: 14,152 staff years
Program 2—Corporate Services: 2723 staff years
Program 3—Comcare: 176 staff years (a part year effect shared with the Industrial Relations portfolio)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the increase in the number of Department of Social Security (DSS) offices in Queensland over the past few years:
(1) What are the grounds for opening new offices.
(2) What were the costs for setting up each new office in Queensland for the past 4 years, including fixtures, office equipment and public announcements concerning the new service.
(3) How many premises were in rented property and how many were in buildings built or owned by the Commonwealth.
(4) What costs in transferring and training new staff were incurred as a result of opening these new offices in Queensland.
(5) How many additional staff now work for the DSS across Australia compared with the years prior to July 1989.
(6) How many more people were employed by the DSS to operate these new premises over the past 4 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) New offices are opened to improve service delivery to clients in newly developing and previously unserviced locations. Factors taken into account are:-
(a) existing and projected client numbers;
(b) the availability and cost of suitable office accommodation in the proposed locality;
(c) infrastructure requirements such as access to public transport links, banks, and other community services; and
(d) wherever possible, co-location with other Government services, such as offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service.
(2) The costs for setting up each new office in Queensland for the past 4 years, including fixtures, office equipment and public announcements concerning the new service, were:-
(3) All 21 new offices opened in Queensland since 1 January 1989 are housed in premises leased from the private sector.

(4) In most instances, the transfer of staff to new offices in Queensland in the period concerned was cost neutral, due to the close proximity of the new offices to the offices from which staff were relocated. However, transfer costs amounting to $99,943 were incurred in total in respect of new offices opened in remote localities in Queensland in the period.

Training costs incurred in establishing the new offices were minimised by the transfer of experienced staff from one office to another. Where this was not possible, additional training costs of $97,668 were incurred.
(5) Total staffing in DSS has changed from the 1988-89 figure of 17,051 as follows:
1989-90: reduction of 501 or 2.9%
1990-91: increase of 1,385 or 8.4%
1991-92: increase of 1,135 or 6.3%
1992-93: increase of 1,347 or 7.1%

ANSWER.PARA: The total increase in staffing over this period was 3,366 or 19.7%, to the present total of 20,417 staff.

PARA.TAB: (6) An additional 47.32 staff were employed to operate the new offices opened in Queensland in the period.
Additional staff have been employed in both new and existing offices according to changes in client populations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is the Department of Social Security (DSS) advertising to attract new clientele and using devices such as supplying paper inlays for plastic trays used in Hungry Jack's restaurants.
(2) How much money has been spent in the past 3 financial years on advertising and merchandising activities to expand the client base of DSS.
(3) How much money was spent on the services of advertising agencies in the past 3 financial years and what agencies were involved.
(4) How much was spent on Hungry Jack's paper inlay scheme and what were the details of this expenditure.
(5) What research has been done to assess the effect of the Hungry Jack's project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department has an obligation to ensure that people are aware of Social Security payments they may be entitled to receive. Promotion in fast food outlets has been found to be an effective way of reaching the target audience of low income families with children (ie. those eligible for Family Allowance Supplement (FAS)). The promotion formed part of a larger campaign to promote FAS prior to the introduction of Family Payment on 7 January 1993.
(2) Details of expenditure on advertising and merchandising to encourage those who may be eligible to DSS payments to test their eligibility over the past three financial years total $2,141,134.44.
(3) Money spent on services of advertising agencies in the last three financial years totals $594,872.39.
The names of the agencies were:
Clemeger (Melbourne);
Grey Advertising (Canberra);
Hambleton Ruff (Melbourne); and
Young and Rubicam (Sydney)

(4) A total of $22,200 was spent on the design and printing of tray liners for Hungry Jack's store. These funds represented printing ($18,700), artwork/typesetting ($1,500) and film separation ($2,000). A total of 1.1 million tray liners were printed and distributed to 106 stores across the country. These tray liners were used for eight weeks during October and November 1992. There was no fee paid to Hungry Jack's for the promotion. The service was offered as a community service activity sponsored by Hungry Jack's.

(5) Because of the introduction of TeleService Centres, unprecedented demand for services and technical problems at the time of the promotion, accurate figures of the effect of the promotion are not available. However, all indications are that it was very successful. In Western Australia a two for one burger offer was included on tray liners and 47,000 vouchers were returned as part of this offer (DSS paid no cost for this special offer).

A similar type of promotion occurred in McDonalds stores in mid 1990 in Victoria. Evaluation of that promotion showed that an average of 82 calls a day were received as a result of the promotion. More than 70 per cent of the callers were eligible for either full or part rate FAS. Favourable comments about the use of food tray liners as a means of promotion of FAS were also received.

The Hungry Jack's promotion received extensive media coverage in Western Australia and Queensland (states with a large concentration of Hungry Jack's stores) increasing the reach of the message beyond those who dined in Hungry Jack's stores.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Small Business, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) researching methods of preventing termite damage to buildings in Australia; if so: (a) what are the details of all research projects involving attempts or successful experiments to control, prevent and/or exterminate termite infestations; (b) for each research project, what is the name of the researcher and the section of the CSIRO conducting it; (c) for each research project, what are the details of funding received by CSIRO, including the source of the funding; and (d) are some of the CSIRO researchers engaged in research of termite control or extermination methods as specified in (b) competing for funds with each other.

(2) If CSIRO researchers are competing for funds with each other, are they in a conflict of interest situation when advising on alternative methods already available, or about to become available, to control or exterminate termites other than those which they are researching.
(3) If CSIRO researchers are not competing for funds with each other, why are they not in a situation of conflict of interest.

(4) Are CSIRO researchers permitted to provide privately paid consultancy services; if so: (a) for whom have CSIRO researchers consulted on matters concerning termite control methods; and (b) who were the CSIRO researchers who provided private consultancies on matters concerning termite control.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The CSIRO Divisions of Entomology and Forest Products have been engaged for many years in research to protect wood and wood products from wood-destroying insects, particularly termites. The latter insects are the major cause of attack and damage to timber-in-service.
(a) The termite projects currently undertaken by the Division of Entomology are:
Improved baiting techniques for control of termites.
The evaluation of chemical and certain physical soil barriers to replace organochlorine insecticides (= cyclodienes) for protecting buildings.
The assessment of plastics and other materials for resistance to termite attack.
The use of the fungus Metarhizium as a biological control agent for termites.
The use of entomopathogenic nematodes as biocontrol agents against termites.
The Division of Forest Products termite projects are:

Evaluating granite particles, commercially marketed under the name "Granitgard", as a potential physical barrier against subterranean termites when retrofitted around existing buildings. Granitgard has already been accepted as an alternative termite barrier to chemical barriers in the protection of new buildings in all regions of Australia below the Tropic of Capricorn and has been incorporated into the revised Australian termite standard.

Working closely with members of the pest control industry in developing novel baiting techniques in termite control in which the emphasis is on environmentally acceptable strategies, and the minimum use of chemicals in the environment.
Evaluation and screening of chemicals that may prove suitable candidates as termite attractants when incorporated into termite bait systems.
Developing and screening new chemical formulations that may prove suitable as bait toxicants.

Evaluation of inclusion compounds as an alternative treatment to arsenic trioxide. The inclusion compounds have a similar mode of action as arsenic trioxide, but have negligible human toxicity. Commercialisation is expected later this year.

Laboratory and field evaluations of novel wood preservatives which are more environmentally acceptable. In addition, the evaluation of diffusible solid rod preservatives for remedial wood preservation.
Research into principles of laboratory and field techniques for the evaluation of wood preservatives and termiticides.
Evaluation of wood fibre/cement composites against termites.
Research into interaction of decay and termites in determination of natural durability of native and exotic timbers.
Panel products preservation.
Developing practical procedures in the non-destructive detection of termites in buildings using acoustical emission techniques.

(b) In the CSIRO Division of Entomology Dr Tony Watson, Dr Michael Lenz, and Mr Leigh Miller are involved in all the termite projects. In addition, Dr Richard Milner and Ms Judy Staples are involved in the project on Metarhizium and Dr Robin Bedding is involved in the project with nematodes.
In the CSIRO Division of Forest Products, Dr J R J French is involved in the first five projects listed above and Mr J W Creffield is conducting research in the other projects.
(c) Total external funding received by the Division of Entomology for work on termite control is currently around $150,000 per annum.

External funds received by the Division of Forest Products for work on termite control is approximately $100,000 per annum. Details of industrial funding sources and the work involved is subject to confidentiality agreements.

(d) The termite research of the Divisions of Forest Products and Entomology do not overlap, but may be viewed as complementary when considering the broad area of termite attack and damage, and the Divisions' major clients are the chemical and wood preservation, and the pest control industries.

The research in the Division of Entomology involves the development of biological methods of termite control using fungal pathogens and nematodes for a number of termite species and the use of improved baiting systems and killing agents against Mastotermes and Coptotermes particularly in Northern Australia. Studies are also being carried out on the use of a range of chemical and physical soil barriers as an alternative to cyclodiene insecticide to protect buildings and other structures from termites and the ability of selected plastics and other synthetic materials to withstand termite attack. Research being carried out by the Division of Forest Products is centred around the ability of timber and timber preservatives to withstand termite attack, plus some work on granite chip barriers and baits for termite control.

Both Divisions participate in joint field trips and perform collaborative research between the two laboratories and overseas termite researchers (for example, principles of test methodology for laboratory and field techniques).

(2) The CSIRO researchers do not compete with each other for funds, rather they complement each other's research efforts. Communications between each Division are frequent, and areas of research are discussed and understood. In fact, researchers from each Division are currently engaged in a collaborative research project on termites in Thailand with the Thai Department of Forestry, funded by the Australian Centre for International Agriculture Research. Advice to the general public involves options, and considering the wide range of research being undertaken by both Divisions, conflict of interests is not an issue. The working relationship between the two Divisions is seen as interactive, rather than competitive.
(3) See answer to (2) above.
(4) CSIRO staff are not permitted to provide private paid consultancy services [CSIRO Terms and Conditions of Employment (Para 21 & 23)].

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 2368 (Senate Hansard, 25 November 1992, p3542):

(1) Why have company names not been included in the answer when in an answer to an identical Question on Notice No. 300 (Senate Hansard, 21 December 1990, p6380) asked by Senator Vallentine, company names were included.
(2) What precisely are the items described as `white phosphorus filled metal', and are they intended for use in Singapore, or for on—selling to another country.
(3) How does the limited disclosure of defence exports fit in with the Minister's support for the creation of a United Nations register of arms sales, as indicated in the Age of 27 June 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since answering Senator Vallentine's question in 1990 I have accepted arguments by exporters that disclosure of company names could disclose information provided in confidence and could unduly prejudice their commercial interests.

(2) White phosphorus filled metal is a substance used to fill 81mm mortar bomb shells which, when exposed to the air, gives off a very thick white smoke. The goods are intended for the use of the Singapore Defence Forces, Singapore, who have certified that they will not authorise the transfer of the goods to another country (unless for use by their own armed forces) without the prior written approval of myself or an authorised delegate.

(3) As indicated in the Age of 27 June 1991 the Australian Government fully supports the United Nations arms register. The establishment of such a register of conventional arms transfers under the auspices of the United Nations will enhance the transparency of such transfers and aid in the reduction of the illicit arms trade and in regional confidence building. Australia has advised the United Nations about its sales of major items of military equipment in accordance with the United Nations resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the report in the ANU Reporter of 27 May 1992, of an interview with Professor David Lea, in which it is stated, amongst other things, that conventional aid is not working, as is evidenced by the fact that the poorest people in poor countries are getting poorer, much of the Third World's accumulated debt is a direct result of foreign aid and loans from the World Bank and regional development banks and `privileged elites are not really interested in any change'.
(2) Is Professor Lea's assessment of the aid malaise accurate.
(3) Will directing more aid through non-government agencies better serve the poor.
(4) What proportion of Australia's aid and development budget is administered by non-government agencies.
(5) Will a greater proportion of Australia's aid and development budget be targeted to small scale projects managed by those people who are the intended beneficiaries of the projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) No. Professor Lea's assessment of the so-called aid malaise, while well-meaning, is out-dated and inaccurate.

Professor Lea argues that aid has failed to alleviate poverty because its essential purpose is to preserve a system which damages the interests of the poor and supports privileged elites. These arguments had more validity in the past but aid programs now, including the Australian aid program, pay greater attention to poverty alleviation.

In the post-Cold War period, there is widespread recognition that poverty alleviation is a global priority. Poverty alleviation is now a major theme in the work of multilateral development organisations such as the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program. The links between sustainable development, environmental issues and poverty reduction are highlighted in Agenda 21, the internationally agreed plan of action arising from the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
Professor Lea asserts that the poorest countries and the poor within many countries are getting poorer. This also is misleading.

From 1960 to 1990, key human development indicators for the least developed countries, that is the very poorest countries, have shown considerable improvement. Average life expectancy has increased from 39 years in 1960 to 51 years in 1990. Infant mortality has decreased from 170 per 1000 live births to 114 per 1000 in 1991. The percentage of people with access to clean drinking water has risen from 21 percent in 1975 to 47 percent in 1990. Adult literacy has increased from 29 percent in 1970 to 45 percent in 1990. Real GDP per capita has increased from $580 in 1960 to $740 in 1990, based on measures of purchasing power parity.
Professor Lea argues that much of the Third World's accumulated debt is a direct result of foreign aid and loans from the World Bank and other regional banks. This is not the case.

The fact is that many developing countries borrowed large amounts from private banks during the 1970s and early 1980s. When real interest rates rose dramatically in the early 1980s, debt-servicing became a major problem for many developing countries. This, in turn, substantially reduced the ability of developing countries to attract private financial resources.

As a result, private financial flows to developing countries fell from a high of 52 percent of net financial flows in 1980 to 34 percent in 1987. At the same time, official development assistance (ODA) flows to developing countries increased from 29 percent of net financial flows in 1980 to 54 percent in 1987. Thus foreign aid had a critical role in underpinning resource flows to developing countries in this period.

Loans from the World Bank's International Development Association (IDA) to eligible developing countries are highly concessional, with no interest charges and 40-50 years to pay back the loan, including a ten year grace period. IDA further helps severely indebted countries, particularly in Africa and South America, through its debt-reduction and debt-servicing facility. The Asian Development Bank's soft-lending arm, the Asian Development Fund (ADF), is also highly concessional.

(3) Providing aid through non-government organisations (NGOs) is one way of directly meeting the needs of the poor. However, NGOs alone are not the answer to poverty. Helping the poor requires a combination of strategies. While small-scale, localised activities directed specifically at the poor have an important role, they also need to be accompanied by measures which result in increased economic activity, improved services and better infrastructure.

(4) In 1991-92, 4.5 percent of Australia's aid budget was administered by NGOs. In 1992-93, the proportion was approximately 5.7 percent. This compares to 2 percent in 1983-84, 2.6 percent in 1987-88 and 4.3 percent in 1989-90.

(5) Australia's aid to individual developing countries is based on the needs and requests of recipient governments, and Australia's capacity to assist. This results in a mix of activities, some small-scale and some large, which varies from country to country. There is no merit in deciding at the outset that a certain proportion of Australia's total aid budget will be earmarked for small-scale projects.

The question of people's participation extends far beyond small-scale activities. The obstacles to the full participation of women in development remain one of the greatest development challenges. For this reason, women's needs are taken into account in the planning and implementation of all Australian aid activities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has a formal agreement been signed between the United States of America (US) and Australia concerning US use of the Delamere bombing range; if so, will the agreement be made public; if not, when will one be concluded.
(2) What impact will the extra bombing activity have on the environment of the area.
(3) What extra preparation and repair costs will be incurred by the Australian Government as a result of US use of the bombing range.

(4) What implications are contingent on US use of the bombing range in the following areas: (a) the number of US aircraft landings on Australian soil; (b) accommodation or residence of US military personnel; and (c) permanent US support facilities and staff in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no formal agreement between the US and Australia that specifically relates to US use of the Delamere Air Weapons Range (DAWR), or other Air Weapons Ranges (AWR).
There is no intention to conclude a specific agreement in the future.
US access to the DAWR is provided for under two logistics agreements:
Cooperative Defence Logistics Support Agreement
Cross Servicing Agreement

These agreements allow either country to charge the other for services provided to support the other's armed forces. The use of AWRs for training is included in the types of services covered by these agreements.

(2) An Environmental Management Plan for RAAF Base Tindal (including the DAWR) was prepared in 1987 by Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd for the Department of Defence, and the RAAF is committed to that environmental plan. This plan minimises the damage arising from bombing activities and ensures repairs are carried out at the conclusion of a bombing program. Any environmental impact arising from US bombing activity will be minimal.
(3) As US activity on the range will be on a full cost recovery basis no extra preparation or repair costs will be incurred by the Australian Government as a result.

(4) (a) There is likely to be some increase in the number of US tactical aircraft visits to Australia as a result of the DAWR facility being offered to foreign countries, in line with the Government's policy of furthering defence cooperation with its allies and regional neighbours. While there is some foreign interest in the use of the DAWR, it is too early at this stage to quantify any likely additional foreign use of the range. US aircraft will operate primarily from RAAF Base Darwin when using the DAWR. To a lesser extent they will also operate from RAAF Tindal and from US ships. The US will pay for any services Australia provides to support these operations.

(b) While some limited on-base accommodation may be provided at Darwin on a full cost recovery basis, US military personnel will almost always be accommodated in private hotels during periods when they are using the DAWR.
(c) There are no plans for the establishment of permanent US support facilities and staff in Australia in support of DAWR activities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the management information system APPOINT, which was designed and implemented by the Office of the Status of Women (OSW) to provide a method of storing and retrieving information about the memberships of committees and other groups:
(1) When is the report of the APPOINT system on the progress towards an increased number and percentage of female appointments to committees and other groups to be made available.
(2) Have quarterly reports on equal opportunity appointments been provided to OSW by each Government department since the inception of the APPOINT system in 1991.
(3) Which Government departments have failed, either in part or in total, to provide these quarterly reports to OSW.
(4) How many progress reports have been provided by OSW to the Prime Minister and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women on equal opportunity appointments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The second report on the progress of female appointments to committees and other groups will be available in early July.
(2) Due to resource constraints some departments have not responded on a quarterly basis.

(3) Two departments have never provided APPOINT reports to OSW. These departments are the Department of Finance which declined to use APPOINT; and the Attorney-General's Department which has a system similar to APPOINT. The following departments have, at times, not provided a report to OSW:
Defence
Employment, Education and Training
Foreign Affairs and Trade
Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
Industry, Technology and Commerce
Primary Industries and Energy
Prime Minister and Cabinet
Social Security
Transport and Communications
Treasury
Veterans' Affairs.
(4) An Initial APPOINT Report was provided in November 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Register of Women, a database maintained by the Office of the Status of Women (OSW) since 1987 for Commonwealth Ministers and departments as a source of names for possible appointment to committees, boards and authorities:
(1) Have any reports been produced on the performance of the Register of Women.
(2) Have any records been kept on the number of appointments where a Government Minister or Department has referred to the Register of Women before making the appointment.
(3) Are there any ways by which the performance of the Register of Women is, or can be, monitored.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) OSW does not currently produce formal reports on the performance of the Register of Women.

(2) Records are kept on the number of searches requested by Departments. However, to date, OSW has not been able to keep full records on the number of women appointed through reference to the Register of Women.

OSW has recently installed a new Register of Women database, and data is currently being transferred onto this system. This replaces an outdated system which had limited capacity and diversity. From the new system OSW will be able to store and retrieve data pertaining to the name and number of women appointed through it.

When the system is running smoothly OSW will contact all Women's Desk Officers asking them to actively promote the Register in their Department to encourage use of the system. Departments will also be requested to provide information on appointments where the Register of Women has been used to provide names.
(3) Ongoing monitoring has been built into the new system. OSW will be producing monthly reports on the number of searches requested by Departments, and the number of subsequent appointments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Affairs and Trade: Appointment of Women

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:
(1) How many positions were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(2) How many of these positions were held by women on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(3) What changes do the resulting proportions represent since the Labor Caucus motion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of both the Minister for Trade and myself, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Table 1 provides information on the representation of women on boards, councils and committees to which Ministers responsible for the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio appoint members. Data is presented for 1989 (the earliest year for which data is readily available), 1992 (the latest year for which data is readily available) and the percentage change between these years.

ANSWER.PARA: The information in Table 1 shows that:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1989, 141 positions were available for appointment; in 1992, 217 positions were available; the resulting change is an increase of 76 over the period.
(2) Of these positions in 1989, 24 (17 per cent) were held by women; in 1992, 39 (18 per cent) were held by women.
(3) The change between 1989 and 1992 is an increase of 15 in the total number of positions held by women. This represents an increase of 1 per cent over the period.

ANSWER.PARA: Table 1: Comparison of proportion of women on boards, councils and committees, 1989 and 1992
(1)Earliest readily available data is for October 1989.
(2) Latest readily available data is for 1991-92 financial year. Data will be updated at 30 June 1993 and reported in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Annual Report, 1992-93.
(3) Members are appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
(4)Members are nominated by the Director General of AIDAB and the Australian Council for Overseas Aid.
(5)There were no female members of the Austrade Board on 21/8/88.
Source: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Annual Report 1991-92, AGPS, Canberra.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training: Appointment of Women

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Appointment of Women

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:
(1) How many positions were available on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(2) How many of these positions were held by women on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(3) what changes do the resulting proportions represent since the Labor Caucus motion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2)—see table below.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:
(1) How many positions were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(2) How many of these positions were held by women on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(3) What changes do the resulting proportions represent since the Labor Caucus motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The number of positions that were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and are now available, for the relevant bodies, are as follows:-
(2) The number of positions held by women on 21 August 1988 and now held, for the relevant bodies, are as follows:-
(3) The changes since the Labor Caucus Motion represented by the resulting proportions are as follows:-
The following information is also relevant:

The Australian Institute of Family Studies comes within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Social Security. However, members of the Board of Management of the Institute are appointed by the Governor-General. There are currently two women members on the board of seven.
Until June 1989 the Australian Institute of Family Studies came under the portfolio of the Attorney-General.

In 1988 the Minister for Social Security nominated members of two Committees of the Social Welfare Research Centre: the Research Management Committee and the Advisory Committee. However, members were appointed by the University of New South Wales.
In 1988 the Research Management Committee consisted of four members, one of whom was a woman, while the Advisory Committee consisted of eleven members, one being a woman.

The centre has now become the Social Policy Research Centre and these two Committees have been replaced by a seven member management board. Presently two members of the seven are women. Three members are appointed by the Minister for Social Security and one of these at present is a woman. The remaining three positions are nominated and appointed by the University of New South Wales with the Director of the Centre being an ex officio member.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:
(1) How many positions were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(2) How many of these positions were held by women on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(3) What changes do the resulting proportions represent since the Labor Caucus motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) 407 positions were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and 217 are now available.
(2) 17 of the 407 positions or 4.2% were held by women on 21 August 1988 and 14 of the 217 positions or 6.5% are now held by women.
(3) This 2.3 percentage point increase represents a 54% gain in the proportion of positions held by women since 21 August 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labor Caucus motion of 21 August 1988 requiring women to be appointed to at least 25 per cent of places on Government boards, councils and committees, for each of the boards, councils and committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, and for all of these combined:
(1) How many positions were available for appointment on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(2) How many of these positions were held by women on 21 August 1988 and are now available.
(3) What changes do the resulting proportions represent since the Labor Caucus motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) Board of Directors. On 21 August 1988, there were nine (9) positions available on the ATC's Board of Directors. Nine (9) positions are still available.

Bureau of Tourism Research (BTR) Advisory Council. There is no limit on the number of positions on the BTR Advisory Council. There were eight members on the Advisory Council as at 21 August 1988. Three of these were Ministerial appointees. The other members were nominees of the Australian Standing Committee on Tourism (2), the Australian Tourism Industry Association (ATIA), the ATC and the former Department of the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories.

Tourism Advisory Council. There are no limits to the number of appointments that may be made to the Tourism Advisory Council. As at 21 August 1988 there were twenty-two (22) positions on the Council comprising fifteen (15) industry organisations, four (4) union positions and three (3) personal appointments.
(2) ATC Board of Directors. On 21 August 1988, one (1) position was held by a woman. In 1992, three (3) women were on the Board of the ATC.
BTR Advisory Council. One position on the Advisory Council was held by a woman on 21 August 1988. This was a Ministerial appointment and the appointee remains a member of the Advisory Council.

Tourism Advisory Council. There was one Council position held by a woman on 21 August 1988. Two positions were occupied by women during 1993, one of whom was a Ministerial appointment. The appointee remained a member of the Tourism Advisory Council until her death earlier this year.
(3) ATC Board of Directors. The representation of women on the ATC Board has increased from 11.1 per cent in 1988 to 33.3 per cent in 1992.
BTR Advisory Council: no change (33.3 per cent of positions Minister appoints).

Tourism Advisory Council: The representation of women on the Tourism Advisory Council, in terms of the positions to which the Minister can appoint, has increased from zero per cent in 1988 to 33.3 per cent in 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Can a copy of the Nursing Home Fees Control Manual be provided; if not, why not; if so, please provide.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Nursing Home Fees Control Manual has been specified in a statement made under section 9 of the Freedom of Information Act and is therefore available for public release except where it contains exempt material.

A copy of Parts 1, 2, 4 and 5 of the Manual has been provided to the honourable senator. Parts 1 and 2 contain a consolidated description of current and previous funding arrangements, while Parts 4 and 5 contain a list of Departmental circulars and an index, respectively.
I shall not be providing a copy of Part 3 of the Manual, which is exempt from disclosure under paragraphs 37(1)(a), 37(2)(b), 40(1)(a), 40(1)(b) and 40(1)(c) of the Freedom of Information Act.

The Manual is an internal document of which Part 3 describes the procedures Departmental staff are to follow when processing nursing homes fees and the annual reconciliation forms (NH20 form) and includes instructions for using the Nursing Homes Payments computer system.

The public release of this document would allow a person who gained illegal access to the Department's Nursing Homes Payments computer system to interfere with the correct and legal payment of nursing home benefits.
Therefore access to the information contained in Part 3 may put the Department at risk from possible computer fraud.

I should point out that the decisions taken and the procedures followed by Departmental staff, when processing fees and the NH20 form, are set out in the National Health Act 1953 and Nursing Homes Financial Arrangements Principles 1989 and also in the Department of Finance Regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has General Motors USA shelved plans to continue the development of the electric car known as the `Impact'.
(2) Does Australia have the institutional capacity to lead the world in the development of electric vehicle technology to fill this void.
(3) Will continued reliance on internal combustion powered vehicles result in an overall reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

(4) Do vehicles running on compressed natural gas use up to double the amount of fuel to achieve the same tonne/kilometres result; if so, are exhaust emissions from such vehicles which contribute to the problem known as `global warming' accordingly increased.
(5) How much revenue from Federal fuel levies has the Government collected since the release of its Energy 2000 report in 1988.
(6) How much of this revenue has been spent on electric vehicle research and development.
(7) How much of this revenue has been allocated to the development of Australian energy storage technology since 1988.
(8) Does the Government plan to increase funding research into energy storage.
(9) How many kilometres per day does the average Australian urban motorist travel.
(10) Would an electric passenger commuter car, with a range of 1OOkm, prove adequate for the day-to-day needs of the majority of urban dwelling Australians.

(11) What action is the Government taking to investigate the potential for developing Australian electric vehicle technology in order to supply a future domestic or overseas electric vehicle industry with component parts.
(12) What is the energy source which most motorists likely will use to power their cars in 2025.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) GM has announced that it has put on hold its plans for high volume production. However, development work will continue.

(2) No. It is not clear how large a void GM's announcement will leave. GM will remain involved in electric vehicle development, as will other motor vehicle manufacturers in the US, Japan and Europe. The resources that these companies are dedicating to electric vehicle development are far larger than those available in Australia. Nevertheless, Australia could have a role as a component supplier.

(3) While there is considerable scope to improve the efficiency of internal combustion powered vehicles, it is not clear whether this is sufficient, or will be attained sufficiently rapidly, to-off set growth in global vehicle numbers.
(5) I refer the Honourable Senator to Table B. l: Commonwealth Government Budget Revenue (p4.55) in the Budget Statements 1992-93.

(6) Revenue collected from fuel excise is not hypothecated to energy research and development. Commonwealth funding for energy research and development takes two forms; indirect, through the internal allocation of resources in research institutions such as CSIRO and universities; and direct, primarily through the Energy Research and Development Corporation. Up-to-date information on the level of indirect funding is not available. Since 1988, the Energy Research and Development Corporation (and its predecessor, the National Energy Research and Development Council) has invested $296,581 in electric vehicle R&D.
(7) Since 1988, the Energy Research and Development Corporation (and its predecessor) has invested $1,069,956 in energy storage technology R&D.

(8) Energy storage is one of the priorities of the "Draft Research Strategy for Renewable Energy Sources and Systems" developed by the Energy Research and Development Corporation and currently being discussed with industry.

(9) There is no national data how many kilometres per day the average urban motorist travels. Those passenger cars which travelled in capital cities in 1991, averaged some 30 kilometres a day. US data shows that, for first cars, 75% of all trips involve distances of less than 80 km, while for second cars, 90% of all trips are less than 40 km.

(10) While an electric passenger commuter vehicle with a range of 100 kilometres would prove adequate for the needs of the majority of urban motorists on a majority of days, it would not be adequate for their needs on all days, especially week-ends.

(11) The Government provides support for energy R&D through a mechanism which has been designed to be responsive to the needs of industry and the community as a whole. This will help ensure that public funds are directed towards those areas which will provide maximum benefits to Australians. This mechanism provides a framework in which industry can take advantage of commercial opportunities to become involved in any emerging electric vehicle manufacturing industry.

(12) 2025 is sufficiently far away that we can only speculate. There are massive uncertainties about the rate of technical progress and the magnitude of environmental issues that may have to be addressed. Current indications, however, are that fuels for road transport will be largely petroleum based.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Wetlands Conservation Society of Western Australia nominate the Beeliar Wetlands for inclusion on the register of the National Estate in 1985.
(2) What action has been undertaken by the Australian Heritage Commission to process this nomination.
(3) Why has there been a delay of 8 years in processing this nomination.
(4) Has there been any action by an agency of the Western Australian Government which has led to this delay.

(5) What action will be taken to ensure the finalisation of this issue and ensure the protection of this important wetland area, which is now one of the few remaining wetland areas on the Swan Coastal Plain.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Assessment of the nomination is nearly complete. The Commission has comprehensively reviewed all available published and unpublished documents relating to the area, and consulted experts in a number of fields. Information has been obtained from the WA Museum, the Department of Planning and Urban Development and its predecessor the State Planning Commission, the Department of Conservation and Land Management, Murdoch University, the WA Environment Protection Authority, the Royal Australasian Ornithological Union, Alcoa of Australia, the Water Authority of Western Australia and the Wetlands Conservation Society.

(3) As the Wetlands have not been the subject of any Commonwealth decision, and the State Government is moving towards the conservation of this area, processing of the Beeliar nomination has not been allocated a high priority. The Beeliar Wetlands is a large and complex nomination (2700 ha, consisting of two wetland chains, comprising some 22 separate wetlands or groups of wetlands). Investigation and validation of the claimed values, and selection of an appropriate boundary, has also been a complex and lengthy task.

(4) In June 1992 the Department of Planning and Urban Development provided comments on the Commission's draft assessment of the Beeliar Wetlands. Additional investigations were prompted by those comments.

(5) When assessment of the nomination is complete the wetlands will be considered by the Commission for entry in the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate. If the wetlands are entered in the Interim List, the protection provisions of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 will apply. The Beeliar Wetlands will be protected in the Beeliar Regional Park, which has been proposed by the State Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which companies have submitted an Intention to Register an Interest in the Research and Development function or the Specialised Food Production function at the Materials Research Laboratory.
(2) Was 2 April 1993 the advertised closing date to submit an expression of interest.
(3) Have the expressions of interest submitted by this date been evaluated.
(4) Has a decision been made from which companies to seek quotations; if so, which companies have been selected.
(5) Have two additional companies indicated a desire to register an interest since 2 April 1993; if so, has an extension of time been granted and is the new closing date 23 May 1993.
(6) Why was the closing date extended.
(7) Have other potential tenderers been notified of the extension to the closing date.
(8) Did the Minister, or the department, direct that the two additional expressions of interest be invited; if so, why.
(9) Were the original companies who registered an expression of interest considered unsuitable.
(10) What other companies have been invited to consider registering an interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Five organisations have submitted Registrations of Interest in the Research and Development function or the Specialised Food Production function at MRL Tasmania.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. It is practice, accepted by industry, that information on companies involved in a tendering process not be made available until the matter is one for the public record.

(5) Since 2 April 1993, three organisations have made enquiries about the functions being considered and the requirements for tendering. As at 7 June 1993, one of these organisations had forwarded a formal registration of interest. The closing date was not extended. Under the Commercial Support Program process the Invitation to Register Interest is used to provide comment on the Statement of Requirement with a view to refining it before the tendering process. Accordingly, late responses to the Invitation to Register Interest can be accepted provided the purchasing delegate is satisfied that no advantage is derived from the late acceptance.
(6) As indicated above, the closing date was not extended.
(7) As indicated above, the closing date was not extended.
(10) None. The only invitation to companies to consider registering an interest was the initial issue of the Request for Registration of Interest advertised on 17 February 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 24 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many students in receipt of Austudy have been investigated and subsequently found to be fraudulently claiming Austudy in the `independent category' in the past financial year.
(2) How many students in (1) were found to be still living at home with their parents.
(3) What action has been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) 9 students were found to be incorrectly claiming the `independent' rate in 1992/93.
(2) Details of the nine students' domestic arrangements are not readily available. Students may meet the `independent' criteria even if they live with their parents.

(3) As the amounts involved were below the level at which charges are usually laid, no client was prosecuted. However, the students' entitlements to assistance have been reassessed and recovery begun on debts totalling $14,625.
