(3) Volunteer Management Program
(4) The Community Organisations' Support Program (COSP) Standard Conditions of Grant, as follows:
In these conditions unless the contrary intention appears or the conditions otherwise require:
"Commonwealth" means the Commonwealth of Australia;
"Department" means the Commonwealth Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services;
"grant" means the provision of financial support for the project under the conditions;
"grantee" means the person, organisation, institution or body being the recipient of the grant;
"project" means the activity for which the grant has been approved; and
"Secretary" means the Secretary of the Department or authorised officer and includes any person who is for the time being performing the duties of the office of the Secretary of the Department.

1. These conditions apply to the provision of financial support by the Commonwealth under the COSP. The offer of grant, these conditions, the special conditions (if any) and the formal written acceptance of the grant, together form the contract governing the payment and use of the grant. The grantee shall observe the provisions of these standard conditions and such special conditions, if any, as are attached. The contract shall bind the grantee and the Commonwealth.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Written Acceptance of Conditions of Grant

PARA.TAB: 2. Prior to any grant payment being made, a Letter of Acceptance of the conditions of the grant shall be signed by the Chairperson/President, Secretary or Treasurer of the recipient body and returned to the Department.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Limitations on the Use of Grant Funds

PARA.TAB: 3. The grant is made to the grantee specifically for the purpose and costs described in this contract.
4. The prior approval, in writing, of the Secretary is required to vary the purpose or any condition of the grant.

5. If the grant is used for any other purpose, without the prior approval of the Secretary, the grant may be revoked and thereupon the grantee will be required to repay to the Department all unexpended funds received under the grant and shall be liable to pay to the Department a sum equal to the moneys from this or any previous grants which have been expended for unauthorised purposes.
6. Funds which are not used within a prescribed period of time, as stipulated in the Letter of Offer, may be offset against a subsequent grant payment or be required to be repaid to the Department.
7. The grantee shall advise the Department of any other funds that it is receiving, or is expecting to receive, for the same purpose.
8. The grantee shall not make a loan, gift or donation from grant funds, other than in accordance with this contract.

9. The grantee shall not sub-contract or divest itself of a project without the Secretary's approval and without applying to the sub-contractor the same conditions which were applied in the original contract.
10. The project shall be commenced as soon as practicable after agreement to the conditions of grant.

11. If for any reason the grantee is unable to commence or continue work on the project or forms the opinion that progress will be significantly retarded, the grantee shall immediately notify the Department in writing and consult with the Department about terminating the grant or otherwise dealing with the matter.

12. If the project cannot be completed by the date specified in the Letter of Offer, a request for an extension, in writing must be submitted to the Department at least one month before the specified completion date or such other time as agreed.
13. As and when required by the Department the grantee shall co-operate or participate in the evaluation of the project's activities.

14. The grantee shall keep such records as will allow separate identification of the grant from other income and enable expenditure to be verified. The grantee shall permit these records to be inspected and the project to be visited at any reasonable time by the Secretary.
15. Unless otherwise specified in the agreement grant payments will be made by quarterly instalments payable at the beginning of each quarter.

16. Within 30 days of the end of each quarter, the grantee shall forward to the Department in a form acceptable to the Department a cumulative (year-to-date) statement of cash receipts and payments relating to the project. For the purposes of this statement, a quarter shall mean any period of three calendar months ending on 30 September, 31 December, 31 March or 30 June of any relevant financial year.
17. Within 3 months of the end of each grant year the grantee should forward to the Department the following:
a) a statement of compliance signed by an authorised officer of the recipient organisation.
This statement shall set out whether:
i) the grant has been used for the purpose for which it was provided; and
ii) the conditions included in the agreement have been met; and

b) an audited Statement of Receipts and Payments, in respect of each grant, certified by a person qualified to be a member of a recognised accounting body in Australia and who is not a member, or a public officer of the association.
This statement shall also include:
i) receipts and payments and a balance sheet in respect of each grant; and
ii) certification that salaries and allowances paid to people employed under the grant are in accordance with award salary rates or the general rates in force at the institution.
18. If the requirements set out in the Conditions are not met by the due date to allow the satisfactory acquittance of the grant, further funding in respect of the grant will be withheld.

19. Any grant funds not expended or committed by the date specified in the conditions of the grant, shall be offset against any subsequent grant approval, or be required to be repaid to the Department (subject to any approved extension of the completion date).
20. The grantee shall submit a progress report of the project to the Department every six months, unless otherwise specified.

21. All project-related income which is generated through the application of the grant (eg. bank interest, fees for services provided under the grant, revenue from the sale of project material, conference fees received, etc.) shall be applied to the project and is to be fully disclosed in the required financial statements.

22. The grantee may transfer funds between expenditure item(s) by up to 20% of the approved allocation of funds. The Department shall be notified of any such variation as soon as practicable. No re-allocation of grant funds shall otherwise be made without the prior written concurrence of the Department.

23. The salary levels and allowances for the staffing establishment as detailed in the approved budget are to be based on award rates. Organisations are to ensure that award provisions are maintained to employees funded either wholly or in part by the Department.

24. If the project cannot be completed by the date specified a request for an extension, in writing, must be submitted to the Department, at least one month before the specified completion date or such other time as agreed.
25. Ownership of equipment purchased under a grant is vested in the grantee, unless stated otherwise in a special condition of grant.
26. Assets to be purchased by grant funds must be identified in the approved budget.

27. Disposal of real estate property acquired with grant funds during the term of the project and the use of any proceeds from such disposal requires the prior approval, in writing, of the Minister or his delegate.

28. In the event of the voluntary winding-up of an organisation during the term of the project, the disposal of assets acquired from grant funds requires the prior approval, in writing, of the Secretary, subject to the provisions under which the grantee is incorporated.
29. Details of the sale, disposal or write-off of any asset acquired with grant funds during the term of the project are to be included in the financial statements.
30. Assets purchased by an organisation with grant funds during the term of the project are to be insured unless specific exemption is given, in writing, by the Department.
31. A grant may be terminated if, in the opinion of the Minister:
the project is not being carried out with competence and diligence; or
the project is not being carried out in accordance with the contract; or
the grantee fails to provide information concerning administrative or financial aspects of the project in response to a reasonable request from the Department.
32. Upon completion of the project or termination of the grant, grant funds that have not been expended or committed for expenditure on the project shall be recoverable by the Department.
33. Any material produced with funds provided under these grant arrangements shall not be offered for sale without the prior written approval of the Secretary.
34. The grantee shall ensure that all materials produced which involve the use of grant funds, display due acknowledgment of the Department.
35. The grantee shall acknowledge Commonwealth funding in any formal public statement or in any printed material, the cost of which has been wholly or partly met from the allocation.
36. The grantee and its employees are not by virtue of this contract employees of the Commonwealth.
37. The Department accepts no liability for any debts incurred by the grantee.

38. The grantee indemnifies the Commonwealth and its employees from and against all action, claims, demands, costs and expenses (including the costs of funding or settling any action, claim or demand) made, sustained, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by or attributable to any injury to any person (including death) or damage to property which may arise from any action, event or omission during the carrying out of the project of the grantee, its employees or agents.

39. The grantee shall not purport to represent the Commonwealth in connection with the carrying out of the project and shall not be empowered to act on behalf of or to bind the Commonwealth in any respect.

40. Where premises are being leased and rental is being met wholly or partly under the grant, no person or organisation other than the grantee shall be permitted occupancy of any Commonwealth funded part of the premises without the concurrence of the Secretary including concurrence in the terms and conditions of such occupancy.

Where such concurrence is given and rent or other charges are made for such occupancy, any income from the rental shall be applied to the operating costs of the approved budget before the application of any Commonwealth allocation under these arrangements in respect of such costs.

41. Where a difference arises under these conditions or in relation to the project which the Department considers should be determined by arbitration, the matter shall be referred to a single arbitrator who shall be a person nominated by the President for the time being of the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory and the arbitration shall be governed by the laws relating to arbitration in force in the Australian Capital Territory.
42. These conditions shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the Australian Capital Territory.
43. Failure by the Commonwealth to enforce any provision of this Contract shall not be considered as a waiver by the Commonwealth of any right in respect of any such provision.
In addition some Special Conditions of Grant were imposed. That the organisations:
recognise and accept that there is no implied commitment for the Commonwealth to provide further funding beyond 30 June 1995;
include in each of their annual reports an acknowledgment of the Volunteer Management Program of the then Department of Health, Housing and Community Services;
agree to make available to the Department one copy of any resources or other documentation produced;
agree to take all possible steps to ensure self sufficiency by the end of the grant term on 30 June 1995;
agree to the Executive Officer and the President of the Association (or where this is not possible another nominee from the Committee of Management) attending Workshop in Canberra;
provide plans detailing how the priority areas will be addressed within one month of the date of the Workshop; and
provide detailed evaluation plans within one month of the date of the Workshop.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has the department decided to purchase the Point Perpendicular lighthouse and associated buildings and land on the Beecroft Peninsula.
(2) What is the expected cost of the proposed purchase.
(3) How will the purchase be funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) will install a new automated light at Point Perpendicular in February 1994. The existing Point Perpendicular lighthouse and associated buildings will then no longer be required by AMSA and AMSA has offered the site for sale to the Commonwealth. AMSA proposes only to retain sufficient land (some 200 square metres) for the new light and for a helipad for maintenance access.

The Department of Defence has decided to acquire the site because it is the only remaining parcel of land affected by measures protecting public safety of the Beecroft Naval Gunnery Range, not already in Defence ownership. Defence control of this property will facilitate management of the range and ensure continued public safety during weapons testing.

The range fully surrounds the site on the landward side and the only access to the site is through Defence property. On the seaward side the site is bounded by 85 metre cliffs. Defence ownership is not intended to change existing access arrangements for recreation purposes when the range is not in use. The lighthouse visitors' parking area is already on Defence property.

Most of the remainder of the Beecroft Peninsula was acquired from the NSW State Government in 1979, but the lighthouse site, an area of four hectares out of a total area of over 4000 hectares of Commonwealth land on the peninsula, has never previously been on the market.

The existing Defence lands on the Beecroft Peninsula are managed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Services under contract to Defence, at a cost of around $500,000 annually, under the general guidance of a draft land management plan developed in 1987, and now due for review. Review of this plan will take conservation and management of the lighthouse site into account.

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has informally expressed interest in developing a visitor's centre on this site and this use could be accommodated under lease after the site has been acquired.
(2) The asking price is $285,000, although I expect the Department may be negotiating further on price.
(3) The purchase will be funded from the 1993/94 Defence Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has any decision or instruction relating to the relocation of Newington Armament Depot been given; if so, what are the details; if not, when and how will a decision be made?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following discussions between relevant Ministers, I directed on 24 December 1992 that the Department of Defence commence planning immediately for the closure of Newington Armament Depot and the associated ammunition supply line between Kingswood and the anchorage in Sydney harbour, based on a timetable assuming Sydney will be successful in the bid for the 2000 Olympic Games. Should Sydney's Olympic bid be unsuccessful, the intention is still to vacate the depot and close the supply line, and to sell all or part of the site to the New South Wales Government or other bidders on the basis of a commercial decision. The precise timing for this can be decided after the International Olympic Committee decision in September 1993.

In clarifying the timing for closure of Newington, I further directed that an interdepartmental committee be set up, chaired by Defence, to examine and report to me on options for relocation of the depot and associated supply line. This committee should complete its report by the end of June 1993. I expect that the Government will then be in a position to decide the terms of a proposal for a new east coast armament complex (comprising a depot and a wharf) for submission to the statutory environmental impact assessment process prescribed under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act of 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Prime Minister received any reviews of alternative locations for the Newington Armament Depot which have been written since 1990?

(2) Have any such reviews adequately considered whether the relocation of Newington should be consistent with the possible future relocation of the Sydney fleet base to another east coast location, which under Government policy cannot include Jervis Bay; if so, will a proper evaluation of this matter be performed before Cabinet considers the proposed relocation of Newington Armament Depot?
(3) Have any reviews of relocation sites since 1990 adequately considered whether the northern focus of Australia's defence strategy requires an armament depot to be located north of Sydney?
(4) Will a proper evaluation of this matter be performed before Cabinet considers the proposed relocation of Newington Armament Depot?
(5) Which sites in or near Port Philip Bay have been evaluated in reviews of relocation sites since 1990?

(6) Did the evaluations of those sites highlight (a) that the Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) has expressed a strong interest in performing warship repair and maintenance; (b) that, within 20 years, most or all Australian warships will have been built by AMECON at Williamstown; (c) that AMECON will therefore be well placed to perform warship repair and maintenance well into the 21st century; and (d) the consequential logistics and security advantages of locating an armament depot in or around Port Philip Bay; if so, will a proper evaluation of these matters be performed before Cabinet considers the proposed relocation of Newington Armament Depot?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No review of alternative location for the Newington Armament Depot has been put to the Prime Minister or Cabinet since 1990. However, I received in 1992 an internal Department of Defence review, initiated at the direction of the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in October 1989. Subsequent to this internal review, I have directed that an Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) be set up to examine and report further on the issues associated with relocation of the armament depot and associated ammunition supply line. (See also answer to Senate Question on Notice number 291).

(2) The Government is cognizant, of course, that any relocation of Naval armament facilities should be consistent with the long term location of the east coast fleet base. Adequate and simultaneous consideration will be given to both matters.

(3) Strategic factors are always an important consideration in any proposed relocation of major defence facilities. In this case, notwithstanding the northern focus of Australia's defence strategy and the consequential imperative to locate some operational bases in forward areas, Government endorsed strategic guidance confirms the need for major bases, support facilities and training areas to be located in more southerly areas, less vulnerable to attack and close to essential Defence and civil support infrastructure. A critical function of the armament depot in question is to provide an Explosive Ordnance (EO) service to ships of the Royal Australian Navy. Such a service includes regular replacement of ammunition expended in practice, rotation of EO stocks for maintenance and removal of ammunition outfits from ships about to undergo major maintenance. All of these functions need to be carried out predominantly in a benign support environment prudently remote from the anticipated area of potential hostilities. Some EO, sufficient for short term operational needs, is indeed stored at or near the forward bases, but the requirement for a less vulnerable wholesale ammunition depot, more proximate to the primary support and training areas, is fundamental.
(4) Yes.
(5) Point Wilson, near Geelong, is the only Port Phillip Bay site identified for further consideration by the IDC.

(6) The warship repair and maintenance requirement is only one factor influencing EO transfers to and from the fleet. The fact that AMECON might be well placed to perform such work is acknowledged but, similarly, it is Government policy to seek value for money through open and effective competition. Hence Navy does not envisage awarding any one organisation exclusive rights to all east coast repair and maintenance work. With regard to any security or strategic advantages of Port Phillip Bay, it should also be noted that the entrance and approaches to that bay would be difficult to protect from mining in the event of hostilities. All such factors will be taken into account during the Government's evaluation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What current employment and training programs are there specifically for older unemployed people.
(2) How much is expended annually on each of these programs for older people.
(3) How many older unemployed people receive assistance through these programs each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) There are two broad groups of employment and training programs:
labour market programs; and
entry-level training programs.

Except for the Landcare and Environment Action Program and the Accredited Training for Youth Program, which are specifically targeted to unemployed youth, no labour market program is targeted exclusively to any specific age group.

Entry-level training programs such as traineeships and apprenticeships are directed primarily at younger people, but the Commonwealth does not set age limits which would exclude older participants. In practice very few older people participate in entry-level training programs.
(2) and (3) Commencements of clients aged 50 and over on DEET Labour Market Programs in 1992/93, to 31 May 1993 are:

With the exception of the JOBSTART wage subsidy program, it is not possible to determine the share of total expenditure which goes to clients aged 50 and over. Expenditure on JOBSTART in 1992/93, to 31 May 1993, for clients aged 50 and over is $14.5m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Western Australian Government's proposed re-routing of a powerline from Manjimup to Beenup through high conservation value old-growth Karri forest in the south-west of Western Australia:
(1) How much of this forest has been (a) nominated for entry on the Register of the National Estate; (b) listed on an interim basis on the Register, or (c) has been entered on the Register.

(2) Given that the National Forest Policy recognises the significance of old-growth forest and requires protection of identified areas of high conservation value, what steps will be taken to protect this forest, which would be destroyed or degraded by the construction of the powerline.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Approximately 25 kilometres of the 114 kilometre Manjimup to Beenup transmission line route traverses an area which is proposed to be listed on the Register of the National Estate.
(b) None.
(c) None.

The area proposed to be listed on the Register of the National Estate traversed by the Manjimup route has been identified as having potential national estate significance because it contains undisturbed vegetation, diverse vegetation and a unique vegetation assemblage.

(2) Under the National Forest Policy Statement, State governments have adopted the policy of avoiding the clearing of public native forest for non-forest or plantation establishment wherever possible and, where this is not possible, ensuring that the clearing does not compromise regional conservation and catchment management objectives. Governments have also agreed to protect the nature conservation and catchment values of forests by ensuring that the activities of all agencies will be undertaken in accordance with effective and legally enforceable codes of practice, consistent with those currently applied to forest harvesting.

The Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 does not place any legal constraints on the actions of owners of private property or on State or local Governments. Only the actions of the Commonwealth Government are constrained if a place is on the Register of the National Estate. Therefore, while the Commission can provide State governments with advice concerning the protection of National Estate values, it is up to the State government to decide what it will do with this advice. The Commission has not been formally asked by the Western Australian Government to comment on the Manjimup route.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the number of elected officials of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in 1990-91 when the travel costs were $1,728,077.
(2) What was the number of elected officials in ATSIC using travel in 1991-92 when it was

QUESTION.PARA: mated that travel costs would be $5,060,000 and what was the final expenditure on travel for elected officials in that year.

PARA.TAB: (3) Why did the Commission's travel costs increase from $6.05 million in 1991 to $11.13 million in 1992, and what is the expected expenditure for 1993.
(4) What is the correct number of ATSIC elected officials and what is the estimated cost of their travel for the 1992-93 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following response to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) The number of elected officials in 1990-91, comprising Commissioners and Regional Councillors was 808.
(2) The number of elected officials in 1991-92 was in the order of 800. The final expenditure.on travel for ATSIC Commissioners and Regional Councillors in that year was $5.3m.

(3) The increase in the Commission's travel costs in 1991-92 over that for 1990-91 of some $5m is attributable mainly to full year costs of meetings of the newly elected Regional Councillors elected in November 1990. Regional Council travel costs amounted to $4.3m in 1991-92 compared with $1.05m for 1990-91 (part-year cost). The Commission's travel expenditure for 1992-93 is estimated at $12.4m.
(4) The number of elected officials as at 9 June 1993 was 786. The travel costs for Commissioners and Regional Councillors in 1992-93 is estimated at $5m.

ANSWER.PARA: No Regional No elected Commissioners Regional Total
Councillors Commissioners Total Travel Travel Total Travel

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What consideration has been given to contracting the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS) to perform the various research tasks that have been performed for the Office of the International Year of the Family (IYF) and why was it decided not to use the AIFS for this purpose.
(2) Why have two interdepartmental committees for the IYF been formed and did one committee replace the other; if so, why.

(3) With reference to an answer in Senate Estimates C, in which it was stated that to 19 April 1993, over $669 000 had been expended on salaries and administration in relation to the IYF, what has been achieved with this money.
(4) What are the details of the specific IYF projects on which the $127 000 had been spent up to 19 April 1993.

(5) With reference to the National Council of IYF: (a) what work has been done to date; (b) what work is the council currently doing; (c) how many times has it met; (d) is the position of chair a paid position; if so, how much is the chair of the Council paid and who is the chair.
(6) How much has the Commonwealth budgeted for the IYF initiative and what are the details of how and when this money will be spent.
(7) What changes have been made to the original budget for the IYF initiative, both in terms of the amount of money allocated to the program and when that money is, or was, to be spent.

(8) With reference to a draft IYF timeline which was provided to Senate Estimates C as attachment D to a letter of 6 February 1993 sent to Ms Tricia Harper from the First-Assistant Secretary of the Policy Development Division of the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services: (a) which, if any, of the items on that draft IYF timeline have been completed and when they were completed; (b) for any of the items that were not completed in accordance with the timeline, what are the reasons; (c) for any of the items that were due to be completed by June 1993 and are not yet completed, what are the reasons; and (d) if any of the items on the draft IYF timeline have been abandoned, what are the reasons.
(9) Please provide a copy of the latest timeframe for the implementation of the IYF initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Institute of Family Studies expertise in family related research studies is well understood by the Office of the International Year of the Family (IYF). Research related tasks commissioned to date have been awarded to other expert consultants because of their involvement in previous International Years; knowledge of State Government welfare programs; expertise in conducting national attitudinal qualitative market research; and/or experience and ability to undertake cost effective national market surveys.
(2) During 1992, IYF matters were referred to a small existing inter-departmental committee which had responsibility for co-ordination of Government response on a number of international issues.

In April, 1993 the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services established a broad based inter-departmental committee with specific responsibility for the development and co-ordination of the Federal Government's IYF activities. Matters on IYF are no longer handled by the previous committee.
(3) The following outcomes have been achieved:
development of a cross portfolio strategy for the 1993-94 Budget;

negotiations with each State and Territory resulting in the establishment of a Commonwealth-State/Territory Officials Working Group to co-ordinate inter-government activities, preparation of discussion papers on national communications and a national grants program and endorsement of the broad themes for the Year;
preparation for the establishment of the National Council for IYF and material for speaking appointments by the Council Chair; and
commissioning of a number of research related projects to assist in the development of a plan of action for the Year.

(4) Consultancies related to the development of strategic directions for the Year ($38,595), consultations with NGO's on family related issues ($22,586), and communication planning ($8,877), printing of the report for the 1992 National Family Summit ($25,000), printing of an IYF information kit ($17,583), remuneration—Chair, National Council ($4,800), and incidentals associated with community consultations and stationery design ($9,559).
(5) (a) Community consultations and speaking appointments undertaken by Chair.
(b) Preparation for initial meeting of Council.
(c) Nil.
(d) Yes. $19,585 per annum. Ms Jennifer Rowe.

(6) $1.65m was provided in 1992-93 and $0.17m for 1993-94 for preliminary planning for the Year. Expenditure in 1992-93 is estimated at $1.12m. Final allocations for 1993-94 and 1994-95 will be determined in the 1993 Budget context.

(7) Delays in planning caused by the transfer of responsibility for IYF to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and then, following the Federal election, to the Minister for Family Services have resulted in an underexpenditure of $0.53m in 1992-93. These funds have been rolled over to 1993-94.

(8) (a) While all items listed have been commenced, the only items completed to date are the report of the second consultancy (Harper), completed in July 1992, and the 1992-93 IYF New Policy Proposal, approved by Cabinet in August 1992.
(b) & (c) Changes in Departmental administrative arrangements for IYF and the 1993 Federal election.
(d) Nil.
(9) Key elements of the IYF timeframe:
July 1993—First meeting of IYF National Council
17 August 1993—Federal Budget announcement of IYF funding
Late Nov/early Dec 1993—UN launch of IYF
A more detailed national time frame and program of initiatives will be released following the 1993 Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Annual Report

In addition, the department produced 8,500 copies of DEET Review, a version of the annual report for broader distribution. DEET Review contains the entire text of the annual report apart from technical appendixes.

The only extra cost associated with DEET Review were $45,000 for printing and distribution, bringing the overall cost of the annual report plus DEET Review to $555,000. The unit cost was $43.02, the major components being:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Annual Report

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many copies of the department's 1991-92 annual report were produced.
(2) What was the total cost per copy to produce and what are the components of this cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Four thousand copies of the Department's 1991-92 annual report were produced.

(2) It is not possible to provide the total cost of producing the annual report because the Department does not maintain separate records of staff time and components other than printing costs. The printing cost of the annual report for 1991-92 was $40 848, or $10.21 per copy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the value of Defence spending in each State for each of the past 3 financial years.

(2) What is the total value of the work carried out to date in conducting the Commercial Support Program (CSP) in relation to the research and development and production functions of the Materials Research Laboratory (MRL) Tasmania.
(3) What CSP meetings have been held in relation to the MRL Tasmania activity, when were they held and by whom were they attended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Defence Spending by State

ANSWER.PARA: ACT NSW VIC QLD SA WA TAS NT

Note: The majority of Defence spending overseas has been excluded from these figures, but not all overseas expenditure is separately identifiable as the processing of payments in some instances is handled centrally.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, certain other elements of expenditure including some capital equipment payments are also handled centrally. As a consequence the expenditure profiles for some States and Territories, particularly the ACT, may be distorted.

(2) The evaluation of the MRL-Tasmania function under the Commercial Support Program commenced in late 1992. Officers involved in this evaluation have contributed to the exercise on a part time basis, for example in their capacity as members of the Management Review Team (MRT) or the In-House Team (IHT). Such activities have been included in their normal duties, and it is not possible to isolate the costs associated with their contributions to the MRL-Tasmania evaluation.
(3) The following formal meetings have been held in relation to the CSP review of MRL-Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have representatives of the Air Traffic Controllers Union advised the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) that they have serious concerns about the safety of the new airspace system due to come into effect on 11 November 1993.
(2) Has an independent cost/benefit study been prepared on the new mandatory transponder requirement.

(3) Will jet airline traffic at airports such as Kununurra and Karratha no longer receive a directed traffic or separation service from the CAA; if so, which other countries have a similar procedure at airports with a similar air traffic mix.
(4) Has the Regional Airline Association advised the CAA that it is opposed, on safety grounds, to certain aspects of the CAA's proposed airspace system.
(5) Is the CAA proposing any modifications to the airspace system in response to comments from industry participants.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Civil Air Operations Officers' Association (Civil Air), representing Air Traffic Control staff, has not advised the CAA that they have serious concerns about the safety of the airspace management arrangements scheduled for introduction on 11 November 1993.

In a letter to the Authority dated 13 May 1993, the President of the Association stated, `The position of Civil Air has been that we would accept the CAA plan provided that the industry agreed and more importantly understood the changes, and further that practical procedures can be developed.' Additionally, in the same letter, the Association stated that it had `some difficulties with some of the practicalities', but `consultation continues.'

In a previous letter dated 7 May, their Vice President Administration, as Association project officer for the Airspace Classification System, discussed the matter of a statement on philosophy for the provision of services, mainly to jet operations. The issue of management of the traffic information to Instrument Flight Rules (IFR) aircraft about Visual Flight Rules (VFR) aircraft who enter Class E airspace without a transponder was also raised.

The CAA considers that the matters expressed by Civil Air relating to the airspace model have been properly addressed through the consultative process that has been undertaken, and through the practical workshops which have had both industry and Association representation. This mechanism has allowed the Authority to work closely with these bodies to develop procedures and to ensure a common understanding of the changes.

(2) An independent cost/benefit study has not been prepared on the transponder requirements for the new airspace model. Where a transponder requirement has been mandated in the new arrangements, alternative procedures such as reporting by radio, or specific conditional exemptions, will exist to offset the requirement to carry a transponder.

(3) For over 20 years jet Regular Public Transport (RPT) flights have been operating into uncontrolled aerodromes such as Kununurra without a separation service being provided by the Authority, ie without Air Traffic Control. Since December 1991, these operations have been operating to and from similar locations without a directed traffic information service about VFR flights.
The CAA has developed and enhanced previous practices of mandatory broadcasts to ensure that jet RPT aircraft have self-help traffic advice about all flights, both IFR and VFR.

(4) There has been no advice from the Regional Airlines Association (RAA) indicating that they are opposed to certain aspects of the airspace system. At a meeting with RAA pilots and two RAA Managers, the attitude was expressed that a directed traffic information service should be available to IFR RPT flights. The Authority is examining the feasibility of providing a limited service.

(5) The Australian Airspace Classification System is the result of the most comprehensive consultation program ever undertaken by the Authority. It spans three years during which time every sector of the aviation industry has had the opportunity to contribute to the development of the system. At a consultative forum held in Canberra on 17 February this year, attended by representatives of the various sectors of the industry, an agreement, developed jointly by industry representatives and accepted by the Authority was reached on the way to proceed.

Subsequent to this meeting, three days of workshops were held, on 7, 21 and 22 April, with industry and Civil Air representation at a technical level, to jointly write the procedures for the implementation of the system. Further, a charting workshop, where industry was once again represented, was held on 19 May to jointly determine the methods of presentation of the airspace on charts.

The CAA is satisfied that the airspace classifications scheduled for introduction in November 1993 are the product of exhaustive consultation and that the airspace management arrangements will achieve the necessary balances to preserve, or enhance safety, whilst containing costs to the flying public.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of the investments that the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and Defence Force Superannuation Scheme have in Jupiter's Casino in Queensland.
(2) What are the dates for purchase of shares in the casino.

(3) How are members made aware of the interests that these three superannuation schemes have in the casino, for example are members regularly informed of any purchases or sales of securities relating to the casino, and are members informed of the investment returns on this investment.
(4) Is this an appropriate investment in the light of the adverse publicity which the casino has received regarding irregularities in the tendering process for the Brisbane Casino licence.

(5) (a) What considerations were taken into account in making the investment; (b) what advice did Commonwealth Funds Management (CFM) seek before investing; and (c) were the trustees of each of the funds investing in the casino aware of adverse, or potentially adverse publicity surrounding the project.
(6) Did the department, CFM or the trustees inform the Minister of its/their intention to invest in the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On behalf of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Australian Equities Unit Trust owns 31,226,176 shares in Jupiters Limited at 28 June 1993 which represents approximately 17% of the share capital of this company. Jupiters Limited is the owner and operator of the Conrad Hotel and Jupiters Casino at the Gold Coast, Queensland, and licensee of the proposed new Brisbane Casino. Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM) does not own any Jupiters Limited shares on behalf of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme.

(2) CFM's predecessor, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT), subscribed for an initial investment in the Jupiters Trust of $5 million on 3 August 1983 represented by 20 million partly paid units. These units were converted to fully paid units on 29 October 1984.
Subsequent transactions, including bonus issues and capital reconstructions, have resulted in the present investment in Jupiters Limited.

(3) Members are informed of the Funds' investment policies and of the investment returns on each asset class, eg. Australian shares, international shares, fixed interest, but reporting does not extend as far as investment returns, purchases or sales of securities at individual investment level. This would be an extremely difficult exercise given the many transactions undertaken by the Funds manager. Nevertheless, reference to the Jupiters Casino investment was regularly included in SFIT's annual reports since 1983.

(4) The investment in Jupiters Limited has outperformed, in share price terms, the Australian Stock Exchange All Ordinaries Accumulation Index by a significant margin since 1983. This has been beneficial in financial terms to the interests of members of the respective superannuation schemes. CFM is not aware of any irregularities on the part of Jupiters Limited in the Brisbane Casino licence process which would cause it to dispose of the investment.
(5) The investment by SFIT was undertaken only after exhaustive examination of the proposal over a two year period prior to the investment being made.

(a) The decision was based solely on investment criteria and portfolio diversification undertaken in accordance with the responsibility to enhance investment returns in the best interests of members of the scheme.

(b) SFIT sought extensive advice from external independent consultants including a detailed report from Pannell Kerr Forster, Chartered Accountants, a recognised expert in the hospitality and casino industry.

(c) At the time the original investment was made, i.e. 3 August 1983, SFIT was responsible for the management and investment of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund. The Boards of Trustees of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme were not formed until 1 July 1990. The Trustees are not aware of any adverse, or potentially adverse publicity surrounding the project which would cause them to direct the Funds manager to dispose of the investment.

(6) No. The legislation governing the activities of SFIT at the time the original acquisition was made did not require individual investment proposals to be referred to the Department of Finance or the Minister. Since the creation of the CSS and PSS Boards the responsibility for investment policy has rested with the Trustees.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 1 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an answer given to Estimates Committee E in which it was stated that the Department of Transport and Communications is currently considering the recategorisation of the Launceston Airport:

(1) What is being considered in the way of recategorisation of the: (a) security service; (b) fire service; and (c) protective service, and for each service: (i) has it yet been decided whether the categorisation is to be downgraded; if not, when will such a decision be made; and (ii) what will be the impact on jobs.

(2) (a) How many passenger movements go through the airport annually; (b) what does this mean in terms of the airport's overall categorisation; and (c) what does that categorisation mean in terms of services required to be provided.
(3) Is a formal instrument of recategorisation being considered; if so, what are the details, including when such an instrument may be expected to be issued.
(4) Is the Federal Airports Corporation aware of any possible future decline in demand for passenger services at Launceston Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The Department of Transport and Communications has recently considered the security categorisation of Launceston Airport. A decision has been made to reclassify it to Security Category 3. The airport security categorisation does not affect the security service (that is, the Federal Airports Corporation's security staff) nor the fire service.

The only significant impact of a change in the security category of Launceston is that the Department will no longer insist on the Counter Terrorist First Response (CTFR) capability provided by the Australian Protective Service (APS) at the airport. The APS currently provides one officer per shift, a total of 3 officers for this purpose.

(b) (i) and (ii) No consideration is being given to the recategorisation of the Rescue and Fire Fighting Service at Launceston. A category 6 level of Fire Service is provided at Launceston which is in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organisation recommended practices.
(c) See my answer to (1) (a).
(2) (a) There are 393,027 domestic passenger movements; the Regional Airlines account for an estimated additional 62,000 passengers.

(b) Security categorisation is determined by consideration of both the number of regular public transport passengers using the airport and the airport's frequency of use by aircraft seating over 100 passengers. In the case of Launceston, the change in the pattern of operation by airlines utilising Launceston including the use of smaller aircraft contributed to the decision to change the categorisation of the airport.
(c) See my answer to (1) above.
(3) A formal instrument of recategorisation was signed on 18 June 1993.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Achievements in Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 4 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total cost of consultancy services associated with the preparation of the Department's book, entitled Achievements in Employment, Education and Training.
(2) What were the total costs associated with the book in the following areas: (a) preparation; (b) printing; (c) publicity and promotion; and (d) distribution.
(3) Did the majority of the achievements acknowledged in the book take place before 1992.
(4) How many copies of the book were printed.
(5) How many copies of the book have been distributed.
(6) Has the book been distributed following individual requests or has it been distributed to all contacts on the Department's mailing list.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The total costs of consultancy services associated with the preparation of the book entitled The Resource Book: Achievements in Employment, Education and Training were $13,646.00 for artwork, design and typesetting.
(2) The total costs associated with the book in the following areas were:
(a) preparation, $13,646.00 for artwork, design and typesetting;
(c) no publicity or promotion was undertaken; and
(d) distribution,$16,788.58.

These costs do not include DEET staff costs. A Public Affairs Officer Grade 3 ($44,280 pa.) managed the production of the publication along with a number of other projects over a period of five months. Other DEET staff at various levels were involved from time to time assisting with the publication.
(3) The majority of the achievements acknowledged in the book took place before 1992.
(4) 8,038 copies of the book were printed.
(5) 7,538 copies of the book have been distributed.
(6) The book has been distributed following individual requests as well as to some of the contacts on the Department's mailing list.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a collection of material on the Disability Reform Package which was distributed enclosed with a letter from the Chairman of the Disability Task Force (Mr John Bowdler) of 24 May 1993:
(1) How many sets of leaflets have been distributed Australia-wide.
(2) What was the total mailing cost associated with distributing the leaflets.
(3) Who was responsible for packaging the leaflets and what did this cost.
(4) On what basis were the recipients of the leaflets determined.
(5) Did many small businesses throughout the country receive the material totally unsolicited.
(6) On what basis was it decided to distribute this material in a wide variety of languages, much of which would have been totally indiscernible to the recipient.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A total of 22,718 sets of Disability Reform Package (DRP) information were distributed Australia-wide. Of these, 11,495 were sent to intermediaries working with Non-English Speaking Background (NESB) communities and 11,223 were sent to intermediaries working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Intermediaries include organisations such as welfare and community groups and Migrant Resource Centres as well as individuals such as social workers and doctors who work with specific communities.

(2) The total mailing cost associated with distributing the leaflets was $19,254.20 for NESB intermediaries and $6,612.07 for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander intermediaries. The difference in cost reflects the difference in the material sent to people on each mailing list.

(3) The Australian Government Publishing Service arranged for Ambassador Press to package the leaflets. The total cost of packaging (inserting and lodging) the leaflets was $9666. This cost is in addition to the mailing costs.

(4) The recipients of the mailouts included intermediaries such as welfare and community groups and Migrant Resource Centres as well as individuals such as social workers who work with NESB or Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

(5) The Department's mailing list comprises organisations and individuals who have indicated their interest in receiving information that may be of relevance to them. Only those small businesses which had asked for general Social Security information relevant to NESB or Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities would have been targeted in the mailout.
(6) It was decided to distribute DRP material in a range of languages on the basis that:
many intermediaries work with a range of NESB communities;
it was not possible to predict in all cases which particular translation intermediaries needed; and

it was more cost and time effective to distribute the DRP information in the full range of community languages than to split the mailout into language-specific groups. The English versions of the translated material were distributed during the previous six months.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the latest best estimate of the number of men in Australia aged 65 and over who are not in receipt of any age or service pension.
(2) What is the latest best estimate of the number of women in Australia aged 60 and over who are not in receipt of any age or service pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) At June 1993 there were about 228,300 men in Australia aged 65 and over who were not in receipt of any age or service pension.
(2) At June 1993 there were about 516,800 women in Australia aged 60 and over who were not in receipt of any age or service pension.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 18 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the concerns of the Barngala people of South Australia over mining by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) at Iron Princess:
(1) What process of consultation took place between the Barngala people and BHP over the effect of mining at Iron Princess on sites significant to the Barngala people.
(2) When did these consultations take place and for how long.
(3) Who was involved in the consultations.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statements by the South Australian Minister for the Environment (Mr Mayes) that the consultations were effective; if so, will the significant sites be given the fullest possible protection under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister has been advised by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) that the concerns of the Aboriginal community first arose not during any direct consultations in the past on mining at Iron Princess, but from an invitation to the Barngala (spelt Barngarla) people by BHP to visit a proposed waste dump site in the vicinity of mining at Iron Princess.

(2) Since the concerns were raised with BHP by the Barngarla people, following their visit to the proposed dump site, there have been satisfactory ongoing consultations between BHP and the Barngarla people. These consultations have been assisted to an extent by the appointment by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of the Hon Hal Wootten AC, QC under Section 10(1)(c) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. The Hon Hal Wootten AC, QC was also appointed by the Minister under Section 13(3) to attempt to resolve the dispute by mediation.
(3) The current rounds of consultations have involved BHP, traditional Aboriginal owners, the Barngarla Aboriginal Consultative Committee and the Hon Hal Wootten AC, QC.

(4) Yes. However, a function of the appointment of a person under Section 10(1)(c) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 is to provide a report on the matters set out in Section 10(4) of that Act. These matters include the adequacy or otherwise of the processes used by the State, and by other relevant parties such as BHP, to ensure the adequate protection of significant Aboriginal areas and places which may be under threat of injury or desecration. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is not able to exercise his powers to make a declaration under the Act until he has received and considered the report which has been commissioned from the Hon Hal Wootten AC,QC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to statements appearing in the magazine Pest Talk in April 1993, the organ of the Australian Environmental Pest Managers Association (AEPMA), relating to the implementation by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) of the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) contained in the report Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia:
(1) Who, in the AAVCC, conveyed the information appearing in the article in Pest Talk to the magazine and who was the individual to whom the information was conveyed.

(2) Has anyone in the AAVCC secretariat had discussions with Mr Ross Blackmore in relation to the NHMRC final recommendations on cyclodienes; if so, was Mr Blackmore dealing with the AAVCC on this matter in his capacity as the Regional Director of Velsicol, the company distributing the cyclodienes heptachlor and chlordane in Australia, or in his capacity as Chief Executive Officer of the Environmental Pest Managers Association, or in both of these capacities.
(3) Is the information in the article in Pest Talk which refers to the AAVCC and the NHMRC recommendations correct; if not, in what respects is it incorrect.

(4) Is it of concern to the Minister that in dealing with the AEPMA representatives, the Government may not know in which capacity an individual representative is acting or providing information or that the person with whom it is dealing is in a situation of a conflict of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1 and 2) The AAVCC has consulted a wide range of people and groups in investigating the issue of the continued use of cyclodiene termiticides, including consumer groups, environmentalists and industry. No one within the AAVCC Secretariat has spoken directly to the producers of Pest Talk or Mr Blackmore about the specific recommendations on the cyclodienes. As the sole supplier of commercial quantities of chlordane and heptachlor, Velsicol has regular contact with Officers of the Department in relation to the approval of applications for the importation of these chemicals under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.

(3) There are differing views regarding the alternatives to the cyclodiene termiticides, particularly in relation to their effectiveness. It will be necessary for all the these views to be considered before the final decision on the future of the cyclodiene termiticides is made.

(4) Officers of the Department frequently have contact with individuals from industry, the consumer and environmental movements and other special interest groups. At times some individuals will present with potential dual and differing representation. In these circumstances officers are well aware of the potential conflict of interests and need to ensure that the confidentiality of certain information is maintained. Departmental officers are also always conscious of their responsibilities under the relevant legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 14 December 1992:

PARA.TAB: For each labour market program the department currently offers, what is the average per unit cost of the program for each person who finds full-time employment within 3 months of having left that program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Government has established a comprehensive array of labour market programs (LMPs) specifically designed to overcome particular barriers to employment or labour market disadvantage.
Through a process of Post Program Monitoring (PPM) the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) follows up LMP participants

ANSWER.PARA: three months after their labour market assistance has ended. A "positive outcome" is recorded where a participant is in unsubsidised employment or further education or training not provided through DEET.

PARA.TAB: Simply measuring the number of people in unsubsidised employment understates the successful outcomes for many people who at the PPM census/survey time were successfully continuing in training.

The table indicates the current (May 1993) average net unit cost for major LMPs and proportions of LMP participants who were in unsubsidised employment three months after LMP assistance ended. These proportions are based on March 1993 survey results which cover program completions during the 1992 calendar year.

(a) The average net unit cost discounts the gross cost for offsets (direct savings in Job Search Allowance and Newstart Allowance outlays) as a result of an unemployed person being placed on a wage subsidy, training or work experience program and receiving alternate Commonwealth income support. For wage subsidy/work experience programs the offsets are also discounted for the estimated employment displacement effect of the program.
